This game is great! Not only is the story good, but because of the open world, you can try new tactics and aircraft again and again and never get bored! The DLC's are also pretty good, adding a dog-fighting mission, and 2 anti-ground missions. The aircraft trees and skins also provide challenges to complete in order to 100% the game. Overall this game is a 10/10, but to be fair, this game is unique so I can't compare it to something else.

My interest in this game was piqued after playing Project Wingman, expecting an experience at least equal to, if not better, considering this game was made by a triple A studio. Honestly, save for a few missions, I loved this game. At least for the first 2/3 of the game, anyway. 

The campaign's storytelling and momentum completely broke down pretty much immediately in the last 1/3 or so, destroying everything it built up to throughout the rest of the game. I won't spoil the plot points, but the final mission especially just felt rushed and tedious, with the fights pretty much almost entirely influenced by whether or not the game wants you to hit your opponents. 

I can't really speak for the multiplayer as I didn't try it. The general gameplay feels good, so if you don't care about the campaign, it couldn't hurt to try, I suppose.

But if story IS what you're looking for, just play Project Wingman, if you haven't already. The game's story, pacing, music, etc. is leagues better, with the added benefit of supporting an indie dev that really deserves the support.

The original arcade action flight game is back!!! This version of Ace Combat is as great as the others. Visually stunning with enough aircraft to satisfy anyone into flight sims without the pain of (sims). The game is just fun.  The story is meh, but really who plays games like this for a story?

An excellent game after years of absence of Ace Combat games. Graphics are gorgeous, and the new mechanics like PSM and improved enemy AI is easy to learn for newcomers in the series, and difficult to master for veteran pilots. The DLC missions are among the best missions of the entire game.

The game does not support Flight sticks, Widescreen, key mapping and other stuff (like menu without Mouse support) because it is a port of the PS4 version. Keep this in mind if you're going to buy it for PC. If you can play it on PS4, go for PS4. Ace Combat has always been a Playstation game.

For veteran pilots who played the "Holy Trinity": [spoiler]The story is enjoyable but has its drawbacks, certaintly not at the level of 5 and or Zero, but miles better than 6 and Assault Horizon.  Its worth a try.[/spoiler]

Edit: my initial review below still stands (largely) BUT, I embraced the cheesiness of the dialogue and I now howl with laughter rather than get frustrated with it. I think it is because I was stuck on one mission and had to hear the stupid lines repeatedly. I still think it has some *meh* missions and the story is pretty dull by AC standards, there is very little attachment to any of the characters. Count, for example is just boring and his AI basically doing nothing but moaning all the time is just urgh. But yeah, I gave it another chance and like it a lot more now. The MP has a high skill-ceiling but is pretty cool too. 7.5/10

Coming close to finishing the game now and it is a slog. As a fan of the series I was expecting this to be a return to form after the mediocre AC AH, which without emulation has been our only alternative to Project Wingman or sim games. Graphics-wise, great. Music-wise, god-tier. Gameplay-wise, mixed-bag. Some missions are fine, nothing special, just fine, others have lousy instant-fail conditions. Great controls, superb explosions, the aforementioned soundtrack etc.. BUT, the teammates just NEVER STOP TALKING. Literally every second some lame, nonsensical quip about sandwiches comes through the radio, or some bloke starts telling you a tale about a mysterious pilot who made his enemies feel like antelopes or something. It's completely immersion breaking and both poorly written and not amusing.  IT NEVER STOPS. If you enjoy the dialogue, great, good for you but urgh, drove me nuts. 6/10

As many people already stated, this is NOT a flight simulator. Seriously, the flight model, basically, isn’t. The weather is static and serves as a set of obstacles. But, it’s not what this game is about.
This game is about beautiful (static) clouds, movie tropes, and a lot of explosions. This game is about realistically stupid politics, realistically insane generals and hilarious mess which the global security and intelligence community is. Oh, and if you didn’t forget to get a DLC, if you’re stuck on a mission that’s not your style, you can just grab an overpowered cheatplane, finish it and return to your flying bae F-2A.

TLDR; The game is unrealistic, and has an unenjoyable story, but fun and varied gameplay. Probably not worth $60, wait for a sale.

An arcade air combat game. Don't expect realism or a good story (because games aren't known for that).
However, the gameplay is good, mainly with well varied levels. You'll find each level has its own interesting fun gimmick. Nimble drones, giant plane, base attacks, and windy canyons.

Planes escalate in speed and power, and have a selection of special weapons to mount on them which include a giant cruise missile, railguns, lasers, firing multiple missiles at once, or a faster and more maneuverable missile. Some planes are special and allow you to do interesting maneuvers which can give you an edge in a multiplayer dogfight.

Other things like sound and graphics? They make the game pretty, and it also runs well too. I have a medium-end PC and I can maintain smooth frames consistently. I don't remember experiencing the game crashing or freezing, either. The soundtrack is also good.

Really bad story.  The worst Ace Combat story out of them all.  The Ace Combat stories are pretty out there in terms of sci-fi, but, still rather immersive and enjoyable.  This one...just wow.  Any adult fan of spy novels or military books will absolutely hate the lack of immersion in this story and the far fetched prisoner air squadron your are forced to fly in after you are court martialed for allegedly assassinating your own president.  There is an annoying supporting character who just confuses the story and eventually serves no real purpose.  She was jailed for fixing a jet fighter and flying it, only to be shot down by an invader in her own country.  Naturally, her own countrymen throw her in jail just because, and force her to fix working million dollar airplanes loaded with bombs as a prison slave because she's special.  In fact, the missions you fly, for the most part, after mission 2, until mission 13, serve no real purpose in the war.  You are just made fun of by the prison guards and your own wingmen who hate you because you are a traitor, but, somehow given a multi-million dollar plane with missiles and forced to fly as a prison slave pilot?  Yea, no thanks.

Its a pretty game with realistic graphics and mechanics work both ways. You can set them to be fictitious for a more game like experience or to advanced for maneuvers that feel like actually how a jet will respond to turns and pitching. The camera angles could be improved like a view given from outside the jet in the previous ACE Combat games with allows to view from a bit far back. Nonetheless its still a great experience.

This game really kicks ass! It is like how games used to be made, but with modern features and details. Tons of replay value, constant unlocks based on a tree with player choice and NOT random loot boxes, and excellent game play. The balancing is very nice, sometimes the best plane statistically is not the best plane for the mission because of plane-specific weapon sets. The missions have a lot of variety in theme and mechanics and tie into the story well. The controls are tight. A lot of customization with plane parts and even skins for single player at a certain point. I would even recommend the season pass, as the missions were fun and had a nice side story to them. The story is nice and cheesy the way it should be.

I haven't had this much fun flying in the deep dark blue sky since Ace Combat 5: The Unsung War. If this is the direction for the series I will pre-order Ace Combat 8 whenever they make it. And I dont preorder often.

Imagine this game from the perspective of someone in the LRSSG. One day, out of nowhere, some random guy you've never heard of joins the unit and is immediately promoted to one of the squad leaders. He never speaks, ever, and nobody cares to mention it. What's even more surprising is that this random jackass, despite once serving in a penal unit for allegedly murdering the president, has access to the most advanced military aviation hardware in the entire world. He also appears to have no blood anywhere in his body, considering he can regularly outmaneuver unmanned drones in a dogfight. His squadmates call him Trigger, his enemies call him Three Strikes, and from what you can tell, he's the most skilled fighter pilot in the entirety of the Osean Air Force, if his insane kill counts are anything to go by.

This is a great game if you like arcade-style casual story games about fighter planes however, i must say that this game does have its problems which are listed below. I bought this game a few months ago and just now decided to write a review for it. I enjoyed it a lot when i was playing it, i dropped it after an hour of trying to get my HOTAS to work, but after many hours of research i finally got it to work with my kit (Thrustmaster TWCS throttle and VKB Gladiator Space EVO stick - to get most hotas' to work you have to map each button individually, which was very annoying) At first i was dissapointed in the gameplay even with the HOTAS, as it didn't really feel nice in the hands for a fighter simulator. I did end up enjoying the game the more i played though. So there's that. 

Now onto the problems that i personally didn't like with the game, and then ill do the things that i liked and loved in the game (respectively) 
1. Poor HOTAS support 
(it takes a long time to configure a HOTAS in this game, as well as it being very jank controls)
2. Weirdly stiff handling or absurdly smooth handling 
(on certain planes i found myself either making 90 degree turns with the high G turn mechanic or barely 30 in the same time with and without the high G turn) [Before you say "oh you just had beginner/expert  flight settings on" i changed them to be expert at the very beginning and kept them static throughout, i don't know why it happened, but it does.]
3. High G turns 
(the camera makes a weird movement that takes me out of the game in third person, the high G turns are a fun concept and fairly well executed, it just makes it feel weird in my hands when i can turn 60 degrees in an F-14 Tomcat while also going 800 (whatever the speed is measured in))
4. really awkward turning mechanics 
(when i was flying between obstacles sometimes the high G turns would turn a bit too much [as stated in my 'weirdly stiff or absurdly smooth handling' segment, sometimes i needed to make an 80 degree turn between two close walls and i either  turned too sharply or too little and crashed)
5. Crashing 
(when i hit a wall or the floor it would bump me about 10-20 feet above where i made contact, this, of course, made tight areas really a pain to get through. I did manage after awhile, but it annoyed me enough to write this. - Also sometimes it was an insta-crash or i get three strikes before i crashed, i dont exactly know why, i assume it was because of health and airspeed.)
6. Lack of variety in weapons 
(you might be confused if you have played the game, but i dont like how each plane only had one special weapon - also 200 standard rockets is way more than anyone would ever need.)
7. missile lock range 
(most modern missiles can lock on to an enemy from an average of 16 KM [farthest you can visually ID an aircraft is about 6KM and almost every single missile in the game is a Fox-2 - heat seeking missile - Fox-1 is a semi-active radar lock, Fox-3 is full radar lock], in the game, you need to be within 2km of the enemy - which is almost entirely too close for comfort IRL, as well as being basically within gun range.)
8. Mission briefing and being wrong
(The mission briefings are mostly correct, but sometimes the mission changes from air attacks to a heavy ground assault halfway through, when i sortie i equip the best weapons for that specific mission, but when i suddenly have to take out 20 ground targets with my standard missiles - because i equipped 4-way-multi-lock air-to-air missiles that i only use like 15 of because the mission changed, it can be quite aggravating.)
9. Per plane parts ( i dont like how it doesnt get rid of your pre-selected parts to upgrade your planes for each mission, whenever i selected a better plane for a mission)
10. plane stats 
(i dont like how each plane has sliders instead of hard numbers for plane stats, its very hard for me to see which is better of two planes that have very similar bars. This game does a better job than others with this however, as each bar's value is more visually different compared to another plane. - even if each stat is not accurate in its job.)
11. low countermeasure count
(there is less than 10 flares in any aircraft - even though flare count in something like the F-16 has more than 20 at all times. While it is understandable within the game's story [with how even one flare costs $57 for things like the A-10, F-15, F-16, and F-22] they would skimp on prices, but in the late and early stage of the game it just doesn't make sense when you are flying several million dollar machines which also burn several hundred dollars worth of fuel every time they take off. [$500-$2000 per hour of flight for commercial planes, Fighters use more.])

Now onto the things i liked about this game,

1. Fairly engaging story 
(i liked the story that takes place in this game, its a little confusing at times and the cut scenes don't really affect missions/game play - all that talk and hypes about the 'best pilot' were squashed when i took them down within 2 minutes. It didn't really feel worthy of all the screen times IMO, also i was on max difficulty)
2. Take off and Landing 
(I really enjoyed taking off and landing between missions, especially when you needed to resupply for specific missions. I also really enjoyed how its optional to skip them if you so choose, but it was a little disappointing when the take offs or landings at the start or end of missions were skipped without warning, i would've loved to land and take off when i started or ended a mission instead of fading to black and a menu popping up.)
3. Variety in planes 
(I really liked the amount of variety in the planes you could pick from, - if the mission briefings were accurate i could've made the right purchase the first time lol - i do also like how each plane was--roughly--put in sequence)
4. Plane upgrades 
(i like how plane upgrades can drastically increase a plane's performance if utilized correctly)

There's so many things i can pull for any single problem or thing i liked about this game, but this is already a long ass review. So here's the TL;DR I like the game, just a lot of minor to major annoyances that can be avoided or conquered if approached properly

TLDR: buy on sale.

The game is both nice, and frustrating at the same time. Planes go whoosh, guns go brr and MISSILE MISSILE MISSILE.
In my opinion, guns don't work well enough to be fun/effective, but you have MISSILES. (and plethora of mostly visual mods, some target guns)

No way to change controls or sensitivity in-game (.ini tweaking exists, but... it's a 2019 game ffs)
Graphics look great, but how you interface the game is uncomfortable.
I like the fact that there is a nice story, but I'm not motivated to listen to everything they say.

I would really appreciate an "objectives" list being displayed. Especially on easy mode.

There is multiplayer. It works. That already beats Rogue Squadron, which would be a fine space flight combat game, but it died, so I was looking for something that works. AC7 works. But you get placed in a lobby with players who have all the modules unlocked, completed the story and know how to fly (probably have some mods that work in MP to, but I won't say with certainty).

If you are looking for technical 1v1 dogfights mostly with noseguns, mostly separated from the chaotic battlefield... look somewhere else. If shooting secondary weapons - aka MISSILES - in a 3D arena while you fly in a jet, this is good choice for you.

My HOTAS was recognized without any extra setup, basic controls work, but cannot reassign them, and it's impossible to do fine adjustments quickly, thus making gunfight spray&pray at best. I tried flying with gamepad, and I think is's better that way. At least there is a simple INI tweak to set sensitivity and that made flying with gamepad buttery smooth.

Obviously this is personal, but I always have problems with aligning myself with the combination of sky, clouds, terrain, radar and UI. When I ignore radar and UI, it gets better. Sad. There is a triangle-arrow thing that is supposed to point towards the current target, but it's just unreliable. Radar position is 2D, lacking any height data (see how Elite:Dangerous solves 3D radar)

To end on a positive note: I think the digital/modern look of the menu and the tactical replay of the mission is cool!

I would love to have an option on Steam to write a review with a "meh" or 50-50 option instead of just thumbsup/thumbsdown, because this game would fit that place in my opinion.

SPOILER ALERT, MISSION LOCK

You accidentally shoot the VIP you are supposed to protect, and this is scripted (as soon as you shoot an enemy on VIP's tail, I suppose)... this makes you a convicted criminal, and... they give you planes to fly... sure, the devs enriched the story by other convicts flying with you and mocking you that at least you're good with MISSILES.

Not a revolution yet but still a revelation by all means.

[b]The newest Ace Combat entry adds a few excellent new changes to the series core gameplay, while taking away some. [/b]
The most notable new feature is the implementation of the volumetric clouds and air turbulence which affects aircraft handling, visibility and weapons use. It finally feels like there is an almost tangible medium between the player and the target, not just a digital vacuum. Also enjoyable is the system of performing post stall maneuvers so with some skill you can break up the circle dogfighting without the quirks of the previous instalment. One of these was softlocking due to running out of ammunition in missions where you cannot rearm ( looking at you Ace Combat 5). Thankfully the system of regenerating rockets seen in Assult Horizon makes a return so we do not have to worry about that anymore here.
Speaking of weaponry, it's especially gratifying to see a range of more futuristic weapons that are available for standard fighters. I am very glad that the parts system has returned, thanks to which you have a wide range of possibilities to tune your fighters according to your needs. 
As for the soundtrack, all Ace Combat games soundtracks are on the very same high-level, but here Keiki Kobayashi has surpassed himself and I guarantee you will find yourself humming the game's leitmotif after completing the campaign.

[b]Ok but what about the features that have been taken away? [/b]
The one that hurts the most is the lack of a co-op mode and various multiplayer modes from AC:Assault Horizon, or even better ... from AC:Infinity. 
The lack of any kind of non-linearity, whether in terms of branching campaign paths (as in ACX) or within maps (as in AC6). Some missions goals btw seem to be way to harsh in the context of excessive score caps required to be done in a very limited time. Something the new players will feel the most. 
I won't elaborate on the plot much but it's a well-written more up-to-date than ever techno-thriller delivered in a very epic way with memorable characters and engaging dialogues between them.

So yeah 9/10 Ace Combat game. Would totally be thrown into solitary for not giving it a perfect score.

Today happens to be the 5th Anniversary, so what a better day to review the game. I absolutely adore and cherish this game, so I might be a bit biased, I've had over 200 hours total across all platforms. The first time playthrough is a experience I won't ever forget, the twists and turns of the story goes keeps you invested, especially if you have played other Ace Combat titles and understand the lore, I won't spoil the details don't worry. The gameplay is the traditional AC experience, it is more of what we love of the series. The music is heavenly, It's perfectly suited to where it plays, It is my favourite in the series. The Multiplayer is pretty good, it's a bit dated in how it works, but I don't think that's a bad thing, all it really needs/needed is more content, like new maps or modes. Overall I love Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown. Thank you Project Aces & Everyone involved.

This is one of my favourite games.  I originally got it for Xbox One, probably after it had been out for a year or two, and thought it a pretty fun game.  I've played a lot of fighter sim games, and they were either way too arcade-ish and unrealistic, or so realistic that they had a really steep learning curve.  This is that one game that has got the balance just right.  In a way, it's almost like Forza for fighter jets.  All the non-fictional aircraft are licensed by their manufacturers...which for an fighter jet nerd like me is a huge deal.  Other aircraft games pale in comparison.  This is my favourite of all time, all games, all systems.
Additionally, the plot is interesting enough to suck you in, and actually care how it all turns out.  The graphics are good, especially the aircraft models. The level design is creative and challenging. With my moderately powerful computer, I get good framerates at all times.

I have only two complaints, and I'm sorry, but I'm gonna be that nit-picky person.

First complaint is that 90% of the characters are white, and the only Black character I noticed ("Wiseman") is given a rather parodic/stereotyped voice - like someone told the actor, "Ok, try to sound Black.". And he gets killed off too. It bothered me - it just feels like a slight, an unnecessary microaggression.

The second is that you cannot select the gender or pronouns of your character "Three Strikes".  We never see the character or hear their voice, and the name is ambiguous, so there is absolutely no reason why it has to default to cisgendered male. I imagine that fixing this would incur and unacceptably high cost, requiring editing a lot of dialogue and re-recording a lot of voice acting. I get that.  All I would ask is that the next game in the series allow the player to select, "he/his, she/her, and they/their", and adjust pronouns and dialogue accordingly.  I'm sure it seems like a fussy complaint, but little stuff like this is how normalization happens, how people like me become "normal" and acceptable. Other games have done this perfectly (Baldur's Gate 3 comes to mind), and the standard should be that a game character can be trans or non-binary and that all the other supporting characters in the game treat them with the same respect that you would expect for any other human being, and nobody makes a big deal out of it.  I don't think it's a big ask.

These complaints aside, this is one of my favourite games of all time. I recommend it, with the caveat that players ought to join me in applying consistent, respectful pressure to the game designers so they remember to correct these two oversights on future releases.

For those familiar with the Acecombat series for PS2, Acecombat 7 Skies Unknown appears to be a much needed and welcome return to its original form. A complete revert away from the trash that came out with the PS3 and later (looking at you Assault Horizon). If you haven't figured it out, I absolutely love the earlier Acecombat series. For an arcade style flight sim, the storylines tend to be really good, the music is fantastic, and little details like delay in sound over distance add a wonderful depth to the game. Furthermore, it looks stunning on PC and the ability to play with an actual joystick is nice however, ot feels weird not having a PS2 controller in my hand. It's supposed to come out for switch in July.

I got this game when it was on a crazy good deal, and it has to be quite possibly one of the best purchases I've ever made.
No joke, this game got me into the franchise and obsessed with it.
As a starting point for newcomers, I feel like this does the job quite nicely. And after buying some of the past games for my PlayStation 2, I can see that this game perfectly accommodates for veterans of the franchise as well with amazing set pieces and callbacks.
Wish I could have played the other games first before Ace Combat 7 to be able to lose my marbles on some of the things that does happen given the context. But I would have never gotten into those games without this one.
Sure, the story is serviceable at best and definitely pales in comparison to some of the prior games. But where this game it sells at is in its hype gameplay.
Out of all the Ace Combat games I have played so far, this is the one I like to replay the most. With some extraordinary set pieces and dialogue, and especially the extraordinary soundtrack that accompanies each unique mission.
I cannot sing this games praises enough, I would highly recommend getting this in your library. Especially when it comes to the steam sales where the price of the $60 game can go down to the low low price of $8 or $9.
Jump in the cockpit and enjoy the joyride, you won't regret it.

Dwayne Johnson's remarkable journey to success
Dwayne Johnson's upbringing was far from glamorous. Born into a family of wrestlers, with his father Rocky Johnson and his mother Ata Johnson, who is the adopted daughter of professional wrestler Peter Maivia, he was no stranger to the world of wrestling. However, the family's financial situation led them down a challenging path, exposing Johnson to a life marked by conflict and minor criminal activities. These early struggles became the driving force behind his relentless work ethic and determination to succeed.

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. 

Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. 

However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

I am not the type to write serious reviews, I either just shitpost or simply don’t make a review, but I think I NEED to make a review for this game in specific. 

Before this, I had never played both an arcade flight simulator nor an Ace Combat game. I originally found this game through its amazing soundtrack and followed it until I got a new computer. I eventually got this during a sale and tried it out for the first time and I fell in love with it since. It’s become one of my favorite games of all time that I have now and I frequently listen to its OST. 

Gameplay is amazing, soundtrack is perfection, controls are iffy but easy once you understand it which shouldn’t take too long. Game time is around 8 hours if you take your time and the story is interesting in my eyes. Coming back to levels that I originally struggled with and instantly clearing them with ease makes this so much more fun. This game is a must have in my opinion, best 12$ I’ve spent.

Legitimately one of the greatest games I have ever played. 
The story can seem incoherent on the first play-through if you're unfamiliar with the overall lore of the franchise and you're not paying attention, but the gameplay is just immaculate. Soundtrack is a 10/10. Very fun and atmospheric. 

Multiplayer is a furball and isn't for me, but that doesn't mean you can't have fun in it. 

Overall, 9.9/10.

Aside from the price, what's not to like about this game? 

Story wise, I would feel much better if this was set in an alternate universe to current day than a completely different universe with a whole lotta different country names. The story is simply there as a filler in my opinion and is completely scripted. No user choice at all.

Gameplay wise, it's always a simple "fly there, shoot enemies" with a cutscene in between each mission trying its best to explain the story. However, what is not simple is the chaos in each dogfight. Every plane has their own ideas and fly about the place making planning absolutely go out the window, coupled with the sheer number of maps available makes no two sorties feel the same. 

Multiplayer is very enjoyable, although a player with some very advanced aircrafts can easily trash pretty much everyone. Multiplayer does give you a lot of money very quickly so it is a really good place to farm cash and have fun while you're at it.

TL;DR, it's very fun for both aviation enthusiasts and the average gamer (I do wish there's SplitScreen, if there is one, I haven't discovered it yet).

***SPOILERS***

I got into the ACE series with AC6. I enjoyed the game so much that I ended up creating my entire gamer ID around it. The dialog was...cheesy, but the game play was so enjoyable. I loved everything else about it! So when I built a PC and decided to purchase AC7, I was pumped. Man am I disappointed! 
.
One of the best things about AC is the user interface, and in-game play. This newest version is rough. The dialog is absolutely atrocious. I enjoy campaigns. I enjoy the story that has been curated for me, but even now, I'm on level 12 and I still don't know which nation I am flying for. I still don't understand what happened in level 4 (assuming that'll be answered later). And I still don't get most of the character interactions.
.
The radio chatter is just bad. "You'll go into solitary if you disobey!" -Already *allegedly* killed the former president. Pretty sure you'd keep me from flying again if that happened. "Shut up and do your job!" - Literally just asking mission critical questions. "That bird is worth more than your life. Don't scratch it!" (Same mission) "Escort our planes out of there. They are mission critical. You're expendable." -So you don't mind if I crash the plane then???
.
The menu, sub menu, sub-sub-menu, is so detailed and flimsy it's hard to navigate at first. Not anything to really be concerned about, I'm just being picky.
.
The amount of upgrades available for purchase in the aircraft tree is a welcome site over AC6. You start out basic and move to more advanced planes and weapons. I like the availability of upgrading other aspects of flight as well. I do however HATE the aircraft tree itself and think its a far over complicated system. Also, the price for some items will take a huge amount of play time to unlock everything. (also just being picky with this portion. I get it's a game. Play to upgrade)
.
I love and hate the upgrade to "realism" that is brought in by the weather development. Lightning can strike, effecting performance. Air turbulence pushes you around. The radar becomes less accurate in heavy cloud cover. This is a nice touch on a game that is supposed to be "realistic".
.
Overall I would recommend the game to fans of any war sim, but bare in mind, this is not, nor will ever be a fully polished game. There are aspects that just piss you off throughout.
its fun as hell

Games like this scratch a specific itch.  For what it is, Ace Combat 7 is a smooth air combat game, in the same vein as Call of Duty is for warfighter games.  AC7 is not a flying simulator -- that's Xplane or MS Flight Simulator.  Overall, the goal here is combat.  Blow the baddies out of the sky.  Rain terror over enemy strongholds.  Fly fast, roll, flip, evade, shoot.

The graphics are not a point of focus, though good for the time of release using Unreal Engine 4, the models of the jets look great in a sunsetting sky above the clouds (where you can't see the low-res terrain).  AC7 has multiplayer which is geared more for solo queuing, just as their non-coop campaign is.  You can technically queue in multiplayer with friends using the in-match 'Invite a friend' option, but you'd have an easier time with the Steam friends list and either 'Invite' each other or 'Join' each other's games using that interface.  Hopefully Ace Combat 8 will REALLY refine their multiplayer experience and community.

I bought this game on Steam's Winter Sale for a couple bucks, and also purchased some DLCs after putting some hours into it.  For the money, I think it's worth it.  I've had a fun time buying planes and parts and spec'ing out my machines.  However, even for the money I paid, I would've hoped for a better campaign.  I don't enjoy this solo campaign.  The creators tried to do too much all at once.  Objectives are frustrating in early-game because mission preparation is pointless. 
 You're not going to have the right equipment to do what you need to do and beginners have a tough time.  It's not until you put in many hours and buy more advanced items will the mission objectives finish like they're designed to.  The story line is not worth watching in the cutscenes.  The AI wingman radio banter is cringe and would've been better just not included at all.  I hope the developer doesn't carry-over the same poor writing into the next game -- which I'm interested in playing if it has Unreal Engine 5.

This game is so good. 

The graphics are marvelous even on lower graphical settings, and explosions and other effects are realistic and impactful.

It has VR support, although the selection of planes in VR is much less than the other modes.

There are around 20 missions in the singleplayer mode, most with different premises and gimmicks, which are quite creative, and I find myself coming back to AC7 again and again and again. Huge replay value. The plot, while extremely hard to believe, sucks you in and really engages you.

The soundtrack just keeps getting better and better. Every mission's soundtrack is great one way or another, some just standing inches above the rest.

Now, is this game worth full retail price? Maybe. However, it's much better if you get it on sale, such a good deal for a lower price.

If you loved this game and are waiting for AC8's (eventual) release, play Project Wingman. It's really about the same.

Every mission has some dumb wildcard gimmick that turns an otherwise fun and cool arcade flight sim into a tedious puzzle to contend with.  The tight time limits in timed missions change it into a desperate race of mental logistics and time management.  You're not playing the game.  The game's playing you. The whole experience is expressly anti-fun, which is sad, because it could have been so much fun.

I didn't count or write it down, but there were too many missions that took me more than five tries on normal difficulty because of time limits or bogus gimmick junk (inclement weather like thunder/sand/wind, escort BS).  Mission 12, a "protect this thing" mission, was the final straw for me.  I'm not crashing, I'm not getting shot down, I'm not even running out of time and I'm still failing. Trying over and over again was just not fun. I really wanted to like it, I really do love the premise, but it did it's best to kill the fun every single step of the way. Huge waste of time. Maybe I will try it again someday but not anytime soon.

This game is a very big disappointment.  In terms of visual effects, Hawx 2 did better, and the difference is a dozen or so years.  Too complicated narrative typical of Japan, faction names difficult to remember.  I still don't know which side I fought on.  An unsatisfying upgrade tree, frustrating checkpoints and not very clear messages about the current mission goals.  The mechanics of wheeled combat are not implemented, it is difficult to use the on-board gun, and there is no use of radar-guided weapons.  If you come here as an aviation enthusiast, you will be disappointed.  Quite interesting cutscenes, but I have a hard time understanding their connection with the missions.

CAUTION! PULL UP! MISSILE! CAUTION! PULL UP! CAUTION! PULL UP! MISSILE! MISSILE! MISSILE! CAUTION! PULL UP!

These warnings (with their "beeps") will burn into your subconscious, forever.
Story is well crafted, the cutscenes and the briefings afterwards nail the contrast between the "raw" military standpoint and people yearning for peace.

The missions are mostly good, some might be a bit tedious without the right plane and loadout, but a few are straight annoying regardless what you choose honestly. However, the overall impression is still more than positive.

FILMHANDLUNG
Martin Scorsese erzählt mit seinen Lieblingsschauspielern Leonardo DiCaprio und Robert De Niro die erschütternde wahre Geschichte einer Mordserie auf dem Land der Osage in den 1920er-Jahren.
Zu Beginn des 20. Jahrhunderts brachte das Erdöl der Osage Nation großen Reichtum und sie wurde über Nacht zu einem der wohlhabendsten Völker der Welt. Der Wohlstand dieser Ureinwohner Amerikas zog sofort weiße Eindringlinge an, die die Menschen manipulierten, erpressten und den Osage so viel Geld stahlen, wie sie konnten – bis sie sogar zum Mord übergingen. Vor diesem Hintergrund erzählt „Killers of the Flower Moon“ anhand der ungewöhnlichen Liebe zwischen Ernest Burkhart (Leonardo DiCaprio) und Mollie Kyle (Lily Gladstone) eine epische Western-Krimisaga, in der wahre Liebe und ein unfassbarer Verrat aufeinandertreffen. Robert De Niro und Jesse Plemons sind in weiteren Rollen zu sehen. Regisseur von „Killers of the Flower Moon“ ist Oscar-Preisträger Martin Scorsese, der zusammen mit Eric Roth auch das Drehbuch schrieb. Der Film basiert auf dem gleichnamigen Bestseller von David Grann. Quelle: paramount.de

REALLY trying to get into this game but it stops me at every turn.

---------------------

I decide to try out the Mouse and Keyboard controls.

The intro cutscene begins.

In the lower-left of the screen, it tells me I can skip the cutscene.

However, it's using the xbox controller controls, so I have no idea what button to press.

I press Esc. Nothing.

I press Space Bar. Nothing.

I press Enter. Nothing.

I press - and I cannot stress enough that this not hyperbole - every single number and letter on my keyboard, including the numpad. Nothing.

I Alt-Tab out because what I OBVIOUSLY really wanted to do was 'research', not 'play a game'.

I find out that the answer is 'F1'. It's F1 to skip the cutscenes.

How silly of me not to have known that.

No matter, I skip the generic-ass cutscene and prepare to play.

The Mouse and Keyboard controls are laughable. The sensitivity is ridiculous.

As a result, the plane on my screen is thrashing around like some kind of wounded sky shark.

I give up on Mouse and Keyboard and decide to try it out on gamepad.

------------------------------------

The game doesn't force me to quit out and restart if I want to use a controller (I'M LOOKING DIRECTLY AT YOU, WARHAMMER 40K - INQUISITOR: MARTYR), so that's nice.

I restart the mission so I can find out what the gamepad controls are.

I take off.

The plane is reacting to my controls just like it should.

Everything feels fine.

I begin to relax.

I have a few moments until I have to engage in combat, so I decide to look around.

I touch my right gamepad stick and the camera WHIPS to the back of my jet, so I'm now looking backwards.

I release the stick.

The camera WHIPS back to the default view.

My frustration begins to rise.

"Relax." I tell myself. "Just drop the sensitivity in the menu."

I pause the game and go to the menu.

Nope, can't find it in the options anywhere - looks like I need to exit the mission.

I exit the mission.

The setting simply doesn't exist. A cursory internet search will show you that you have to manually make changes to your ini file.

This shamelessly expensive game, which claims it was released in the year 2019, *doesn't have a sensitivity slider for gamepad*.

That's fucking ridiculous.

At least Bethesda games let me play them for a bit before they piss me off.

---------------------------------

I tried to ignore it and just 'play'. Nope. If I want to play this game I will need to manually change the ini.

I'm more than capable of doing that (just like pretty much anyone else with a pulse). Maybe one day I will.

But in the meantime I'll be playing games that don't make me manually fix them due to having woefully subpar gamepad options.

I feel pretty confident in guessing that this game is less a game and more a collection of minor annoyances for me, minor annoyances that other people are happy to overlook.

That is genuinely awesome for them, but it doesn't affect my experience one bit.

I bought this game on a whim, and you know what? It was worth. This game slaps.

It's exactly what I was expecting and then some. Some great atmosphere, weather effects, planes for the plane dorks, and tight controls. A good amount of fun missions like raiding, dogfighting, combat support; there's also other missions, like escort. :)

I do have a few nitpicks here. For one, the localization is a bit skrungly. With gems such as, "How could you talk about food?" and "You put the meat between those buns and that burger is well done." You could see how this would be a little distracting while you're trying to dodge fifty missiles. Still, it has an odd charm to it; and the voice actors do their best with it, so it's hard to fault it too much.

This game is by no means easy, I think when all was said and done I game overed on just about every mission at least once. That said, there's generous checkpoints here, and even when some missions get out of control you can at least rely on a respawn after your nearest cutscene.

The story and characters are surprisingly good! It was a little confusing at times, but this is my first Ace Combat game, so eh. I can tell that there was a lot of care put into this. Solid gameplay, solid music. And hey, I'll be hearing MISSILE MISSILE MISSILE PULL UP in my nightmares for some time to come.

When you pay the troll toll, learn the ropes, and then pierce the firmament; it's hard not to feel like an unstoppable sky god. Good stuff.

Ya know... I really, really wanted to love this game.  The thing is, I just don't.  I don't really like hardcore sims because the learning curve is too steep, but AC7 is the complete opposite.  It's just too basic.  It's too arcade-like.  I knew what I was getting into as I have played older AC games, but this one just isn't hitting the smile switch.  After the first two missions, I was pretty much over it.  Now I'm halfway through the missions and it's just like a first-person shooter but in a plane.  It's very similar to the H.A.W.X. game from about a decade ago with slightly better graphics.  I honestly liked that game better over this.

Now, this game isn't terrible (except for the story, which is absolutely HORRIBLE!!) and if you like arcade-like shooters, this is for you.  The graphics are pretty good and it's a descent enough challenge.  As a pilot IRL, I just prefer something where a bit more flight skill is needed.  Unfortunately, no one makes mid-level flights sims any more like the Jetfighter series or the Novalogic series (F-22 Lightning 3 / F-16 Multirole).  I was hoping they would add a little more something like those games but they didn't.  So the only alternative is to go full, hardcore sim and get DCS or you're stuck with MSFS/X-Plane/etc where there is no combat.

Some humongous negatives for this game are:
- No joystick support unless you own ONE specific model.  (Controller works, but people don't fly planes with a controller!!!)
- No multi-monitor.  This was truly disappointing for my 3 monitor setup

So I guess it's still worth playing but it's just not wonderful.  Wait until it is on sale.  Sigh.

First of, Ace Combat is not a Flight Sim or even a Flight Arcade. It's a 90's Hollywood Ace Pilot Game.It has as many logic flaws as said movies, and that's the point, the game is more about what makes it FUN than logic.

Game wise, It's a blast, the challenge is mostly fair, save 1 or 2 places where feels a bit bullshit, a mission with lighting, fog and big spiky cliffs comes to mind!

The game is a solid recommendation if you just want to have a weekend of fun.

My only gripe is the lack of Controller options, specially a more in depth capability of making the controller as I'd like to fly, this really hampered my enjoyment for the first 3-4 hours, until I get used to the arguably worse control scheme.

EDIT(Post Playing Project Wingman): 
It's insane to me that this game has a higher budget but lack of so many features that should be simple to add, that an indie project has. Playing with a custom control scheme and Track IR, made a MUCH lower budget game SO MUCH MORE ENJOYABLE. I still recommend BOTH games, if you like one the other is just an extra cake.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I wish I could refund the game.

I played AC04 in PS2 era.  That was a fine game, if not the best air combat game (I also played AC3 in PS1 era).  The first 2 sorties were okay, nothing groundbreaking but it was reasonably fun and the characters were okay (not as great as AC04, but it is okay).  What annoy me the most, is the stage design.  

First thing first, most mission briefings are misleading at best, about 80% of the mission involve both air AND ground engagement, u thought it is a air combat mission and took your best fighter, then u need to bomb ground targets.  A ground sweeping mission from briefing? You need to intercept a launching ICBM in the 2nd half of the mission and you are screwed if you are riding the A10 for ground targets in the 1st half.  Most of the time you are better off just invest and bring a good multi-role plane (such as F-35) as you will do everything anyway.  Other than that icing, sandstorm interference, these elements brought nothing new to the table but only causing harassing the players (or force them to bring deicing part on their planes).

Secondly, Easy difficulty is anything BUT easy.  Yes you get easier to shoot down a foe, you can take more beating before going down, but you don't get more time for a search and destroy mission that the time is very tight if you are not in the fastest aircraft.  And there are quite a few escort/protect mission that the escort target(s) go down pretty quickly if you don't kill the target fast enough, and they won't survive longer just because you are in a easier difficulty.

And, last mission worth a individual mention IMO, SPOILER AHEAD

[SPOILER ALERT]
The final part of the mission, require exiting the space evaluator, I had like 50+ attempts retrying and never make it to the exit (always end up crashing somewhere) and having to resort to trainer.  Indeed I died quite a few times in the last mission of AC04, which involve entering the tunnel like this one to destroy the target, but the exit is much more straight-forward than this one, something is wrong with the dev on this one I would say......

And finally I beat the game (except the very last part of the final mission) in easy difficulty, but in my opinion it is even harder to beat AC04 in a F-4 phantom in hard difficulty (No ACE is too much for me) 20 years ago.  And at last I have a complain about the DLC.  I chose the most expensive "TOP GUN: Maverick Ultimate Edition" but I have no access to the best planes (like CFA-44), not the best business practice IMO.....

This game is tagged as a Simulation. It's not.
It's an arcade game and should be labeled as such.

SPOILER WARNING:

It is an OK game for the $10 I paid for it. Had I paid full price I would have been pretty upset. The campaign is straight-up disappointing when compared to Ace Combat 6 (one of my all time favorite games ever). Almost every aspect besides graphics has gotten worse. The story is unbelievably cheesy, and wholly unbelievable(the bar is stupidly low and they still missed it), especially in the first 5 or so missions. The missions themselves are also a lot less fun. In AC6, many missions would have a set amount of objectives (i.e defend these units, assist the fleet in their assault, defend friendly support aircraft), and achieving a certain amount of these objectives would lead to completing the mission. I really liked this system, and was disappointed to see that they did away with that entirely. I also really miss the AC6 feature of calling in allied support or setting your wingman to  a specific target. Also, the standard missiles have an annoyingly short range compared to AC6. There are lots of little things as well that bother me, such as the minimap being almost completely useless in most missions because it is just a simplistic topographical map. In the end, there were only one mission that I really enjoyed, that being the canyon run mission.

Multiplayer is pretty much completely dead so not much to say there

Don't pay more than $10 for this
You'd be better off buying Ace Combat 6

AC series, all missions S in 3, 4, 5, 0, and PSP versions have been cleared with ACE.
It's interesting, but it's one of the least exhilarating in the series.
Even in the old game, there are a lot of troublesome missions that occur once between several missions, but this time there are many.
In particular, One of the drawbacks of the AC series is that it feels sluggish to fly until you encounter an enemy when retrying.
As many reviews have said, it's easy to get stressed out by doing consecutive missions with one arm tied up.
There's something quite irritating about having to restart a game under such a strict time limit.
If you say, 'The time limit is strangely strict and I only clear C rank,' then there is no problem at all. The story will move forward and you will get some money.
Even though one play tends to be redundant, they are forced to use special weapons that are not very interesting.
Having to restart the game when the time is up at the last minute is more painful than fun.
If you try to clear S rank, the difficulty will be severe anyway,
I wanted the game to feel a little more comfortable the first time I played it.

Before falling down the Ace Combat rabbit hole, I didn't really give a shit about fighter jets.
After falling down the Ace Combat rabbit hole, I still don't really give a shit about fighter jets, but these games kick ass.

If you really want a push to be interested in this kind of game but also don't give a shit about fighter jets, consider this. Fighter jets are the closest real-life analogue to anime mecha. Fighter pilots and mecha pilots are similar in that both are specialized pilots that get into a large machine equipped with insane, expensive weaponry that has the ability to kill you near-instantly as long as the pilot can see you. These games have fairly "anime" plot lines too, making it that much easier to mentally substitute "plane" with "mech".

This game inspired me to download the free base game of DCS.  Upon playing DCS I discovered quite quickly I'll need a hotas.  Now, unlike DCS, Ace Combat 7 is very easily played with just a keyboard and mouse.  I did order a hotas for DLC, but until it arrives I am not fit to make a comparison between the two. DCS looks like an excellent game but I won't be able to make a judgment until I receive my hotas. In the meantime....Ace Combat 7 is about the most fun I've ever had playing a jet fighter combat game.  Mouse and keyboard and have an insane blast. I do highly recommend this game if you DON'T have a hotas.  Everything is very easily laid out right on the keyboard and a hotas is not necessary for this game.  Now, once I get my hotas and have a chance to dive into DCS I may come back and edit this review.  But, regardless of how good DCS is, or is not, this game is still a major blast.  It's tons of fun.  If you like missiles and bombs and jet fighters then absolutely buy this game.  👍

OK at a discount. Played this up to campaign completion at hard difficulty. It's a mixed bag, with some gameplay problems that really diminishes the fun. Main ones: 

1. Allied AIs are very ineffective. This destroys the feeling of being in a large battle -- there can be many hostiles and many allies in a mission, but although the hostiles will attack the player or objective to be protected, the allies basically fly around doing nothing.
2. Compounding the above, the targeting and radar display doesn't really work well for the setting given. In some missions, player has to destroy specific objectives with many (>20) other target-able other things nearby. In this situation, cycling through targets to find the correct one is tedious, even without having to dodge missiles in the meantime. The radar display will also be cluttered, which makes it difficult to determine, for example, which direction an enemy missile is coming from. 
3. The diversity of aircraft and weapons feel a bit "fake". Ground attack missions switch halfway to critical air-to-air combat (dogfights involving enemy aces, chasing fast-moving flying targets while being pursued by enemy fighters, destroying components of a flying target that has a lot of fighter escorts), usually with strict time limit. Given the ineffectiveness of the allied AI, it feels like the best course of action is to always pick a plane + parts + special weapons combo that will work well for air-to-air combat. Technically we can still use a combination focused on ground attack for such "ground attack" missions, but it's much more tedious.

Also, as of now (end 2023), it's very difficult to find public room for multiplayer.

ACE COMBAT™ 7: SKIES UNKNOWN is an exhilarating masterpiece that takes flight simulation gaming to new heights. From the breathtaking visuals that make every dogfight feel like a cinematic experience to the intuitive controls that strike the perfect balance between accessibility and depth, this game is a gem for both aviation enthusiasts and gamers alike.

The attention to detail in aircraft design, landscapes, and the overall ambiance is nothing short of awe-inspiring. Each mission feels uniquely crafted, immersing you in intense aerial combat scenarios that keep you on the edge of your seat. The variety of planes and customization options add layers of strategy and personalization, allowing you to tailor your experience to suit your style.

What truly sets ACE COMBAT™ 7 apart is its gripping story line and compelling characters. The narrative draws you in, making every mission not just a battle in the sky, but a piece of a larger, engaging plot. The soundtrack complements the adrenaline-pumping action perfectly, enhancing every moment of triumph or challenge.

Whether you're a seasoned pilot or new to the skies, ACE COMBAT™ 7: SKIES UNKNOWN delivers an unmatched experience that combines stunning visuals, captivating storytelling, and thrilling game play. It's a must-have for anyone looking for an immersive and unforgettable gaming adventure.

Happy flying!

"High-Way To The Danger Zone!"

I pretty much brought the game because I wanted the Top Gun experience and was not disappointed. 
For newbies to the franchise like myself, the plot flew right over my head (pun intended). But the storyline is told uniquely and I found a more 'lived in' world quite engaging. The gameplay, graphics and music are where this game truly shines.

I have yet to see a game that simply welcomes you as the OP hero and lets you run with the idea with full self-awareness; and aiding you are a band of misfits, cool villain and of course beautifully rendered aircraft. I strongly suggest turning off flight aids and playing on the lowest difficulty for newbies and taking an OP DLC aircraft if the going gets tough, then do a second run with something more sane, or perhaps an A-10 only run for funsies...

Nevertheless, I'd say for a replayable game that doesn't outstay its welcome, you can't go wrong.

Ace Combat has never been about realism. Let's be honest, enemy planes can literally turn on a dime and infuriatingly break away from tracking weapons with ease whenever it suits them. No airframe should be able to handle what this game does to them, but that isn't the point. Ace Combat has always been about telling a story in a strange world where aerial combat is akin to arturian legends about epic clashings of steel and magic. It seeks to make you feel like a hero, and by god does it pull it off. At worst you'll be evading missiles and taking pot shots at targets, at its best you are the razor that cuts the sky, and every target falls to pieces in your wake in glorious fireballs. All while sweeping music blasts in your ears, mixing with the constant threat of "MISSILE" blaring in your hud. 

The story will always be a subjective thing, and Ace Combat has never been without a healthy helping of cheese, but it's oh so charming. You'll grow attached to your fellow pilots, and you'll grow to laugh at, and swear at both them and your enemies.
The DLC missions for this game are some of the finest pieces of gameplay the series has ever seen.

I bought this game because I enjoy aircraft related games and while I normally go for more realistic depictions of air combat, I knew what I would be getting into with Ace Combat's more arcadey gameplay. What I didn't know was what a blatant console port this game was..

You don't even get a mouse cursor on a PC game. How ridiculous is that? The graphics and game settings available to you are extremely limited and the non existant control scheme customization is a complete joke. There is only support for like 2 flight stick/hotas options and one of them is an xbox hotas. I use a VKB Gladiator and STECS throttle and cannot use either for anything in this game. It's pathetic. 

The controls are pathetic even if one looks at it as if it were an actual console game. You have like 4 possible changes you can make to your control scheme on an xbox controller. There is no option to change the sensitivity of your view or control sensitivity. 

I'm blown away by the laziness of this game and the overwhelmingly positive reviews it gets. PC players have gotten so shafted and yet they seem to thoroughly enjoy it. This is a shameful port of a lazy console game. 

But aside from the actual gameplay, it looks nice and the battles are interesting. The story bits are fun but they can't make up for the shortfalls in gameplay. It's a no from me dawg.

Not outright bad, but feels like a step backwards for the Ace Combat series.

The graphics are a highlight - the lighting, weather effects, and landscapes are incredible, as are the airplane models. 

The missions come across as your standard Ace Combat options - if you've played any prior AC games, you'll be familiar with the traditional escalation of basic beginning missions, increasingly bigger dogfights and ace squadron battles, timed ground attack missions, and spectacular Death-Star-run style set-pieces. The downside is the length. With mission failures (including the frustrating "you didn't get enough points in the time limit, do those 20 minutes again"), I managed to complete all 20 base game missions in 8 hours. For a $80 game, this doesn't seem worthwhile.

The story is also a big negative. I've played 04, 5, and Zero multiple times, as well as 6 once. I've consulted fan wikis. I still am more confused as to what on Earth (or what in Strangereal) is happening in this game. The other games provide geopolitics that are goofy but still entertaining, with characters that help ground you in the setting. AC7 feels more like a first draft. Or several first drafts in search of a main story. Incomprehensible geography and references to prior games, combined with boring, cookie-cutter characters.

In all, I would say that if you have an opportunity to track down Ace Combat 5, you would be advised to pick that over this game. The graphics aren't nearly as good, but everything else is much better.

Ace Combat 7 is a return to the Strangereal setting and gameplay after the previous controversial title Assault Horizon pivoted towards the real world with a more on rails dogfighting mechanic. If you are a fan that is nostalgic for the other titles than this is a greatest hits of it, especially for Ace Combat 4. Eursea has reformed as a monarchy and is once again the main antagonist with Belkan shenanigans mixed in, Stonehenge returns in all its glory and you once again play a pilot that does not speak a word. 
If you are at all a fan of the previous titles gameplay than this is a sure pick for you, it is everything and more with almost photorealistic graphics. People new to the franchise may be confused by the story but it is still a fun ride with interesting twist and turns from multiple perspectives with heavy pandering towards the Shattered Skies crowd.

There's a fantastic YouTube video essay by Timmm about how "Ace Combat is a Simulator, but not of Reality," and it perfectly describes my feelings towards the Ace Combat franchise and this game in particular. In short, Ace Combat 7 gives you everything you need to feel like the greatest pilot in history, from the crushing lows of political imprisonment to the blazing highs of hard-fought redemption and glory, set to the backdrop of distinctly unreal yet plausible war games. Also (and somewhat ironically), unlike many true simulators, this game is one of the few (official) ways to see inside the cockpits of many 5th gen jets like the F-22, F-35, and Su-57, which is VERY cool. 

It's also pretty cool how the game tries to translate the nuances of real jets into the game's mechanics, like how the Typhoon and F-14 are famous for their ultra long-range missiles (the Meteor and AIM-54 Phoenix respectively), so their jets are both equipped with Long Range Air-to-Air Missiles (LAAM) by default. Also, in real life the F-14 was one of the first jets to be able to track and fire at multiple targets simultaneously, so naturally the in-game version has the option to equip the 6AAM system that can lock and fire upon six targets at once. Heck, the Top Gun versions of the F-14 include Strangereal equivalents to the semi-active radar guided AIM-7 Sparrow.

Jets like the F-22, Su-57, and other supermanuverable/thrust-vectoring jets are also able to perform wildly acrobatic Post Stall Maneuvers (PSM) like the infamous Kobra and Kulbit, which is a nice (if impractical) touch. Much like in real life, PSMs are EXTREMELY high risk and situational techniques that leave you a sitting duck as you twirl around in place, but damn do they look cool, and in the rare cases when they do give you the advantage, you'll have earned all the bragging rights you'll ever need. 

Finally, this game works FANTASTICALLY on a Steam Deck. 60fps at high settings, no problem. I sometimes even dock it for my 55" 4K TV, and it looks surprisingly decent with the Deck's built-in FSR (it's still just an extremely stretched out 1200x800 box in the middle of the screen, but the FSR puts in serious work to make it all extremely legible and playable).

Anyway, cool game, go play it if you haven't already.
worth it

[h1]This is the Ace Combat I've wanted for a long, long time.[/h1]

A return to form, unless you're someone who demands HOTAS support (& doesn't own one of the officially supported sticks. See below.) But if like me all you want is a great arcade flight combat game and you're comfortable playing with a controller, this is the Ace Combat you've been waiting for.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*]The straightforward, classic Ace Combat gameplay I know and love (completing objectives within time limits via repetition and practice, experimenting to find the best aircraft and weapons for the mission, and the satisfaction of just barely squeaking by on higher difficulties) with none of the annoying new inclusions of recent entries (no DFM from AH for instance.)
[*]Visually stunning (search for ini tweaks to enable TAA & greater draw distance - worth it!)
[*]Typically over the top, at times cringey - but that's why we love it - "strangereal" story and world building narrative. Melodramatic & fun.
[*]Stable port with excellent performance on systems meeting system requirements. (One rare exception to this, see CONS below...)
[*]Weather effects (ice, moisture, visibility, lightning, rain, turbulence, etc.) add beautifully to the immersion factor, and affect gameplay.
[*]Decent length. (20 missions. Tons to unlock for replay value.)
[*]Online team deathmatch & battle royal
[/list]

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Limited HOTAS support. (See below.)
[*]Resolution issues. Some users report resolutions seemingly arbitrarily locked. Workaround is to switch to full screen, verify game files, update video driver, and disable desktop resizing. If that doesn't work, try deleting the folder located in C:\Users\yourname\AppData\Local\BANDAI NAMCO Entertainment\ACE COMBAT 7\Config
[*]No FOV (Fix: https://steamcommunity.com/app/502500/discussions/0/1776010325119855174/ )
[*]Lack of full key/button remapping, and mouse directional input inversion. The game really is an almost 1:1 console port, intended for controller play more than kb+m at this point.
[*]Lack of ultrawide resolution support. (Fix: http://www.wsgf.org/forums/viewtopic.php?p=174483#p174483 )
[*]Load & menu lag related to Corsair & Razer keyboards, & certain USB audio devices. Unplugging/uninstalling them resolves it...
[*]VR is console-exclusive at this time.
[*]FXAA only (TAA & longer draw distance ini tweak page 1 & 2 of: https://steamcommunity.com/app/502500/discussions/0/1777135944140331772/
)
[*]Some newcomers may find the narrative slightly confusing without the context of prior games, though personally I don't think I would even without the benefit of having played the others. They provide context, but if you can overlook the series staple cheese and outright oddness, you should be able to follow and understand what's happening without any prior experience. The story is quite self-contained.
[*]The only tutorial the game offers is in the form of radio chatter coupled with brief flashes of text in the first few missions. Users are advised to pay close attention and replay the first few levels if you feel overwhelmed by the sheer amount of info the HUD throws at you. Series vets are used to it, but I can see this being an issue for some.
[*]I love this personally, but expect to replay certain missions - or replay earlier ones to obtain credits for better aircraft - [i]a lot[/i] before figuring out how to achieve victory. I consider the difficulty just about perfect, and it's always been part of AC, but some may find this irksome. Checkpoints during missions are RARE, so expect repetition and practice.
[/list]

[h1]For existing fans[/h1]

For existing Ace Combat fans [b]used to playing with a controller[/b]: This is the return to form we've been waiting for, at least for me. If you already know you love Ace Combat, and all you wanted was an Ace Combat experience without the issues Assault Horizon and Infinity had, then this is the game for you. It's my favorite entry since Shattered Skies, without question. It's challenging, fun, & straightforward.

For existing Ace Combat fans who [b]demand HOTAS[/b] as the interface of choice. Unfortunately, you have a valid complaint, because...

[h1]Officially supported HOTAS[/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/games/502500/announcements/detail/1729848148045999311

As of right now (will update review if this changes,) those are the [i]only[/i] supported HOTAS interfaces. Nothing else will (officially) work with the game. However...

[h1]Unofficial workarounds[/h1]

1) [b]NOTE:[/b] Some report compatibility issues with Fanatec racing wheels using this method. Be aware.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1644325268

or

2) x360ce: https://steamcommunity.com/app/502500/discussions/0/1777135944137796153/

[h1]For those new to Ace Combat.[/h1]

Some things worth knowing:.

[list]
[*]This is not a hardcore flight sim. This is to DCS as CoD is to ARMA. Or at least as Forza is to Project Cars. It's tilted heavily toward the arcade end of the gameplay spectrum. Nevertheless, it provides a fun, challenging experience.
[*]Ace Combat games take place in what has become known as the "strangereal" universe. A world not entirely unfamiliar to us, but fictitious nonetheless. The stories in these games tend to be melodramatic, over the top, and at times downright cringey. But if you can get into them, they are a highlight for many fans of the series. The story unfolds via cut scenes between missions, and radio chatter while flying. This radio chatter also gives you important information about your objectives, so pay attention, as they can change mid-mission.
[*]The game features a fairly straightforward radar, with three view ranges (local, wide, and widest) that you can switch between with a button press. This is useful for finding targets. You can switch between selected targets with the tap of a button as well.
[*]You have four basic weapon types per aircraft. Your normal missiles, your gun, your special weapon, and your chaff. Your missiles will lock onto the highlighted enemies and track them when fired (you can still miss however, as enemies can evade just as well as you can.) Your gun sight will appear when in gun range, allowing you to fire bullets at enemies as well. Your special weapons can be swapped between air to air, air to ground, and various types before each mission, so selecting  the right weapon for each mission is important. Chaff allows you to more easily evade enemy missiles. You also have limited ammo, so some missions allow you to return to base to reload.
[*]You can choose between Novice and Expert control options. [b]I strongly recommend playing with Expert controls[/b], as this gives you all three axes to control. However, if you are someone who tries to play this way and experiences motion sickness or other impediments, don't be afraid to try Novice. Elitism carries no weight with me and it shouldn't with you either. It's a video game. Play the way you find most enjoyable. There's nothing stopping you from trying Expert again later. It's important to me that newcomers to this series not feel put off or excluded if they happen to struggle. The option is there for a reason.
[*]Missions are timed, but don't let that intimidate you. With practice, you will have ample time to achieve victory. But it does demand practice sometimes.
[*]There is a Free Mission mode which allows you to endlessly replay any mission you've already reached or completed previously, which is a great way to earn more credits to unlock additional planes, weapons, and parts. This has always been one of my favorite aspects of AC.
[*]General tips (Credit to M88): https://steamcommunity.com/app/502500/discussions/0/1776010325118879029/
[/list]

All in all, this is a fantastic way to jump into the series if you're new to it, and a return to form for fans. Its biggest flaws are being an almost 1:1 console port with few PC-centric customization options, & limited HOTAS support.

The campaign is pretty slow paced. Lots of waiting, waiting for mission updates while theres nothing to do, waiting out timer even though your objective is completed, waiting for the sandstorm to clear, waiting for your escort to slowly reach its destination, slowly approaching enemies to ID them, slowly platforming in the valley, radar, and the elevator, lots of circling back to strafe targets from a better angle, waiting for weapons to reload.

If the air to ground missions were skippable it wouldn't have soured my opinion of this game. Air to ship combat is great though, lots of targets and anti air that isn't a cliffwall or invisible instant loss radar. The dogfighting missions are fun. Theres always something to duel and you are always under missile lock. The downside though of the dogfighting is that its very quick to complete so they add in the features that I complained about above.
