[h3]Section 1: Technical[/h3]
In short, the game plays fine on keyboard+mouse but I would recommend a controller, it has historically been a PlayStation series.
Make sure you enable "expert controls" in the options as that is how the rest of the series plays, the default control scheme is very limited by comparison and far less fun.
Some people have problems with playing on a flight stick so don't expect great support there.
The PC version does NOT have a VR mode, that was exclusive to the PS4 version sadly.

[h3]Part 2: On the AC Series[/h3]
To begin with I would like to dispel an idea that many may have about the series that would likely repel them early on: Ace Combat is not a flight sim. Putting AC into the flight simulator category is similar to lumping the Burnout, SSX, and Call of Duty series into the driving, snowboarding, and racial abuse simulator categories respectively.
Ace Combat carries the themes of aviation one might be familiar with from movies like Top Gun with real aircraft and an attempt at air force lingo sprinkled throughout the mission dialogue, but it takes place in its own universe with its own nations and a fair share of oddly sci-fi elements often explained in a vaguely Kojima-esque way.

[h3]Part 3: Flow Gameplay[/h3]
Expanding on my statement in the intro section, I have found after having played through every mainline AC game that it can in many cases more comfortably be compared to a series like Jet Set Radio or Tony Hawk's Pro Skater on the gameplay side of things.
Admittedly an odd image to conjure, Ace Combat missions will provide you with an area and some specific objective to accomplish, but will often allow you to fly around and complete these objectives with a degree of freedom, I find myself more closely making the alt sports game comparisons when it comes to how the player can achieve these goals.
While it is possible in many cases to take the safer and more realistic approach of taking out one target per pass over an objective area before retreating to high altitude to avoid any risk, in the same way one might take the easy route in Tony Hawk of grinding one rail in between manuals over and over again to rack up your score, the fun starts when the player begins taking risks. With some practice a player can be moving at high speed very close to terrain, making rapid use of their plane's unrealistically high stock of bombs, missiles, and bullets to knock out many targets in a short period of time while dodging missiles and gun emplacements with ease. These situations I can compare easily to the feeling of being in-the-zone in a skateboarding game, where you make full use of your environment and skilled movement to string together as many tricks as possible.

[h3]Part 04: Gameplay Balance[/h3]
Many planes can be unlocked in AC7 for the player to fly, a currency earned through completing missions allows for an unlock tree to be explored that leads to not only new planes, but multiple weapons for each as well as parts that can fill a slot on any aircraft to affect their abilities.
Given the branching paths present in the progression tree and the existence of useful parts scattered throughout, you will eventually end up funnelling money into another fork and acquiring half a dozen planes that would never be viable to fly in order to get one part to minmax the configuration of your current "best" plane.
While player freedom is a nice convenience, the result of the parts system is that your plane choice midgame will be mostly determined by the weapons they come with and ammo capacity, while at the endgame your choices will be around if the plane has cobra or kulbit manoeuvre capability (advanced movement techniques).
In previous games your plane unlocks were linear but you could choose not to buy the newest one and keep saving or get a new weapon for an owned plane if you wanted, in some cases there were planes you could only unlock by putting more time into a certain plane before it even if this meant using it for a short while after the plane was viable. In the original Air Combat you would even lose a plane if you crashed it in a mission and that would set you back somewhat in your playthrough. 
In AC7 the only reason to not use the most expensive plane you currently have with a combination of your best parts would be to intentionally nerf yourself, though there are some weapons like long range AA missiles that would force your hand and have you use a worse plane (unless you bought the Top Gun DLC for the special F14)

[h3]Part 5: Story[/h3]
The story for Ace Combat games is never exactly Shakespeare, but I would have to say that AC7 is maybe the worst in the series that I have played.
Most would agree that the "holy trinity" of AC games released in the PS2 era are the peak of the series, with 4, 5, and Zero's cutscenes utilising still manga-ish images with voiceover, shoddy 3d anime models, and full-motion video with real actors respectively.
AC7 decides to take the worst of these three and go with the shoddy 3d models again. Sure this one is down to a matter of taste, but another more egregious thing taken from AC5 is the amount of in-mission dialogue in the game.
My personal favourite of the series, AC4 would unload most of its plot and context through the slides in between missions, and then a bit more in briefings, but would include one or two lines mid-mission to give characters a bit of personality. These lines would always relate to the mission at hand, but almost always your teammates would be focused on the mission. The small bits of levity you hear when you save another plane or a ground unit from being destroyed were like a reward for your performance. 
By comparison, every character in AC7 talks CONSTANTLY, there is hardly a moment of dead air on the radio in some missions, and a lot of it is fun chatter from characters who are according to the plot supposed to be less professional, but even the most elite groups in the Osean forces will just keep chatting about nothing throughout the game and it came to be a pain in the ass for me.
The higher level of chatter worked in AC5 because it was almost exclusively between the three other pilots in your tightly-knit squadron who were characters that you follow through the whole game, but in AC7 everyone joins in like we're in a public Discord call.
In AC4 the still image cutscenes in between SOME missions would tell the story of a civilian during the war who has seemingly no bearing on the player character's mission, this served to add context to the war and provide a small amount of background to a squadron you encounter in the story.
AC7's cutscenes try to mix these elements from AC4 and 5 but manage to nail neither of them, introducing too many characters that don't matter, giving tons of info that the player does not care about, while providing too much info on a villain that is supposed to be mysterious.

[h3]Part 0: Music[/h3]
AC7's music covers a few genres and does well to match the tone of each mission, really pushes you forward and greatly elevates a gameplay system that already feels awesome. I wouldn't say that the music is the best in the series by a longshot but that would be like saying that Dark Souls 2 is the worst Dark Souls game, that still leaves it pretty up there.
I also kinda hate the main motif in the soundtrack and especially the vocal version but that's just me, there're plenty of awesome songs like Stonehenge Defensive and Last Hope I & II that are super memorable along with their missions.

[h3]Part 7: Conclusion[/h3]
This is not the best game in the series, however it is a fantastic starting point, an accumulation of every improvement to controls made in the series.
The game also goes on sale pretty frequently, for like 80% off you have NO excuse.

I had a bunch more to say about VR, multiplayer, and how this game is the Dark Souls 3 of the series and copies AC4 heavily for mission structure but this review has a character limit.

Game is fucking great. [strike] I enjoy the story and graphics. The game play and how it feels to take someone down is just awesome. I really enjoy the cinematic view after every mission. I have one problem though. What the actual fuck is with the bombing missions? That is the one thing I have the most difficulty with in this game that it is actually distracting. The spacing of the bombing targets and the time you have and the ammo you have is so small and far away its so damn hard to finish it. It took me hours to get the first one down, although the second one is the best cause all the targets are all in one simple place and it felt good and fun to take it down, but once I got to mission 11 I just stopped playing for a while. That one is giving me the most trouble because you have fifteen minutes to bomb but you gotta take the time to get to each area and maybe refuel once or twice due to the small amount of ammo. So I get five minutes of having to fucking just fly around and only ten minutes to do boring ass strafing runs. Look, I will continue to play the game looking forward to the other missions, but the bomber missions are what make me put down the game and walk away and not play it for a while. [/strike]

Edit: Four years later and now that I have gotten into other flight sims, my review above is just me having a skill issue

Meh. Was alright until the final mission. Did they playtest the game?

🛦 It's a great arcade game to come back to after a hard day of work. Arcade is the keyword here. Don't expect this game to work like a simulation because it is not.

🛦 If this is your first ACE COMBAT game or if you are not accustomed to flight simulators, then expect some 'turbulence' during learning phase. However, you should get used to it pretty quickly. I highly recommend using a controller.

🛦 After finishing the main story, I wasn't satisfied. I wanted to get back up in the sky and become better at dog-fighting. Luckily there's ACE difficulty which unlocks after finishing the main story in hard difficulty. There's also lots of medals to chase and a whole lot of aircraft, skins, and emblems to unlock.
If you are not into that, then there is online multiplayer, which, to my surprise, is still somewhat alive. However, it's mostly played by veterans who are highly skilled obviously. Nevertheless, multiplayer is great fun. You can invite and play with your friends too in a private lobby, if I am not mistaken. All in all, ACE COMBAT 7 has great replayablity.

Oh, and one last thing...
[spoiler]You might hear missile alerts even when you are not playing the game.[/spoiler]

Ace Combat is one of my favorite series' of all time. The Golden Trilogy of Ace Combat games on PS2 were massively influential in my formative gaming years. Ace Combat 7 is a fantastic return to the Strangereal universe that perfectly unites the tried and proven series formula with a modern story. I can't Recommend this game enough.

This game is the king of the dying Arcade Flight simulator genere. 10/10 story, 10/10 gameplay, 10/10 graphics even on medium settings. The epitome of the Ace Combat series. The DLC is also worth getting, they're still adding new DLC which makes the game more epic.

Become an ace pilot and soar through photorealistic skies with full 360 degree movement; down enemy aircraft and experience the thrill of engaging in realistic sorties! Aerial combat has never looked or felt better!
Project Aces aims to revolutionize the sky with this entry in the series, offering an experience so immersive it feels like you're piloting an actual aircraft! Weather and the environment affect your aircraft and the HUD, adding a sense of extreme realism never felt before in a flight combat game. Epic dogfights await!

The ACE COMBAT series is a flight shooting game in which players can enjoy the pleasure of becoming ace pilots and pursuing realistic skies, the pleasure of flying 360 degrees freely by driving their favorite aircraft, the pleasure of selecting and defeating the enemy with their own judgment of the situation, and the sense of achievement of breaking the difficulty at hand.
The development of this latest work in the series was followed by "PROJECT ACES", which has been in charge of making previous series. Under the theme of "Innovation in the Sky," you can feel the "feeling of the sky" more than ever by clouds embroidered in three dimensions in the sky, gas that shakes according to changes in the environment such as air currents and thunderstorms. With the new world of dogfights created by the environment, you can enjoy the most attractive aerial warfare and speed of the series so far.

Not many multiplayer servers and players, many aircrafts, easy to be hacked (not recommended ._.), 20 missions (3 mode: easy, normal, expert) if no season pass or DLC which is quite short, has top gun DLC => should buy when sale (~4$)

Been playing the series since "Ace Combat 3: Electrosphere" for the PS1, so i'll try to explain the appeal of the series as a long-time fan:

Ace Combat might look like a Flight Simulator game, but it is the completely opposite.

This series focuses on a lot of crazy political plots that are mainly secondary to your Flight Missions that gradually go from your typical military operation, All the way to flying through a tunnel within a giant WMD Railgun so that you can hit it's weakspot like Han Solo. lol
It is very stupid at times, while keeping a serious tone throughout it's plots and twists.


But i'm certain that the main question will be something along the lines of: "what's the appeal of Ace Combat to it's fans?", and the answer is quite simple: it's the same kind of appeal that Modern DOOM games have: 

The Adrenaline Rush of being a unstoppable force of nature that could be put down at any moment with a few well-placed hits while being constantly placed in the middle of unwinnable odds.

Ace Combat is the "Boomer Shooter" of Flight Simulator Games, while keeping itself grounded in it's Military Realism roots.
plane go shoot

Ace Combat 7 is a mostly arcade-like flight combat game with a surprisingly engaging story. 
Personally, I'm not much of a flight sim person, though I've played a few space sims (like the X series) and that utterly forgettable Star Wars combat game (Squadrons, was it?). Nevertheless, the different available control schemes allowed me to succeed without a steep learning curve.
Jet fighter enthusiast will be happy to see that many modern fighter planes are represented in the game. Allegedly these planes come with different specialisations, and there's an "Aircraft Tree" to unlock new ones. Knowing nothing about planes, I figured that higher numbers are better and just went with the planes that seemed the best allrounders...
Most of the combat, at least for me, is done with homing missiles. You have an unlimited amount of those, plus a limited amount of "special weapons", which are typically more elaborate missiles or bombs for ground combat. 
Playing the game at highest visual settings still made it look rather mediocre. I think that's a known bug, though. And to be honest, I was typically flying through the scenery at such high speeds that I couldn't see any details anyway. 
The combat is fun. I played on the lowest difficulty setting (specifically recommended to newcomers of the series) and found the experience challenging enough to be fun without frustrating me. I particularly enjoyed the missions where I got to fight ground targets, but perhaps that's just me. 
The story is surprisingly good. I played through the game in a single weekend because I genuinely wanted to know what was going to happen next. One of the support characters is a a bit of a stereotypical anime waifu, but, well, that's not necessarily a bad thing. 
All in all I enjoyed Ace Combat 7 a lot, much more than I expected. I'd love to see more of this!
The Campaign playthrough took me a bout 10h. I don't think the replayability is very high. There's a Multiplayer, though, which I didn't try out. 
I'd recommend buying the game during a sale; the full price seems a bit ridiculous to me. There are DLCs but I don't plan to buy them.

I woudn't call this a full review, because I just started playing, but I do want to say that I'm pleasantly surprised by this game. While not the hardcore flight simulator I'm more used to, it's not a pure arcade game either - planes actually have a flight model and a sense of physicality and physics (albeit simplified). I do miss the ability to land my plane (when the mission ends, the screen fades to black while in flight), but I can forgive this title for not including that - it's a air combat game, not a flight simulator. 

More importantly, I'm having fun! The graphics are amazing IMO (both visuals and framerate), the story is fun, in a silly sort of way, and the missions have been engaging and just the right level of challenging so far. I've not encountered any bugs yet, though I'm still pretty early in the game. 

As of right now, I can recommend it! One disclaimer - I bought this on sale for $19, so I'm definitely getting my money's worth. I'm not sure what the regular price is, so YMMV depending on when you purchase this title.

[MAIN]
This franchise was my Childhood. The first one I played was Unsung War, then I went from there and playing all the others. When I saw Ace Combat 7 I knew I had to get it. One of the best decisions in my life. Playing this game made me feel like a kid again. Having those air battles, dodging missiles, together with the characters and interactions, this game is everything I could ask for. I highly recommend this game.

[Single Player]
The story is amazing. The scenery, the characters, the planes, everything here is top quality. It really helps you get immersed in the game. The story is a typical AC story, with a lot of memorable and breathtaking moments. The gameplay is tight, the new maneuver are really nice (Even tho I didn't use it all that much). The jets are incredibles, the ones in game and the ones in the dlcs a well. Overall a very solid game for a Ace Combat Fan AND those who want to get in to the game. {9/10}

[Multiplayer]
Well, Here the things are not all that good. I like the multiplayer, it's not bad. It's just not my type. I'm way out of the skill level of anyone there, but it's nice to see what others can do and how good they can fly (Except the hackers, there are a few of them and they destroy the experience). I just wish we had a co-op  campaing, or a couch co-op mode like the old games. {4/10}

This game is a huge nostalgia trip for me. I remember rushing out to the video game store to buy Ace Combat 2 and 3 on PS1 and PS2 and getting the flight stick out to play the titles.
This version on PC does not disappoint. 
It really is a pure Ace Combat experience with really tight graphics and great sound effects. 
The story mode unfolds really well the first playthough, and subsequent playthroughs allow you to skip it and get right into the action.

The licensed aircraft from top military aircraft manufacturers is what makes this game a bit on the expensive side I would imagine. But securing these licenses and being able to fly the planes in the game just adds an extra layer of polish to the game.

I'm ready for the next instalment Namco, so you are cleared for takeoff with Ace Combat 8: OMG Moar Flying Yes Please.

This game is amazing. I'm kind of sad that I slept on this franchise for so long. 

The "story" is total dog crap and the characters you fly with can be very annoying sometimes. From "Let's make a bet" to "Going to tell my son this story". Even trying to "follow" the story makes little to no sense. 

The game play however is amazing. The in game currency to buy planes and upgrades are a bit annoying. However, the planes and how they fly feel amazing. Locking on and dog fighting never gets old. I found myself replaying missions just to push myself for a better score which I normally never do. 

You and also customize your ship with different parts. More armor, fighter flying, or more missiles. 

If you like the idea of flying a jet with over +100 missiles and a special missiles 30-100ish or curious about these type of games. Then this is the perfect one to start. I thought this game was going to be "oh, this is neat. Ok, I'm done." and move on. I played it every chance I got. It's great.

There is a multiplayer, however I don't care about that so if that matters to you. Look for other reviews on that. I'd suggest Thrust-Adjusting Steering Device (MSL) and Multiple Enemy Detection Device (MSL) for ARM.. Basically anything for Reload, Load Limit, and Homing feels the best. On top of Automated Fire Extinguisher and Queen's Custom for body.. 

So the DLC is a bit weird. They have a Season Pass, but it does not include all DLC. There's 3 25th Anniversary packs with 3-4 planes and a Top Gun colab and I think that's it. I got the bundle with the base game, Season Pass, and Top Gun. From what I can tell the DLC aren't super amazing. A lot of the base planes outclass them when you go better into what you can own. Rafale M really feels like it is way better than the DLC imo. I do wish they had included it with the season pass or make a "Definite Edition" instead of this confusing crap. That's my "biggest" personal grip besides the story.

Hopefully more of these games come to Steam or I find other IP's like this.

If you gonna pick this game, buy it with the Season Pass because Bandai-Namco DLC prices are abusive. I'll do a proper review later.

Edit: It just became extra abusive as they rocketed up the prices to give a bigger discount and land on the same price.

It is one of the weakest (and probably last) game of the franchise. It is a passion project and has some memorable moments but mostly in boss fights. OST is good, multiplayer is either dead or unbalanced.

Also check out the community mods. Unhinged and cringe weeb shit, but very fun!

This game has pretty solid graphics, a fair story and a pretty great soundtrack. I wish there was more in this game than an aircraft/weapons tree to fill out as well as only 2 types of multiplayer games. Granted, I'm no developer, but implementing co-op would probably be very simple. Also, the handling model is somewhat limited and could use a bit more freedom. There's no easy way to flip inverted unless you're doing a high yo-yo, and you can't stay that way due to auto leveling. Snag the game on a sale and enjoy plane go fast, zoom.

What can I say, really, It 's an Ace Combat game. it is not a flight sim, so don't expect lots of realism or complexity. However, this game delivers big time on fast-paced fun gameplay, well-scripted and cast dialogue, an interesting storyline, and an excellent music score. You can see the Japanese art style influence in the cutscenes which I enjoy too. All of these are staple qualities of Ace Combat games. I still remember binge-playing Ace Combat 4 when  I was younger and it felt like the same game, just with a different story and refined, bigger and better. Why fix what isn't broken? 
 Multiplayer is very competitive, especially if you opt for a controller like me. However, even if you suck, it's still worth it for the boatloads of credits you get playing online matches.

I wouldn't say this is the best Ace Combat game there is, 5 and 0 still hold that title. But it is a damn fun one regardless and shows that the series is heading in a great direction.

It is not enough for this to be my only Ace Combat game. My first of the franchise and my first aircraft simulator with an amazing narrative. I've completed the game multiple times now and I am never not satisfied. I know it is not acurate to true aircraft but that doesn't matter. Do I enjoy flying my perfectly modeled F16 in ways that would probably shatter the true airframe? Yes. Do I enjoy battling over the skies of Farbanti and listening to the radio chatter of my squad as I go in to assault an arsenal bird? Also yes. 

In my reviews I always like to include both good and bad things about games but as I stand here now I cannot find a single one in the campaigns that I have had.  The game is honestly a model of graphic advancement with awe inspiring sights, great cloud cover, realistic mountains and forest (for when you are flying lower than you need to be), and enemies and allies who stick with you. There will never be a wingman like the Count and never an enemy quite like Mr. X. 

To top off these amazing graphics we get a story that is just as amazing with narrative twist, a futuristic war, and surprisingly moral dilemmas with political intrigue that remind me of the Metal Gear franchise which are so lacking in modern gaming.

Add on an unlock tree that features over 30 aircraft both old, modern, and futuristic with weapons to match and you get a single player experience that just can't be topped. 

My only hope is that we will see other Ace Combat games released in the future or see the older ones make their way to steam and other launchers. Until then I hope to see you all in the skies. Good luck to my fellow Oseans  and Eruseans and happy hunting!

ACE COMBAT™ 7: SKIES UNKNOWN is a triumphant return to the skies, delivering an adrenaline-pumping experience that surpasses its predecessors and establishes itself as the crown jewel of the Ace Combat series. As a long-time fan of the franchise, I can confidently say that Bandai Namco has outdone themselves with this latest installment.

Graphics and Presentation: ★★★★★

From the moment you take off, SKIES UNKNOWN impresses with its stunning visuals. The aircraft models are incredibly detailed, and the landscapes are breathtaking. The transition from calm skies to intense dogfights is seamless, creating a sense of immersion that few other games can match. The attention to detail in the environments and the aircraft is truly remarkable.

Gameplay: ★★★★★

The gameplay in ACE COMBAT™ 7 is where the game truly shines. The controls are tight and responsive, allowing for precise maneuvers and exhilarating combat. The wide variety of aircraft to choose from, each with its own unique characteristics, ensures that there's something for every type of player. Whether you're an ace pilot or a newbie, the game's accessibility and depth strike the perfect balance.

The mission design is superb, featuring a mix of intense dogfights, bombing runs, and thrilling set pieces. The evolving objectives keep you engaged throughout the campaign, which is further enhanced by the inclusion of an engaging and well-written storyline. The addition of the "Strangereal" universe, which connects to previous games in the series, adds depth to the narrative for longtime fans.

Sound and Music: ★★★★★

The audio in SKIES UNKNOWN is a treat for the ears. The roaring engines, missile launches, and radio chatter create an authentic and immersive experience. The soundtrack, composed by Keiki Kobayashi, is nothing short of a masterpiece, perfectly complementing the game's atmosphere and providing an emotional backdrop to the intense aerial combat.

Multiplayer: ★★★★

The multiplayer component of ACE COMBAT™ 7 is solid, offering various modes to engage with friends and players worldwide. Dogfights and team battles are thrilling and showcase the game's strengths. However, the lack of more diverse game modes and larger player counts is a minor disappointment.

Replay Value: ★★★★

With multiple aircraft to unlock, numerous difficulty levels, and the desire to perfect your flying skills, ACE COMBAT™ 7 offers excellent replay value. The VR missions (PlayStation VR exclusive) are a fantastic addition that breathes new life into the game and are a must-try for VR enthusiasts.

In conclusion, ACE COMBAT™ 7: SKIES UNKNOWN is a triumph in the world of flight simulation and combat games. Its captivating story, breathtaking visuals, and exhilarating gameplay make it a must-play for aviation enthusiasts and gamers alike. It's a game that soars above the competition and leaves players with an unforgettable experience in the skies.
If you want an arcade shoot-em-up, then this is the ticket. Leave realism for another day.

TLDR- This game is summed up in one word.

Daredevil.


Let's be honest.  If compared to other dominating combat games, this is like comparing a Lamborghini to your buddies rice burner.  But you know what, you still ride with your buddy cause it's awesome. 

You play this game for the story (WAIT, slow those keyboards!) I'm not talking about the Surreal world that the game is based on, but what it feels like when you're flying at top speed against 100's of drones vs an impenetrable force field and the shield drops and the (@#*&@#^$ MUSIC swells, and you forget you're in your 15 year old computer chair being held together by duct tape, but in the combat seat of a next-gen fighter with questionable armaments. (Yeah mai dude, I know that's not how missiles work.)

I'm late to the series, and after doing some research was amazed to find what I found endearing about it was "what" they wanted to achieve, so hats off to ACE 7 for doing what it set out to do and not flutter it with well, all my fellow gamers know what environment we deal with now.

Overall -

Arcade style combat with decent replay value.  Oddly, like in most aerial games, easy is harder than normal?  Minor bugs, occasional crashes, but not game breaking.  AI are useless, unfortunately, but not so annoying you cringe.  Story is, well it's there, but previous points in above section.  Lots of unlocks via just playing the game, and some DLCs that should have? but not included, preference there.  Enough variety that you don't have to always use the superest (that a word?) plane to do anything.

8/10

My advice is to wait for discount if you want to purchase the entire game with the DLCs, when you get the chance , do it, and play as an ace pilot taking the lead into chaotic skies.

From the first moment you take to the skies in Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown, it becomes evident that this isn't just any aerial combat game. This is a thrilling symphony of speed, strategy, and story, all masterfully orchestrated to deliver an experience that truly stands out in the flight combat genre.

Graphics & Visuals: The game is a visual masterpiece. The aircraft models are meticulously detailed, with every rivet, panel, and insignia rendered with impressive precision. But it's not just the planes that shine. The game's environments, from the expansive blue skies to the varied terrains below, are breathtaking. Dynamic weather conditions and realistic cloud physics don't just serve as eye candy; they play an integral role in your combat strategies, making every mission feel fresh and unpredictable.

Gameplay: Ace Combat 7 nails the fine balance between arcade fun and simulation complexity. Whether you're a novice or a seasoned pilot, the game offers controls and difficulty levels to cater to your skill set. The addition of new weapons and tech encourages strategic thinking, and the dogfights? They are nothing short of exhilarating. Outmaneuvering enemies, dodging missiles, and lining up that perfect shot feels rewarding every single time.

Story: The Ace Combat series has always been known for its engaging narratives, and Skies Unknown does not disappoint. The story is a riveting tale of war, betrayal, and redemption, woven together with cutscenes that rival many cinematic blockbusters. The voice acting is top-notch, and the soundtrack, with its grand orchestral scores, complements the game's tone beautifully.

Multiplayer: The online multiplayer mode is a fantastic addition for those who wish to test their skills against other pilots worldwide. With various modes and challenges, there's always a reason to jump back in for "just one more match."

Final Thoughts: Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is a testament to the passion and expertise of its developers. It's a polished, captivating experience that will resonate with fans of the series and newcomers alike. If soaring through the skies, engaging in intense dogfights, and being immersed in a rich narrative sounds like your kind of game, then Skies Unknown is an absolute must-play.

The game kind of just reinvents the wheel with the same tropes previous installations have already done.

Also, replayability is barely there; it's only present in a handful of missions.

The graphics and gameplay are pretty solid, though; gazing back at its graphics since its release, you can see some areas where it doesn't totally age very well, but otherwise are just easy to overlook since all you're really doing is flying an airplane and shooting things down and blowing things up.

The whole "RAMIREZ, DO EVERYTHING!" in the single player missions gets very boring and very irritating rather fast when you have a squad full of allied AI that could have made it easier for you to do; they only act as depressing filler.

Ace Combat 5 actually did a decent job at making it so you can directly command your wingmates to assist you directly instead of just meandering off on other random tasks while you are expected to carry 90% of the team; this concept dropped since Ace Combat 6. However, this wasn't entirely reliable, which is a shame that it was left that way since then instead of improved upon with Ace Combat 6.

In comparison, Ace Combat 7 really [i]is[/i] a shell of its former self.

Multiplayer experience gets very mid as all you're dealing with are either Team Deathmatch and Battle Royale; I don't exactly know what went thru the development process, but it seems things such as multiplayer co-op, which this game on multiplayer is clearly online-only, wasn't either considered or was put off from the game entirely. The TDM/BR experience is plagued by people who are either already adept or very skilled at flight manoeuvres, or have probably a DLC aircraft or other aircraft with higher agility and better firepower and equipment; late-game issue, I know. This is pretty much where the concept of "fun" is instantly sapped out and becomes actually very boring; it doesn't help that hosts generally don't think beyond the norm and choose to make a specific budget out of the planes. It might be better if, like any other multiplayer online game, you're playing this with friends, but good luck finding anyone who actually plays games like this.

The campaign isn't bad, per se, but as I mentioned before, it reinvents the wheel with roughly the same tropes in the Ace Combat series: big bird, big sub, big gun, big cruise missile; get this, get that; main character syndrome. It's... nothing new. Project Aces really needs to start writing up a better storyline than this if they want their next title to actually be more enjoyable, otherwise I don't see any reason why the Ace Combat series should be getting new releases.

Also, I will mention that almost every other character that I've ever come across this game is potentially forgettable and/or wasted potential. It's weird because Nagase is actually the only character I even [i]remember[/i] as she was basically a titular character in Ace Combat 5, Chopper being (I hate to throw him under the bus) an honourable mention. Actually, even then, the dialogue and each character interaction was actually more memorable and meaningful than anything after AC5; your decisions, or lack thereof, had [i]some[/i] level of impact in the overall gameplay and how other characters responded to you. AC7 was incredibly hollow on that front.

A pointer, however, is that while the aircraft tree is interesting, trying to get almost every plane will be a grind/chore, and most planes I do think are [i]not[/i] worth the effort; most either have highly similar traits, are not that great, or have very similar special weapons. Also, the laser gameplay is, as I expected, rather suboptimal: it [i]is[/i] powerful, but having them available on multiplayer other than the pulse laser is pointless, since it's heavily PvP. Even in campaign mode, the laser beam weapon (as I can only bother to call it) is painstakingly difficult to use when almost every threat is a missile that's waiting to eat your arse every five seconds, and you are already in a fast-paced environment where every second and shot [i]literally[/i] counts.

Overall, I guess if you want Ace Combat because silly basic plane game where you shoot shoot and go boom boom, I wouldn't complain. But if you're looking for something that may be better than AC6 or AC5, this isn't it chief.

Do you want a little more action that Microsoft Flight Simulator?  Maybe this game is for you!

Ace Combat 7 is a jet-fighting game where you play with modern and/or near-futurish technology.  You play through 20 missions with set-timers and scores or objectives that you need to achieve before you see your next mission through.  As you progress, you unlock real life planes (F14 Tomcat, F16, A10 warthog, etc.) and components you can use to modify your plane, including weapons.  The controls in this game can be set as realistic (roll and pitch on a joystick, yaw on controller bumpers) or simplified (you go where your joysticks points to), but either way I would play with at least a console controller rather than your mouse and keyboard!  

Overall I give the game an 8/10.  I don't feel that AC7 put anything new on the table as far as an Ace Combat game goes, but it had fun and unique missions with graphics that were pleasing to the eye.  I like its premise of being in a war with a neighboring nation but after appearing to shoot down a VIP,  you have been put in a 'penal unit' of fighters to serve your country.  To compare it to AC6 which feels more like an all out war, this game is focused more on special operations.  The story told through the cinematics are alright, I cared a lot more about the chatter in game than out.  I didn't play more than a round in multiplayer, but as of the time of writing I will say it is well populated.  Anywho, it is a well crafted game and you won't be disappointed even if you're just looking to collect some planes!

In this game, you're playing as a OSEAN pilot that using aircraft to destroy many enemies that equipped with a missile...MISSILE?!?!?
The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.
The return to form Ace Combat needed. Wish I got to it sooner. Some HD remakes for zero, 5 and 4 would be gud.

short review: game is mediocre at best. If there was an option for "yellow review" it would be it - nor positive or negative, would I recommend it? - no, not because it's bad, it's just meh.
Do I regret buying it? - no. Maybe because I got it on sale.

detailed review:

- physics and handling are too arcadish even for an arcade. Yes, there are differences between airplanes but in 99% cases all feel the same. This is NOT gamepad or joystick issue.
-  story plot is actually good but it's presentation is just mediocre, boring and sometimes annoying. It will be more entertaining to read about it on wiki than playing through it.
- voice chatter is distracting, annoying and far-fetched. A lot of useless talking, joking and even when some drama happens you just don't care, because of how everything is put together.
- sound is good but put poorly: voice chatter and music always get in a way of explosions and action, and overall, both are feeling like TV noise. Music itself is orchestral but makes 0 impact, it's either too graceful or doesn't fit to what's going on the screen in 99% cases, it's like listening to Beethoven whilst watching 2 men arguing at butcher shop. I've put it to 0 on 11th mission because it was enough for me. I would do that to voice chatters aswell but then I'll miss those remaining 5-10% of plot, since I've lost 90% of that because of poor presentation overall.
- another point to not good sound design: there is no feel to airplane's engines, you can barely hear them, no "juice", no drive whatsoever, and thus, speed is translated poorly.
- no option to change controls during missions - you always need to quit the mission and change everything in main menu.
- looks like FOV is fixed to 60 and you have no option to change it, thus, making "no feeling of speed while flying 2500 KM/H" situation even worse.
- replays are also made strangely: no view from target perspective, "fly by" option is too short and always interrupted by "fixed outside cockpit" (or similar) mode and beside that there is only 1 option for that whilst it could be much more like in older games. + again, FOV set to 60 makes it even worse when watching them. So the only thing/place where I could enjoy watching my dogfights is also made poorly.
- gameplay is ok. Yes, repetitive, yes always concludes in making circles around your target until 1 of you is victorious. Instant break feature only makes it worse so I never use it. But despite all of that it plays OKAY which is surprise for me considering all that being said. That's probably because of big variety of weapon arsenal which add some "juice" to pretty standard gameplay for such game.

Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown, released in 2019, is a thrilling addition to the long-standing Ace Combat series, known for its intense dogfights, engaging storyline, and stunning visuals. Developed by Bandai Namco Entertainment, this installment successfully blends the classic elements that fans love with modern graphics and gameplay innovations.

Graphics and Sound:
One of the standout features of Ace Combat 7 is its breathtaking visuals. The aircraft are meticulously detailed, and the landscapes, from cityscapes to open skies, are rendered with stunning realism. The attention to detail extends to the weather effects, with raindrops streaking across the cockpit during a storm, adding a layer of immersion.

The sound design is equally impressive. The roar of jet engines, the whistling of missiles, and the radio chatter all contribute to the game's atmosphere. The musical score enhances the drama of the aerial battles and complements the narrative beautifully.

Gameplay:
Ace Combat 7 excels in delivering a visceral and enjoyable flight experience. The controls are responsive and intuitive, making it accessible to both veterans and newcomers. The variety of aircraft available, each with its unique characteristics and loadouts, adds depth to the gameplay.

The campaign mode features a compelling story set in the fictional world of Strangereal. The narrative unfolds through a combination of in-game cutscenes and radio communications, giving players a sense of the broader conflict. The mission variety is commendable, ranging from intense dogfights to strategic bombing runs. The difficulty curve is well-balanced, offering a suitable challenge for players of all skill levels.

Ace Combat 7 offers a robust multiplayer mode that lets players engage in thrilling dogfights against opponents from around the world. The competitive multiplayer adds longevity to the game, allowing players to test their skills against human adversaries. The cooperative multiplayer missions are a welcome addition, promoting teamwork and strategic coordination.

A standout feature for PlayStation VR owners is the inclusion of virtual reality missions. This takes the Ace Combat experience to a whole new level, immersing players in the cockpit and providing a genuine sense of scale and speed. The VR missions are a testament to the potential of virtual reality in enhancing gaming experiences.

Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown successfully revitalizes the franchise, delivering a visually stunning and engaging aerial combat experience. The combination of a gripping single-player campaign, robust multiplayer modes, and the immersive VR experience cements its status as a must-play for fans of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned pilot or a newcomer to the series, Ace Combat 7 offers a thrilling ride through the clouds and beyond.

I pirated:
Ace Combat 04: Shattered Skies
Ace Combat 5: The Unsung War
Ace Combat Zero: The Belkan War

So I decided to buy this one. It's a very good game.

I was expecting arcadey fun, but instead I got a shitty half-baked flight combat game.

* The third person view lacks information that you need to know how steep your ascent or descent is when you have 0 visibility, so it will lead to a lot of accidental crashing. The cockpit view blocks half your screen. This leaves first person view as the only usable camera.

* Allied planes do nothing and are useless unless the plot decides that they are not, which doesn't happen often.

* The planes designed for ground attack feel like garbage (they made the A-10 bad at attacking ground targets lol). Expect to never need to use anything other than multirole fighters.

* The game later takes IFF away from you and it does so in the shittiest way: Everything will shoot at you until you mark it as an ally. This is compounded by having useless teammates who will not mark anything for you unless the plot demands it and by needing to look at whatever you want to mark by having it dead center in your screen (this results in you needing to dive at ground targets which is likely to cause you to eat missiles/gunfire or crash).

* All escort missions suck either by virtue of being slow or because the IFF issue makes it so you don't know what is going to attack what you're escorting. The game's love of spawning enemies out of thin air often means enemies spawn next to ground escortees when you're far away trying to ID enemies.

* The checkpoint system is supposed to lower frustration but it saves so infrequently that the usual result is that you will have to do half a mission every time instead of the whole thing at once if you die.

* Zero single player replayability unless you're a perfectionist, which also means you have to plan which endgame plane you want since you won't get enough to unlock them all without grinding.

Tl;dr

Overall enjoyable to play but very short and lacks replay value. It gets the job done but ultimately feels uninspired. Only buy on sale if you are a fan of the series or interested in jets.
 
Here is my rationale:

Too short: There are only 20 missions, most of them can be finished in less than 30 minutes. If you skip cut scenes you can beat this game in less than 10 hours. There isn't much replay value. It's super annoying that it's so short and they want to sell you extra missions as DLC.

Too easy: There are four difficulties: Easy casual, Easy, Normal, Hard. I assumed since there were two easy modes, normal might be pretty tough. Wrong. I played on normal with advanced controls and only got shot down a few times, 90% of my deaths were from hitting obstacles. I'm not a veteran player, my only experience is Ace Combat 4 and that was probably 10 years ago.

Gameplay lacks depth: Ace Combat feels like a shooting gallery most of the time. Enemies are helplessly obliterated before you as your worthless allies tell you how great you are. Allies do basically nothing and you destroy probably 90% of the targets. Essentially they only distract enemies. There should be a wingman system or something where you need to use teamwork. The gameplay is fun if repetitive which makes the lack of missions more problematic.

Unfortunately there's no "eh" button for rating so I guess I choose "not reco" in the sense of an AC vet.

The game looks great, the pilot comms create good atmosphere in the heat of battle, likable in-game allies, handling is nice, music awesome as always for AC. A great game to play through once or twice

However, I can't stand Scrap Queen as the character narrator. Just an annoying girlboss archetype which could have been likable if given an actual fleshing-out or given a better reason for being edgy than just straight up saying things such as "my dad heroically died for his country to save his comrades in a retreat during a war that started by the other country. I hate him". She's nothing compared to the reporters from 5 and Zero which gave unbiased documentary and investigative atmosphere, and Pixy adding to the intrigue and mystery of the plot. Even the narrator of 4 was MUCH more likable despite the acting being as flat as cardboard, he actually had a direct personal stake and much bigger grievances which grows from wanting revenge on Yellow and into being wow'd by his presence and growing a bond. Scrap Queen's entire existence is just to complain all the time.

No real aces, Mihaly is a joke to be honest. Even his name is a joke because it's like 10 names long, I honestly couldn't tell if Namco was trying to be funny. He's nothing more than a tool for creation of the real enemy, which is just a faceless and no-personality AI cannon fodder that goes rogue so there's never a connection of you, an ace, and an ace's motivations for 90% of the game. He just kinda shows up a couple of times and picks on rookies, I hardly get a sense of him being a scary threat. He even bugs out the first time you fight him just because "oh no satellites gone" rather than him taking this opportunity to continue to push his limits like his character implies that he always does. 
This could have been slightly alleviated by giving named "green target" aces actual backgrounds just like in Ace Combat Zero, every ace had a story and demise. Here they couldn't be half-a**ed to do that despite the conditions needed for aces to appear being extremely specific or tedious nonsense rather than feeling more naturally occurring like in Zero. Hell, there are only 24 aces compared to Zero's 170! You could go an entire playthrough without seeing a single green ace. 

The [i]special[/i] special weapons are a joke. Seemingly just like every other game that is released in the last 10 years, they have to "balance" (read nerfed into uselessness) because of the multiplayer/e-sports mindset of devs/publishers rather than actually making the game fun. For example "Whoa holy crap AC Zero's legendary TLS and MPBM are in the game!!!" only to find out that the TLS barely damages anything, hitbox as skinny as a needle. MPBM does pitiful damage-over-time rather than massive burst damage. Even the laser machine guns are almost pointless, the low rate of fire alone should have already been its handicap, but no... the clouds stop them dead in their tracks as well. You know what this game is completely filled with? A lot of clouds. There's almost no reason to choose the "wonder weapons" over the conventional weaponry, in fact you probably end up with less damage because of lower ammo count and/or the need for extreme precision... in a game about close-range dogfighting and missile evasions

The plot and resolutions are honestly just bad in the sense of it intertwining with gameplay and story telling.
 I would think the loss of world communications would have a much bigger impact than just a couple of missions where you need to ID the targets or the scientist annoyed he can't do his Steam updates on his drones. How is this major worldwide disaster resolved? Just say "it is what it is". 
 Civil wars and terrorism at a global scale on a massive rise? Rename a few targets among other normal targets, and never mention or show what the breakdown of society looks like in the city streets between civilians.
 Belkan scientist that caused all of a world's woes finally cornered? "Ok I'm good guy now" after annoying little girl gives a cringe 2-sentence speech about love or something

All of the shortcomings of the old AC games in the eyes of modern gaming could definitely be chalked up to being on old tech, awkward early gaming localization, or not having the modern AAA funding. This game however does not have that excuse as it had the backing of AC vets, internet presence, piles of Namco money (they have official Top Gun DLC for christ's sake), oodles of disk space. This game is honestly only a step up from Ace of Duty Assault Horizon only because it's set in Strangereal and doesn't have Dogfight Mode. I honestly don't have high hopes for Ace Combat 8 because after 20 years of the PS2 trilogy it's more than likely that most of the staff those games fell under are probably retired

Ace Combat shouldn't be regarded as just a game, it's being part of something bigger. Much like a family or a tight knit community: even if we go each our way we'll still have a sense of kinship and belonging; I can't help but cheer the team on, when they say they're working on the next 3 games already!

I've followed the series since I was just a kid way back in the 90's. My dad was the one who introduced me to the series, while also having finished the second game before me.

The first game I tried was Ace Combat 2 and later Ace Combat 3, these were amazing. Especially Ace Combat 3 Electrosphere.

But I didn't get a chance to try the rest of the games from 4 to X since I couldn't afford a PS2, PSP or PS3 at that time in life, but later I did get an Xbox 360 to play Ace Combat 6(wow!), the feeling of losing everything in the beginning of the game hit me hard, since my parents lost both their house and company back in the late 2000's, I could truly associate with the emotions being felt at that moment in the game. Then the feeling of mastery and heroism later on became intoxicating, Ace Combat 6 was truly underrated.

The game then became my favorite for many many years, comforting through hard times such as moving to a new town, entering new schools and being less popular than most, and frozen out. I could still have the sense of mastery and heroism through Ace Combat 6. It kept me going when the going got tough. (Nowadays I'm working in Design and Commissioning in a big firm)

But picture the look on my face when I played Assault Horizon... yikes. I was very disappointed with the direction the game was headed(rail-shooter in the skies), then I later tried Ace Combat Infinity at my friend's house on their ps3, I was so happy so see the original format for gameplay and mechanics very much back in action. It gave me hope that I may get to see the true form of Ace Combat once again.

Lo and behold I had my faith fully restored with Ace Combat 7, they returned to their roots while establishing a new platinum standard.

You cannot go wrong with Ace Combat, most of the time.

Aside from no widescreen support or PCVR integration, [b] this game will not disappoint! [/b]

I have never been a fan of combat flight simulation video games, and Ace Combat: Assault Horizon was the only other title I had played before Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown. Despite my disappointment with the previous installment, the overwhelming praise from the franchise's fans convinced me to give this one a try, even purchasing it at its launch.

Let's start with the story. Although it is a significant improvement over Assault Horizon, it fell short of my expectations. The narrative had its moments and introduced interesting characters, but I found it to be oddly told, leaving me somewhat disconnected from the events unfolding. The constant references to states, places, and various elements left me confused most of the time, and I struggled to comprehend the motivations of different parties involved. While my lack of familiarity with the previous games might have contributed to this, I believe the game should accommodate newcomers as well, especially since it's only the second title in the series to have a PC release. Furthermore, the lack of a visible protagonist, their silence, and lack of personality made it difficult to fully immerse myself in the story. The one-sided radio communications, where other characters interact with the silent protagonist, didn't sit well with me, as I prefer more engaging interactions in games. To clarify, I don't mean to say that the story is bad, but it could have been executed better. On a positive note, the cinematics were well-done and added to the overall experience.

Moving on to the graphics, they are undeniably stunning. The game boasts beautiful scenery, an amazing sky, and impressive effects. However, I couldn't help but feel a bit let down by the ground terrain textures, which seemed low-resolution in comparison to the other aspects of the game.

Now, onto the gameplay, which I can confidently say was perfect this time. Despite my initial disinterest in this genre, I had an absolute blast playing Ace Combat 7. The sense of accomplishment from successful kills was incredibly rewarding, and I thoroughly enjoyed the controls and flying mechanics, finding them to be smooth and responsive. This held true for both singleplayer and multiplayer modes. While I don't envision spending an extensive amount of time in the multiplayer aspect, I can understand why many players would be drawn to it.

For achievement hunters: the game has 49 achievements. I am planning to do them all sometime in the near future, but from what I've heard it is not an easy task. I will come back with an edit.

In conclusion, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown proved to be an enjoyable experience for me, despite my reservations about the story and certain graphical aspects. The exceptional gameplay ultimately won me over, turning me into a fan of the franchise. If you're willing to overlook the minor shortcomings and are seeking a thrilling flight combat experience, this game is undoubtedly worth playing.

From the very start of AC7s campaign you are asked one simple question. "Does the color of the sky mean anything special to you?" For those whom are not familiar with aviation and have not been consumed by it's allure this can be a very mundane question. In creation of Ace Combat there is one feeling that it portrays better than any, that feeling of what it was like to imagine being a fighter pilot as a little kid in a living room or outside playing pretend with a toy model of an aircraft. Whether that toy was a folded piece of paper, a cheap piece of plastic that looks like it came from an off-branded star fox, or a $500 model of a MiG-29, you had one feeling in mind, to soar the skies and feel that unrivaled feeling of freedom, to feel cool, to feel unrivaled, to feel like an ACE. This game became the major comeback of a franchise that had forgotten how to give you that feeling. Ace Combat 7 became that shine of light in the dark for those looking for not a realistic flight sim but a fun one that is unrivaled in terms of letting the player have fun with its absurd lore, concepts, and physics.

 Please go and watch this video by Timmm called "Ace Combat is a simulator, but not of Reality" Many of the things I have said in this review are reflected by his video. I've always loved Ace Combat but he managed to put into words how I have struggled to explain my love of Ace Combat and he deserves more exposure for his content as a smaller youtuber with quality content.

 When I look to the sky I think back to those days of imagining flying around shooting down aircraft, pulling seemingly impossible, death defying maneuvers, to soar up and up watching the world get smaller in the blink of an eye. Regardless of which color the sky is, it brings me back to that moment of blissful simplicity. That is what the color of the sky means to me. That is what Ace Combat means to me. Now i'll ask you...

Does the color of the sky mean anything special to you?

There is just enough context for newcomers to enjoy the story, and enough in-game tips to fully understand the game.
Takeaways: Beautiful scenery, awesome controls, amazing dogfights. Be prepared for BS, and boy is it welcome. Obviously not a sim in any way, but it nails the freedom of the skies. SF64 ending. 
Newcomers: Expert mode. Learn it fast, Mission 1 or Free Flight until you get the hang of it. Or enjoy a mediocre experience. The fights on Normal, even, are intense; forgoing full pitch, yaw and roll control is asking for a spanking.
Ace Combat 7 is EXACTLY what sequels should be - better in every single way. Loving attention to detail. Maybe not much for story, but it's as serviceable as you'd expect from an universe called Strangereal.

At the very least, this seems to be limited to the few bosses in the game. Most other planes behave largely alright.

Level gimmicks can range from challenging and fun to just plain annoying. But that's the nature of gimmicks, it can be hit or miss depending on the player. YMMV.

I'm of a split mind here. I'd review this as neutral tending towards negative - the game's pretty, it's got fairly decent customisations, but the annoying bits of the game (overuse of gimmicks, physics-breaking enemies) really detract from the enjoyability of the game. I find only a few missions are actually fun - the bossfights range from frustrating to ridiculous.

Any fights involving Sol Squadron in particular are irritating, as these guys can accelerate and decelerate well beyond whatever the player can do. Same goes for either of the end four boss fights on the last mission.

It would also be nice if the damn MISSILE alert could shut up once the missiles aren't possibly going to hit.

First air combat sim game that I've played. The controls takes some time to get used to at the start. But once it "clicked", damn it feels good to control. I recommend to use the other control scheme, not the default one at start, as it gives you better control of the plane. And Maybe try starting on Normal, if you really have a hard time, then switch to easier modes.

I played about 3~5 missions on third person perspective, I've eventually settled on first person (not cockpit view, some planes have very bad view of the sky).

I know it's more "arcadey", but I think this is a good game for people who want to play air combat sims for the first time.

Story is also very good. It gets you very pumped and wanting to know what happens next. I have completed the main campaign at around ~19 hours (left the game running sometimes on breaks).

Still have to play the extra missions and eventually replay the campaign, maybe on Hard mode this time.

Ace Combat 7 has some of the worst missions I've ever seen in a game. Having played through the campaign, there contains a mission where it requires the player to destroy trucks within a sandstorm. Due to the sheer amount of enemies and the unknown position of the trucks, it essentially requires the player to memorize the spawn positions of the enemies to complete the mission within the time limit.

In addition to that, there is a mission where there is a speed gate for your aircraft where if you brought a slower aircraft due to the misleading mission briefing you're given beforehand, you would just not be able to complete the second half of the mission.

The game looks great and plays fairly well but the rushed development of its story and missions are inherent in its design.

I am yet to see more shitty game full of empty poses, with worse story, absolutely garbage nonsense military background (in mission 2 you are to encounter a lot of AA vehicles which "pose no significant threat"), planes flying like on railways, absolutely straight... Stupid controls, whacky joystick support, camera controls designed in completely wrong way... I dont see a thing done right here. Even the simplistic radar screen which is rectangular instead of radial is irritating. Where is the closest enemy? you can probably get used to it, I just wonder why they did reinvent the wheel? Why square? Every single radar screen I have seen so far was a circle and there may be some good reasons behind that design. For example that when the enemy contact is at 45 degrees relative bearing, it does not get into a corner, as circle has no corners. Why did they not go for a triangle? Would it not be even more "fun"?
And as if this was not enough, the whole plot and situation manufactured as a dumbed-down indoctrination scheme for kids to implant the "correct geopolitical view". Two countries with the gibberish names, but the good and frinedly ones fly US planes while the evil ones use Russian planes... Of course the world is black and white. One side does only good and the other is completely evil. Superpowers are definitely not similar to one another like two peas im a pod. Not at all.

Good game, with a lot of flaws. Would only recommend this to Ace Combat fans for now.

The Good:
[list]
[*]The aircraft handle very well
[*]Classic Ace Combat mission progression
[*]Introduction of new gameplay mechanics (clouds, wind currents and storms) that don't change the whole identity of the game
[*]The OST
[*]Aircraft Tree and upgrade system
[*]Story and dialogues are cheesy, with plenty of fanservice, following into the footsteps of previous games
[*]Game runs well
[/list]

The Bad:
[list]
[*]Lacking SP content, besides different difficulties (which are less in number than AC6), there's no extra modes after you finish the campaign
[*]Lacking MP content, there's only two modes (DM and TDM), no co-op
[*]MP is very meta-driven and unbalanced. Furthermore, bombers and multi-role aircraft are essentially rendered obsolete, due to the MP modes being only about dogfights
[*]Graphics are good, but not breathtaking. Especially in the texture department
[*]S-Rank criterias are unclear
[*]Low-tier aircraft will always be low-tier (even with the best parts equipped; #BuffF4-E)

The campaign is good, but I was dissapointed by the game in the MP department.
I was hoping for co-op missions in a similar style to AC Infinity, but instead we only got two basic modes with no reason to ever use any kind of planes besides fighters.

If you ever wanted to know how Top Gun would look like as an anime, play this game and you'll have an idea.
 To be completely honest, I've never thought I'd like this game as much as I did. The only experience I have with "fighter jet" games are Top Gun on NES and River Raid on Atari xD. 
But man, I had a lot of fun with this one. It's completely arcade and SF. The main plot considers if AI will overtake real pilots in the future, there are huge ground railguns, enormus planes carrying hundreds of drones, fighter jet drones etc. There are also many well directed cut scenes and briefings.  
However, the best part of this game, for me, is the soundtrack. It's godlike. Absolutely perfectly fits the game and is one of the best soundtrack in a video game. Also the graphics  are excellent, especially cloud simulation and simulation of weather effects. In addition to that, the game is very well optimized. I could run it with 40–60 FPS on an integrated Vega 8 graphics card in 1600x900 resolution. 
To sum up, I bought it on sale and thought that will play one mission or so per day. It turned out that I've finished it in a few days, playing several missions in succession. I hope they will make more AC games in the future.

This is my first ever Ace Combat game and honestly I had no clue what to expect. I had played Project Wingman (A game similar to Ace Combat) for a while and caught this while it was on sale. For the price I paid, a little over $10, I'd say it was well worth the price. The story is pretty concise and fun, it isn't a masterclass in writing or surprise but it doesn't have to be. The characters are pretty likable, though the goals of everyone by the end of the story seems a little confusing, but even still playing the game feels rewarding as your reputation slowly builds mission after mission. If anything I'd say the campaign is actually too short. I think to be a really great one it could have gone on for another 3-4 mission. Not only that but the main antagonists of the game feel sort of lackluster. Mihaly seems like a really cool character and I enjoyed the multiple dog-fights you have with him, but his defeat feels really out of place and just thrown in with very little resolve. I like the idea of drone fighters too, but the launching of the two really good ones at the end doesn't seem to have any consequence other than to push the story just a little bit further in order to feel just that more over-the-top. Other than that I don't have many complaints with the story, it has it's problems, but so does every other story from any other game, I think Ace Combat 7 excels in its gameplay. From someone who's only other flight-focused game was Project Wingman this game was very different feeling. It still had arcade-y controls, but the system felt a lot more developed than PW's. For example, I was able to, and still am able to, enjoy and play PW's story to completion using nothing but mouse and keyboard. On the other hand, Ace Combat 7's opening mission and subsequent other missions felt almost IMPOSSIBLE to beat with just mouse and keyboard, so much so that I ended up plugging in a control during the second mission just to play. That being said, the controller controls feel a lot better and smoother too. I genuinely enjoyed the game with a control so if you don't have one I'd heavily suggest purchasing one. Other than that I have nothing more to say, I haven't played the Multiplayer, nor have I played the DLC, and I haven't maxed out the Flight Skill Tree but there are a large number of planes and upgrades to look forward to buying while playing the game casually that by the end of a single playthrough you should be able to max out one part of the tree and about half of another. Good game 9/10

TL:DR Review: If you're looking for an arcade-y combat pilot game, its great. As the seventh entry in the Ace Combat series? It's okay, but its not as good as the best games in the franchise. 7/10.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Alright, bias on the table, I'm an old-school Ace Combat fanboy, but I'm gonna try to judge this game as objectively as possible. 

Personally, I think its just OK. A 7/10, or a 3.5/5 or whatever scale you prefer. Not bad, but not great. It's not for lack of trying, though. While this game doesn't quite match my personal favorite Ace Combat games ever, those being Ace Combat 5 and Ace Combat Zero, it does come surprisingly close. There are only really two things holding this game back. 

First problem pertains to story. Certain elements of 7's story are a bit weak and under-explained, or just outright weird. And the game tends to lean a bit too far into nostalgia for previous entries, particularly 5. Nothing too egregious or blatantly nostalgia-baiting, but it does come across as distracting how much the game references or uses elements, locations, or plot points from previous entries. Makes it feel like the game can't really stand on its own, which, I think, is a major flaw. It also kinda suffers from being a "bridge game". No spoilers, here, for obvious reasons, but the game's ending kinda implies an Ace Combat 8, should one ever happen, will have a pretty radical paradigm shift to it, so, yeah.

The second problem is the music. That isn't to say the soundtrack is bad. It isn't. The vast majority of the music is perfectly solid, nothing extraordinary, but nothing terrible. But when you compare AC7's soundtrack to, say, the soundtracks from AC0 or AC5, its not even close. "Daredevil" is a great little track in isolation, but compare it to "The Unsung War" from AC5 or "Zero" from AC0 and it doesn't even compare. I still get chills listening to "The Unsung War". "Daredevil" has just never hit me that same way. It's a real shame too, because it feels like it had the potential to get there.

On the upside, though, the gameplay feels stellar and the graphics are lovely. Easily the best Ace Combat has ever looked and even the most hefty and laborous planes feel great to fly. There's a great mission variety in the campaign too, and a lot of replay value if you're the type to grind for higher scores or hunt down the rare aces in each level. There's a great range of DLC planes and skins too, including a collaboration with TOP GUN: Maverick, which is genuinely fuckin' sick. The Darkstar plane from that DLC is insanely fast and very fun to use. Highly recommend, if you're interested!

Overall, Ace Combat 7 is a solid game, but as a continuation of the Ace Combat franchise, it falls just shy of true greatness, for me at least. Its still easily worth the price, especially on sale, and the DLC is pretty good too, if you've got the money to burn, but its nothing ground-breaking or a definitive "must-buy".

The game exhibits a commendable visual presentation, earning it a rating of 8/10. The combat mechanics excel in terms of engagement and entertainment value, warranting a score of 9/10. While the campain possesses its merits, it is marred by numerous instances that lack coherence: 7/10.

The multiplayer mode provides an exhilarating experience; however, it is accompanied by subpar communication features. With offerings such as Battle Royale and Team Deathmatch, featuring five to six enjoyable maps, it would have undoubtedly benefited from the inclusion of a cooperative mode: 8/10.

While the game has a solid foundation, it doesn't quite reach its full potential. However, I must admit that I genuinely enjoyed it. The game managed to surprise me with numerous thrilling moments, and the overall experience it provides is quite impressive.

Let's start with the Pros:

-Super pretty, plane models look (mostly) badass, Some of the models look pretty janky when you first unlock them and it does the close in glamour shots.  The Rafael springs to mind.  The refueling probe looks like it's a grand total of 4 polygons...  probably only meant to be seen in close up the one time though...

-Controls are simple, whether you're using advanced mode or basic mode. Game feels like CoD in a fighter jet. Some sort of haptic feedback to speed inputs would be wonderful though. Without looking directly at your HUD, it can be very hard to manage your closure and not overshoot.

-It is arcadey goodness, nothing more, nothing less. (Try to) Shelve your "flight sim" expectations at the door and try not to pick up any bad habits that translate to DCS :D

-Yay, Top Gun aircraft!  I've watched the movie 14 times, so of course I wanted the DLC.

-Oh look, an F18E!  And another one with padded stats!

-Whizzing into the AO in the dark star, dropping a single bomb, and being gone before anyone can even lock you is super entertaining, if very very inefficient for beating campaign missions.

-Ran buttery smooth, well done on the optimization Bandai Namco! *side-eyes Bethesda*  Seriously, not. one. single. hiccup, crash, slowdown, freeze.  Nada. Zip. Zero.  *applauds*  If only every gaming studio produced as polished of a product.

And now cons (aviation pun intended)

-DLC aircraft are fun, but make the campaign super unbalanced initially.

-Then the AI bosses show up, and the unbalance switches in the other direction.  Now AI bosses can accelerate at ridiculous speeds and put 4000 *units* of whatever they measure in game with between you and them, turn around, and bake you with a super laser instantly.  "Watch where his nose is pointing" says the AWACS.  Hard to do when he's barely a red and black pixel on my monitor...

Also, the entire time you're trying to focus and fly a sortie, every single civilian numbskull is expositioning in your ear. I do not need to hear someone *grunting with effort* over comms during the most difficult dogfight in the game. Don't get me wrong, there's some tactical chatter... but there's a whole lot more blah blah blah from characters I've already forgotten about who aren't even in the air.  SHUDDUP WOULD YA!

Cinematics in between missions are excruciatingly long and long-winded to the ADHD prone like myself. I'd watch about 2 minutes of the cinematic and smash the start button as soon as the "I don't care" came along. I'm not even sure I could piece together the entire story tbh...  It was forgettable at best.  But that's like reading certain types of magazines for the articles...

Having played plenty of DCS and a few other sims, I realize most of my gripes stem from this not being as Simmy as I would like. For example:

-Stall mechanics, instead of just *not* generating lift like a real aircraft would, causes you to violently steer directly into the ground, as if you gave it the control input to do so. It's a built in self-unalive button for flying like a granny, apparently.
-Couple that with the energy management challenges you have to do in order to stay behind super drones that basically have VTOL, in close confines, and it results in a lot of really annoying crashes, 40 minutes into a dogfight that hasn't has a checkpoint yet.
- I heard SCP5K has a problem with not having checkpoints too.
- Did I mention checkpoints?  More of them.
-Some aircraft can go faster than 3000.  I have no idea what 3000 means, but it's the number in your hud...  It feels really fast, until the AI outruns you by a factor of 6.
- using a controller when I have the option of over 1000$ worth of Virpil flight stuff is just gross. I don't need to use all of my buttons, just let me map the 12 or so basic button presses and do my thing???  The thrustmaster options are awful... sry not sry.

I realize my complaints here are a personal problem, and it's hardly enough for me to regret buying the game for 20$ on sale and beating it over the weekend. It was entertaining, but strives to be waaaaaaay too story rich in a game with no real rhyme or reason except blow sh*t up.

TL/DR, if you're looking for a Sim, this ain't it. If you're looking to scratch a Battlefield style Air Superiority itch, this'll probably do it.  You're probably going to be way in over your head in multiplayer, because you're way behind the curve if you're starting now, and real world BFM is pretty useless.  But it makes you feel like you're going fast and there's lots of dopamine on a steady drip.  Get it on sale and it's even better.

Un juego épico, sin duda el mejor de la saga. Aunque le falta algo de contenido al multiplayer (como capturar zonas aterrizando, defender y atacar por ejemplo). Fuera de estos dos puntos mínimos, es un juego con una campaña desafiante y emocionante, con gráficos que no se quedan cortos a la fecha 2023. Además, con la progresión del aircraft tree y posibilidad de poner partes a tu avión da la sensación de tener tu avión único con la configuración que mas te acomode y con una cantidad de aviones considerable para desbloquear. Muy recomendado le doy un 9.7 de 10 :3 gracias bandai perdón por tan poco.
