Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is a high-flying masterpiece that puts players in the cockpit of breathtaking aerial combat. From a player's perspective, it's an exhilarating journey through the clouds, offering an unmatched sense of freedom and adrenaline. The graphics and attention to detail in the aircraft and environments are astonishing, making every dogfight a visual spectacle. The storyline, filled with dramatic twists and engaging characters, keeps you invested in the campaign. The wide variety of aircraft and customization options cater to different playstyles, adding depth to the gameplay. Ace Combat 7 is a thrilling experience that proves aerial combat games are alive and soaring, making it a must-play for any aviation enthusiast.

tl;dr game is boring and repetitive

The campaign is fun for all of five missions. Most of it is a slog, and artificial difficulty with scripted invulnerability for major enemies isn't fun either. The story is pretty mediocre as well. The gameplay is also mediocre. Everything that was fun about past Ace Combat games has been stripped away. No wingman mechanics, no diverging story, but you can do backflips so that's cool I guess. It's like they deliberately didn't add all the nice things that have been in the game since Ace Combat 5, but all the build-up for having a functional squadron is still there in the dialogue and story. Why bother being part of a squadron at all if you're just a lonewolf who doesn't cooperate with anyone? Also, your allies don't have working missiles anyway. They are nerfed to the point of being useless, so any missiles shot by allies are just for show. This is not a bug. This was done on purpose.

Does the game redeem itself with multiplayer? No. Project Aces was by far the laziest with this.

The multiplayer is dead. Assume you find a lobby, it will have a hacker because this game has no anti-cheat. Assume you get no hackers, you get two boring gamemodes; free for all, and team death match, and you get five maps to play them on. I think. Really, they're all the same except that one level with the cliffs that you can fly through. That's the only map with any character. Except, the fun is suddenly lost because RNG lightning hits you every few seconds and screws up your screen.

There are no cooperative gamemodes at all. Allegedly, the engine can't handle rendering other enemies... even though they could have literally just re-used the same engine as Assault Horizon like they did with Infinity.

Ace Combat: Infinity was better, but they shut it down, so you can't play that anymore at all. I fear this marks the beginning of the end of a franchise I have loved.

"Sure when VR comes out that will be cool," I said years ago. VR is never coming. Ever. Project Wingman made a better game, and I said that long before I ended up being a part of it, so that's not my own bias speaking.

This game has no replayability. Even the one play through sucks. I loved this franchise, but I will not be buying the next one if it even lasts that long.

War is bad but planes are rad. Few things give me as much joy as flying as fast as possible and splashing bandits. The tutorial is good at getting you used to plane games but I definitely recommend sinking in a little time to learn to fly with the expert controls. The story is good if you're looking for that although in some missions it can be a little difficult to tell what's going on story-wise because you're trying to focus on the objective (I'm looking at you Mission 16). You get a wide variety of planes to choose from, with the aircraft tree splitting into three routes, American jets, Russian jets, and EU jets. Getting new planes and armament for those planes can feel a bit overwhelming at first but don't worry about trying to get every plane and just focus on one tree. I will say that I think BamCo is going a little nutso-mode with the DLC for AC7 but I suggest getting the ones that bring DLC missions. All in all, if you like plane games you probably already own this one and if you don't like plane games, wait for it to go on sale and give it a shot.

Halfway through the campaign (I think) and I'm gonna say this is a really fun, casual game. If you're expecting realism, then this game is definitively not for you (go play DCS World instead). The emphasis is very clearly in making you feel overpowered and, well, an Ace.

My experience so far is a great, fun game. I recommend Project Wingman if you like this, in case you're waiting for the next Ace Combat.

Very fun game experience! This is my first entry on the Ace Combat series and it did not disappoint me! Gameplay-wise, it takes some time getting used to the controls but once you got the hang of it, you'll be soaring the skies and taking down enemies with ease. As for story, it's okay I guess. SPOILERS: [spoiler]I was having too much fun that I didn't even realized that the game already ended with the sky elevator tunnel mission. I really thought there was gonna be a far more grand of a finale mission after that but I guess I should've picked up that final boss memo already one mission ago when the game threw the Arsenal Wing boss against me. Overall, the ending left me a bit confused and begging for more but I still had fun with the campaign story regardless. Just wish there was a bit more to it. As for the side content with Matias "Salvation" Torres, on the other hand, I enjoyed that side story a LOT and I really recommend playing that one![/spoiler]

Anyways, I definitely recommend this game if you're into arcade-style plane shooter games! Very engaging and really worth your time! 👍

An overall fun arcade plane fighting game with a very steep learning curve. As a result, it can cause a TON of frustration (if all you expect is extremely simplistic arcade plane game where you press a button and stuff goes BOOM! I know I expected that and was shocked to find out it's not THAT simple... although once you learn to fly well enough, it's exactly that - you press a button, stuff goes BOOM! with fancy explosions and nice graphics). Sounds is pretty decent, too, and I've encountered no software issues, crashes or performance issues, in this regard everything's well.

At first I didn't like the game. As I said, I had a lot of trouble with certain missions (most missions after third, I think). I kept losing despite playing on easy difficulty, I crashed a whole lot, I failed objectives a lot more than I crashed and overall I did not like the game. It was HARD! It seemed like the game was made in a way that caused a ton of annoyance.

After some 30-40 hours (there are some fun parts in the game so I kept on playing), after beating the entire campaign on easy, then on normal, and then going after every Ace and shooting them all down I finally learned to fly a little. I started my "hard" playthrough (for the achievement!) I managed to get S rank for the first 8 missions (without even trying!). I also shot down all aces before that, I guess knowing their spawn conditions and how to approach certain missions helped a lot. Overall, now I'm finally having fun playing the campaign. After switching to "normal" controls (from expert). I thought I knew how to fly a plane on expert controls from playing a lot of similar games and BOY was I wrong!

Basically: I can recommend this game if you:
- are a fan of series, know how to play Ace Combat series, what to expect and you like it
- are open to new experiences and are not easily frustrated when things don't go your way from the very start (that's me!), and are ready to put forth effort to learn the game, learn the missions and win conditions and adapt (that's also me! although these two sides are in constant conflict)

In short: after suffering through first 10 hours and playing for 30+ hours I finally like this game and can recommend it, as long as you know what to expect!

Let me start with that I come from an military family, so games like this are my favorite games. 

Ace Combat 7 is by far one of the best air combat games that you can play. Now with that said it's no DCS, But that doesn't mean it's not fun. I have play through the game 2 times on pc and Xbox. The controls are very simple to get used to (With context needed). I would recommend playing with a controller, as I have tried with mnk and it's not quite as natural and it has a huge learning curve. The game play is amazing. The missions are thought out and you get the story in a manner that makes it easier to take in then some titles. The aircraft models are relatively accurate. I can't shame the game or studio on that front as I understand hoe the government(s) are with things of that nature. I got the game on sale during Christmas 22, and I got a version with more DLC but it doesn't change the game play in a matter where it's too much pay to have fun. You can get the base edition and have the exact same amount of fun. What I would say is that for anyone who has this on the wish list or in cart and can't pull the trigger I would say wait till its on sale and you won't regret it. 

Overall: Ace Combat 7 is a fun arcade air combat game that at full price I would say is worth it. Con(s): Getting new aircraft can take a bit of time. First play through you can get decently far in the progression tree but you will have to play through like 2-3 times if not more to get all the aircraft and upgrades/parts. It's a niche con but there's only 2 real air to ground main missions, I feel like more missions with more air to ground combat. (There's 20 total missions). Pros: Easy to learn, Aircraft variety, Story/story telling, Characters, Combat, Ability to return to the game after a long period of time and being able to get right back into it without needing to re-learn controls.

Ace Combat 7 is a return to the form of yesteryear.
Bandai Namco did everything they could to make Ace Combat 7 a top title and they succeeded.
The variety in missions is huge and in terms of graphics and audio, Ace Combat 7 is one of the flight combat titles on PC.

Watch a short gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zrngIJjkrSc

The story is a bit faded, but that won't stop you from getting a lot of fun out of the game.
The length of the missions can vary enormously. There are missions that can be completed in five to ten minutes, but there are also 20 to 25 minutes. It is often difficult to predict in advance how long you will be working on a mission. Fortunately, there are checkpoints. If you make a mistake, you don't have to redo the whole mission. But… these checkpoints are sometimes very far apart.

The game works great on a steam deck too: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=feNkWRXlk0M

Each mission takes place in a different setting, so you're always anxiously awaiting what's to come.
What also makes you want to keep playing this game are the graphics and the sound.
You really often stand with your mouth open looking at the fantastically designed aircraft, the various types of terrain and the clouds.
Dynamic weather conditions sound nice on the back of the packaging, but the great thing is that it really adds something in Ace Combat 7. When you fly into the clouds your visibility is reduced to five meters and your cockpit is covered with rain and/or ice, but your enemies can't see you (and vice versa of course).

The Ace Combat series has developed over time from a fun game to a full-fledged Combat Flight Action Video Game that also forces you to think about the use of fighter jets.
There is also a nice multiplayer option that provides variety. If that wasn't enough, the many options in the tech tree give you plenty of options to complete each mission to the best of your ability.

You can tell that the development was rough because the story is all over the place (yes, even for an Ace Combat game), it spends way too much time with Avril and her merry band of "Literally Who?", and has an unhealthy obsession with pitting you against boring UAVs or pilots that choose to ignore the laws of physics. 

Speaking of physics, this is the first game where you can intentionally initiate post-stall maneuvers. Unfortunately there's almost never a reason to do so since you need to slow waaaay down to do it. That sucks. 

But at the end of the day, it's Ace Combat on the PC and it's not Assault Horizon, so you get to spend all your time committing war crimes in jets instead of putzing around in a crappy helicopter. It's really fun. Sadly the multiplayer is DOA because Bamco/Project Aces/whoever the fuck is too lazy to do something about game modifications in multiplayer games, so you're screwed because at least one player per lobby is going to have some kind of super plane and mess your shit up. No big loss for me since I'm trash anyway, but FYI.

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

My specs- 
Intel 3930K 6-core@3.8Ghz

Xbox One wired USB controller/ bluetooth XBone S w/ Steam Link
 Ive seen all the negative comments and nasty discussion boards. DON'T LET THESE DETER YOU!!!
If your gaming rig is half decent, and you have a USB joystick controller available, you can play this. I've suffered no issues whatsoever running it on high settings. 

The gameplay itself is a mixture of AC 6 and Zero, there are no squadron controls like those in 5 or zero. The hangar layout is exactly like Zero, including special weapon selection. The Aircraft tree system includes aircraft, special weapons, and also upgrades that can be added to aircraft via slots. The story in the cut scenes follows that of an NPC rather than the protagonist, as well as one of the main antagonists, the first being similar to AC 6 and the latter more like AC 4. 
The Launch edition pre-order package came with the Phantom II pre-unlocked, as well as 3 additional aircraft skins. Of these was the Su-37: Yellow 13 from AC 4,  F-15C: Pixy from AC Zero,and AC 5 Razgriz  F14-D, so far my favorite.
If I find any issues later in the game Ill update this review. So far, Namco and Proj. Aces have done a Damn good job IMO.

Update: I finished the campaign and i gotta say, the character development improved a lot.
My only complaint thus far is that the online multiplayer seems pretty empty whenever I jump on. Hopefully the DLCs fix that.

Update 1-4-2020: Finally started playing again, but I have one major complaint: Runs like piss via steamlink over wifi. Even in Campaign missions on balanced settings. I suspect it may be something in windows 10 (have a new pc as of this update) or 1 of the 18-20 steamlink client updates I had to install before playing. This probably isn't the game's fault, but it is annoying.

Update 8-13-2023:
Having not touched this game in a while, building a new PC since the last update here and having purchased the Alicorn DLCs (as well as completing Project Wingman) I decided it's time to return to this game. For recording purposes I did have to drop the settings a bit and I didn't bother with steamlink, game still looks great on 1440 x 2560 @ 120 fps (with a 1080 ti).  Main complaint I have now is the lack of a discount on 
 or second season pass for all the 25th anniversary + Top Gun Maverick content... almost $60 USD combined as of updating this review, with the latest of these already a year old at this point. Come on Bandai-Namco...cut us a break. Or atleast remaster Fire of Liberation :/

and it perfectly embodies the dreams I had as a kid playing with my toy planes.
You can put yourself into the cockpit of the jet that your granddad flew and tag bandits; just like I did as a kid
You can get back home from watching Top Gun and get into the cockpit of the F-14 and still splash bandits; just like I did as a kid
You can buy models of aircraft that you saw flying overhead at an airshow; just like I did as a kid
You can come home from school and fly with your wingmates; just like I did as a kid

This game isn't a simulator it is a dream: mine, yours, and everyone else who played on the floor pushing plane models around.
I love it.

My first encounter with the Ace Combat franchise was Ace Combat 04: Distant Thunder (AC4) (the name differs by region but it's the PS2 one) and I've loved it ever since. I tried everything I could to get my hands on the subsequent releases but due to me living in a 3rd world country and rather young age at the time (I think I was 8 or 9 back then? Can't quite remember), it was next to impossible for me to get a hold of anything else due to either monetary reasons or just because the games and consoles they used were too old at that point. Despite all those setbacks, I finally got my second chance at fulfilling that nostalgia in the way of Ace Combat 07: Skies Unknown (AC7). I played it on a shitty laptop barely hitting 30 fps on low settings but I finished nonetheless and all that's left for me to do is kill all the Aces in Ace difficulty. Tbh, this is more of love letter to Project Aces than a Review because now that I can finally pay for things myself, I will buy every Project Aces game that belongs to the Ace Combat franchise. This game was everything that made my childhood great, I hope the devs know they changed someone's life for the better even if it wasn't their intention, now here's my honest review:

As a total novice to Ace Combat, I wasn't sure what I was going to get into in regards to how this game is. I have minimal experience playing Flight simulator games, my only other experience being Xbox 360's H.A.W.X, (And with a flight stick no less). 
That said, I found the story to be typically Shonen, something that was made and wrapped up with a good level of emotions involved. The gameplay is everything that one could expect, providing two options, a Starfox style turn in the direction you want "Simple" Control style, and a Typical Flight simulator "Complex" Style. The added bonuses unleashed over free updates and the expanded flight tree provides a fantastic slew of options to earn your way to amazing planes and fantastic weapons. 
Truly an Ace in a genre like Flying games. 


I'd give the game an overall 8/10. There are quite a few things it does that no other game has done for me, but it's also got a few negatives, namely the feeling of always being the main hero requiring you to be able to manage EVERY situation that arises. Ahh....Ace Combat, as always, top notch, Story rich, awesome gameplay, it's a 9.8/10 for me. Assault Horizon is so much better than this Skies Unknown in so many ways like Apache missions, intense gameplay, close up dog fight. But i really love and recommended  this too tho.

The game was pretty enjoyable. The story was interesting but sometimes hard to follow at the beginning, with the different factions and all that. It was sometimes hard to follow what was actually happening but at some point you understand just enough to feel involved and a little immersed. Gameplay makes the game a fun, relatively polished arcade flight sim. Checkpoints can sometimes be unforgiving. You don't die a ton on normal but it feels absolutely horrible when you dodge tons of missiles but just miscalculate your turn and crash into a building or stall at just the wrong timing -  then for you to loose up to 15 or 20 minutes of progress because there were no checkpoints during the mission. There were definitely some moments where the dogfights were positively tense, and it did feel 'epic' and grandiose. If you're into that, and consider the lack of checkpoints just a welcome added difficulty, the game is definitely worth picking up on sale (but not on full price imo for what I got out of it).

When I play this game I am transported to over a decade ago playing Ace Combat 4, siting on the floor, being absolutely blown away by (at the time modern) PS2 graphics. 

I cant express how happy I am to see a childhood franchise, not only being still made, but being made well and passionately. 

The short of this game is that you are playing basically Japanese TopGun with great English VA and fun (all be it simple and bit arcade-y by design) combat. The story? Umm well something about a country trying to take over your homeland and you have to defend it. 

My biggest complaint is that you suffer from a case of "Main Character Syndrome" where basically it feels like you are the only semi-competent air force pilot in the entire army. Your wing men generally have some plot armor and cant be shot down and down enemies at a snails pace. Unfortunately this means allied units function more as a distraction force then anything else. I wish I knew more about some of them. Gave me more of a reason to care about them. 

If you want to have to have the power fantasy of a being Chad McBigplane and willing to overlook some of the weaker story elements. This is the game for you.

Such a brilliant game, especially when picked up on the sale with all the DLC (Top Gun aircraft and special aircraft and missions).

I'm a JAS 39 Gripen fan, I'd like some more Swedish aircraft (Viggen? Tunnan?) instead of the majority of US aircraft, but still, a very challenging game on hard difficulty, a nice "milk run" on normal and easy.

Buy it! Especially if the bundle is on sale! You won't be disappointed.

HANDS DOWN THE WORST ACE COMBAT TO DATE. 

I have played every Ace Combat released on console since Ace Combat 2. Namco learned a lot about making a quality Ace Combat game over the years and I don't think they applied any of that to this game.

STORY
I know Namco can do engaging stories, I remember the ending of Ace Combat 4 with its epic music and how it made you feel like you were a real Ace ready to end the war and the sense of urgency during the Search & Rescue mission from Ace Combat 5. Those missions really got me invested in the story, but there is none of that here. The story is confusing and not at all engaging and I found myself being bored by the cut scenes. Plot points feel contrived, pointless, and predicable. 

FLYING
I could forgive a lot if the flying was good, but my god how do you mess this up. I initially thought that clouds, weather, and terrain would be a nice addition to the tactics, but it’s just annoying after the first 3 missions. Clouds just blocked my own missiles and made hitting enemies harder, you’re not going to dive into the clouds to shake a missile, plus staying in them too long just makes your plane ice up (like we haven’t figured out plane deicing over half a century ago). There is some kind of modeled weather that can randomly take away the precision I needed by introducing wind, I guess? It always seems to happen when I needed that precision the most, like when I was flying through a radar net or I needed to hold the targeting pod on a silo while getting shot at by an AA gun as my wingman watches on and does nothing as the timer ticks down the last few sounds of the mission, which leads me to difficulty. 

DIFFICULTY
The game isn’t ‘challenging’ hard, its ‘annoying’ hard. I want missions that are a challenge and perhaps require a thought about tactics and give me that since of accomplishment when you beat them. This game, however, just finds ways to make the missions as painful and annoying as possible. When I finally beat them, I didn’t feel like I had accomplished anything, it was mostly just “thank god that’s over with.” Namco found several ways to make missions more annoyingly difficult like marking all targets as unknown until they randomly decide to mark them as enemies, hiding threats on escort missions until you get close to them, not showing you the health or status of friendlies your suppose to protect, and adding in “weather” to mess up your ability to fly through tight spaces in missions that require you to fly through tight spaces. Enemies in the air will sometimes dodge missiles for no other reason than F-you.

GAMEPLAY
The AI in the game is horrendous. The game was telling me to shoot down drones to protect the other friendly squadron but at one point one of the enemy drones was just flying in formation with the friendly squadron while I race from one side of the map to the other listening to them scream on the radio "he's on my six." Many of the missions have almost a dozen friendly aircraft in the air with you. You don’t get to give them orders and they don’t help you out at all. I watched as a friendly fighter would fire a missile at a SAM site, watch the missile explode, and nothing happens. 
On the first playthrough I ran into a few missions that are just unnecessarily hard for no reason other than it was my first playthrough and I didn’t have the special weapons I needed unlocked for them. Without the right parts unlocked there are more than a few missions where I just ran out of missiles by the time I got to the obvious boss I knew was coming and all I could do was just crash and reload at the check point to restock. 
This game adds terrain and weather as more of a thing, but it sacrifices the size of the skybox to do it. I remember the fun of being engaged in an air to ground fight in previous games only to hear the alert to intercept bombers coming in at 30,000 ft and the trill of racing up as the sky turned a darker blue and getting into a high-altitude dog fight with the escorts. In this game they tried the same thing but with the smaller skybox they were flying at 8,000 feet and it just didn’t work. To me this made it feel like you were fighting in a confined space where dogfighters are too close to the ground, and it doesn’t feel like you have room to really move around. 


MULTIPLAYER
I used to spend hours in Ace Combat Infinity’s multiplayer playing the co-op missions. Those multiplayer matches were some of the most fun I have had in an Ace Combat game, and I was looking forward to getting to relive those glory days, but at last, no. The multiplayer is strictly TDM or battle royal, both where you are taking on other players. While skill does matter, unless you find a room that limits the cost of the aircraft when you’re starting out it’s completely dominated by veteran players who are higher on the aircraft tree than you are. Not that any of that matters anyways considering there is hardly anyone on the servers so it’s not like you get to be picky about what room you join.

As an aviation enthusiast, and this also being my first Ace Combat game, it was relatively arcadey, which is not a bad thing at all, it's a breath of fresh air from more simulator/realistic aerial combat games. The story itself was really enjoyable, one of my favorite parts being the jpg of the dog. The combat itself was really fun, it provided the right amount of realism and arcadeyness which made the game really enjoyable for me personally. Not all people will love it, but if you're okay with the arcade style, then I say buy it when it's on sale lol, $60 is not worth it at all, but when it's on sale it's a great purchase. The usage of modern day fighters in an era of drones was really fun, you are challenged with the development of unmanned dog-fight capable aircraft and you in your F-16 in the beginning is really an enjoyable experience. There's different routes you can go on the aircraft tree, whether it be the JASDF, USAF, European, or RFAF line of aircraft, all of them are enjoyable and have their own perks. Arguably, the F-22 is the best endgame aircraft except for the X-02S Strike Wyvern which is after you beat the game. You can also do a sort of new game plus if you beat it on Expert difficulty, unlocking Ace difficulty which I still have yet to complete, but so far it is a bit more challenging, but you do keep your previously unlocked jets which is nice.

TLDR; Game is great, arcadey, has great aircraft, good story, F-22 best jet, Ace difficulty cool, highly recommend

If you're an Ace Combat fan, you already know the game is great. For those who are not fans of the series, expect a fun, casual, flying action game with cheesy - sometimes cringe dialogue - and a forgettable story about two warring nations that serves as a backdrop for the missions.

As for the game being a console-PC port...it's not great. Actually it kinda sucks (without mods).

I needed to modify the game to work on my ultrawide monitor, and there's a video on YouTube posted by the channel ultrawide Nexus titled: ACE COMBAT 7 SKIES UNKNOWN ULTRAWIDE GAMEPLAY FIX. Check that out on how to do it. Worked well for me.

While I did get the game to work on my ultra wide monitor, you cannot adjust the HUD to the boundaries of your screen, so the HUD is centered on the screen with wasted space near the edges. When I tried playing from my PC on my TV, while the game looked incredible the HUD was off-center and I had no idea how to change it; reinstalling the game without mods and playing on default settings didn't change anything. Such a shame, cause this game is a blast to play on a bigger screen.

Overall great game, looks and runs better than the console version of course, but the poor quality port hurts the reputation a bit. Get it on a sale with the Top Gun Maverick DLC and you'll have a blast.

I recently had the opportunity to play the new Ace Combat 7 game, and I must say that it is an amazing addition to the legendary Ace Combat series. As expected, Ace Combat 7 delivers an adrenaline-filled thrill-ride. The game features state-of-the-art graphics that bring to life the intense battles between player and enemy aircraft. The controls are tight and responsive, allowing for a precise and maneuverable experience.

The game’s story makes for an engaging narrative, with plenty of twists, turns, and thrilling missions. With a variety of aircrafts and weapons to choose from, the game offers plenty of customization options with which to tailor your experience to your own tastes. The game also boasts an impressive lineup of voice actors, who add a layer of realism to the proceedings.

The online multiplayer is especially impressive, as the game allows up to 16 players to battle each other in large-scale battles. The matchmaking system is responsive and the connection is rarely laggy, meaning that players can expect smooth and intense battles. Furthermore, there is plenty of additional content such as leaderboards, tournaments, and ranked playlists, which facilitate competing for high scores.

All in all, I would highly recommend Ace Combat 7. It offers an exhilarating experience filled with plenty of exciting missions, customizations, and engagements. With the huge variety of aircrafts and weapons, the game offers plenty of tactical options, so that no two battles are the same. The game’s online multiplayer also adds a social component that encourages competition, making this an immersive and engaging experience. A must-play for any fan of the Ace Combat series.

If you couldn't tell by my username, I adore this series.

The game is pretty straightforward about what it is so if you think a combat flight sim with metal gear undertones, a banging soundtrack, an amazing and probably very familiar vocal cast is even remotely up your alley, you'll have a lot to appreciate here.

The game is not without problems, as no VR support and a lack of support for certain resolutions is a pretty big disappointment. The DLC hasn't seen certain updates it needs either, one of the features is a music player added to the menu but the available music does not include any of the great multiplayer songs or the music from the 3 DLC maps, or the Top Gun crossover song. The structure of the DLC is pretty strange too, since the highest tier package deal of the game available includes the Top Gun and season pass, but will still leave you missing a fair amount of the DLC planes. Just seems like a strange choice is all.

That being said, I don't think any of that takes away from the overall experience of the game, there is a lot to love here and I think this is a game well worth playing. The story is a great cheesy kind of fun, the combat is smooth and the map gimmicks feel fun with so much room to optimize each attempt and even approach maps in entirely new ways between attempts. When it's on sale, this game hits some pretty low prices and it might just surprise you if you end up trying it. Would definitely recommend it and many other games in the series to anyone interested.

There's a few other games in the world that make YOU feel like such a badass like this game. Probably one of the best arcade air combat games I've ever played, if not THE best.

Gameplay - 8/10 (9/10 with mods)
Glorious. The biggest reason to buy this game is the gameplay. High-G turns, PSM's, the variety of special weapons, facing off against the harder enemies, and in the later half, hearing the cheer from your teammates and the fear from your enemies. S-ranking, no-damage runs, gun-only runs, and playing with the sheer variety of planes and special weapons (especially if you got all the DLC's) further increase replayability.
BUT, your 'teammates' are absolutely TERRIBLE. You may be an ace pilot, but these teammates exist to just draw attention away from enemies - they don't actually shoot them down lol. As well, in the campaign, [SPOILER START] it can be a bit infuriating to 'defeat' the enemy ace without actually defeating them (until the final arc). His plane's invincible, and even in the mission where you kill him, he's still invincible until he says all of his lines. Only then can you kill him. As if his monologues are magic spells that make him invincible. [SPOILER END]

Story - 7/10
What a silly melodrama this story is lmao. Lots of, well, interesting choices made by the nations. The 2nd arc of this story has the most comically evil commander I've ever seen. And it can be kinda jarring to hear them speak of doing so well, when in reality they probably took down a small target or two, when you've taken out 30+ already.
Crucially, however, in the 4th (final) arc of the game, it really tries to hammer home the idea that 'war is hell'. Which, after celebrating for taking down some hard to hit targets, can be hard to digest. To put it simply, the delivery was not impactful - I just shot down the massive boss airship in the most brilliant display of aerobatics ever, I don't think I care about a few refugees that died thanks to the enemy's collateral fire. Not my fault bro.

DLC - 10/10
You HAVE to get the DLC's - the new planes, some new weapons, and the greatest character you'll ever meet in Ace Combat history.

TL;DR - War is bad, planes are rad.

I think this game is a solid 7/10, you get exactly what you see, a simplified jet flying sim.
The story didn't really get my attention, but I assume it does make a lot more sense and has a lot more impact if you played the previous games. It's not tightly tied to them as far as I know, but there are references and characters that are shared. I know this because I played AC5 a very long time ago and some names sounded familiar, although I remember next to nothing about that game. 
The controls are good and it's fun to play, although the targeting system can be a bit janky at times, it seems to prioritize enemies in your FOV, even if they're much much further away than others which you don't immediately see, and this can prove to be a bit annoying in missions where you have to target specific enemies or low-speed, ground focused missions.
The soundtrack is very varied, has orchestra, rock, jazz, etc. Overall I enjoyed it a lot and it's probably one of the strongest points alongside optimization, this game runs basically anywhere.

This game is amazing in singleplayer, the multiplayer is full of Meta builds and people who have definetly played this game longer then anyone should.

This game is fun if for casuals and try hard.
They have simple steering mode for the casuals who just wanted to shoot down enemy bandits and have fun or you can pull 12Gs, do cobra maneuver, or become an acrobatic pilots as you progress and learn some skill sets to finally move on from casual control. 

The base game planes are also very good, the unlock process to the end of the tech tree only takes about 7-9 hours of gameplay, this system allows the casual aspect to have somewhat of a challenge so that you be considerate on how to spend your MRP, do you want to spend it on parts? or do you want to get new toys for your aircraft? or just simply buy a new and much more powerful aircraft. They also have 1st time completion bonus for each chapter, so it tremendously helps you on grinding your favorite jets. 

The graphics is also still up to date, the planes looks very wonderful, the sun is too bright in some occasion and I don't know if taking screenshots are possible in this game, I'm not too deep in the mission replay where it shows a recording of you at the end of the chapter. The UI is also very simple and not so crowded with too many information, the main menu is also unique because it made me feel as if i'm accessing through secret military files.

Not to mention that the story not very easy to understand if you don't play any previous games, but in the text dialogue there are some foreshadowing about what happened before this game but it is easy to get hooked on to the story speaking from my perspective :D

Overall 8.5/10 game

So in conclusion great graphics, easy for casuals to enjoy, challenging games for those who wanted to play it on hardest difficulty, easy progression system, Nice UI, and Great story.

Edit: I do not recommend it if you are looking for the Multiplayer experience of this game, It feels like it has been abandoned. I takes too long to join a room as well.

[b]My Score:[/b] 9/10

[h1]Prologue[/h1]
Our story takes place in a universe somewhat different from ours, but with many similarities, such as having developed, designed and built the same fighter models and military planes as our world. This story takes place on the continent of Usean, a place where we find large cities, and also beautiful natural landscapes, such as beaches, forests, deserts and various other types of landscapes, unfortunately all this exuberance is found, where more than a decade ago in 2001 , there was a great war that affected the entire continent. ^^

A war that involved the Kingdom of Erusea, against the other nations of the continent and ended in an armistice. After the end of the war, the other nations, during their reconstruction process, allied themselves with a large military force from another continent, the Osean Federation, which now has troops on the continent for "protection" of the countries, as well as starting the construction of a huge space elevator in the southwest region of the continent, very close to the border with Erusea, bothering and worrying the leadership of the kingdom. Now it's 2019, with the construction of the space elevator completed, and the continued presence of Osean military troops on the continent, making Erusia decide that the time has come to put an end to this, with a withering strike from they air force that would start to a new large war. ^^

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ An excellent game of military fighters, with the most varied types of aircraft, weapons and twenty missions with different objectives on maps with several kilometers in area, to test the aircraft and skills.
+ Twenty-eight different fighter models, each with its own three special weapon options, plus numerous upgrades that can be used on all, including two fifth generation models.
+ Beautiful graphics during combat, including options such as viewing from the cockpit's point of view, and having the camera follow the last missile fired.
+ Impeccable soundtrack, with some really good songs, which I listened to over and over again.
+ Story despite being shown only from the point of view of our squadron and a few other characters, it is easy to understand.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- If you plan to unlock all the planes and upgrades, you need to be patient to collect all the necessary points, as there will be many.
- Some achievements require a lot of repetition, such as completing all quests on all difficulty settings. In addition to achievements that can only be achieved in online mode.
- The game has a considerable amount of DLC, including several aircraft that could have been in the base game but are DLC-exclusive.

[h1] Game mechanics[/h1]
This is how the player's participation begins as a fighter pilot, of one of the divisions of the Osean Federation stationed on the continent of Usean, being awakened by a call to battle on the first day of the invasion by the troops of the Kingdom of Erusea, as the novice and "very communicative" pilot Trigger, performing various types of missions, such as shooting down targets in the air, destroying installations on the ground, protecting allies, among several other types of military operations, throughout the twenty missions of the story mode portraying the war. ^^

In addition, the story starts with only one model of aircraft and a special weapon released, but as the missions are carried out, the player earns points, which can be accumulated to exchange them for more options of special weapons, improvements that can be used in any aircraft, and new fighter models, including a fifth-generation US and Russian fighter, to soar through the skies and shoot down enemies. But be careful, even when piloting the best fighters, the bosses still provide an excellent challenge, especially on the highest difficulties. ^^

[h1] Art and sound[/h1]
Produced by the Japanese studio Bandai Namco, I really liked the graphics of the world and the units on land and sea, but mainly in the modeling of the various fighters, which are the focus of the game after all, with the player piloting them throughout the duration. But the highlight really goes to the sound part, with good sound effects but mainly an impeccable soundtrack, with great songs that even get muffled when we are inside a cloud, some that I kept repeating the mission several times to hear again. ^^

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown was my first contact with any title in the series, I admit that I had never played an Ace Combat, but I really liked what I saw in this one and I just think it's a shame that I don't have more missions to do, so I can only repeat the missions to try to get the best possible score. Anyway, for those who like military plane games, especially fighters, this is a game that I strongly recommend, whether you are experienced or just like me, a newcomer to the series. I would also be very grateful if Bandai wants to release a sequel one day. ^^

I enjoy that the dynamic of this game franchise hasn't changed since I was a teenager, back when I was playing Ace Combat 4 on PS2. The arcade design, with the timer, the near misses, the sometimes vagueness of the situation, and unrealistic flight controls leaves enough to make the game really stressful, in a fun way, because if you fail you just lost 15 minutes and need to start over again. Too many games hold your hand all the way though these days.

The mission design is pretty terrible. The 50 other allied planes flying with you don't do anything. At all. You are constantly hearing that annoying "missile. missile" every .2 seconds. And for whatever reason every mission has a timer. Like you will be in the middle of a 10 min sortie, striking ground targets, and the AWACS will say "sowwy, time is up because it is fuck you:3". Fucking infuriating game. Honestly the time limit almost ruins the game. It doesn't make it harder it just makes it way less fucking fun. You cannot turn it off. Oh it is also worth mentioning that you are the ONLY target it the sky. Missiles, whether they are SAMs or AAMs will only seek you. You will have at least 2-3 missiles locking onto you at any given time. Normally you would evade and engage the source but you have 3 minutes to rack up an arbitrary score based on pretty much nothing. This game is fun, you will have fun. But you will probably break a monitor in two. Also some of the objectives are not stated and you'll just fail because you werent flying in a specific direction. Honestly just play on easy. Any harder difficulty is just stupid.

I returned this game for a few reasons that are specific to my PC platform and tastes. I am coming from the perspective of someone that played Project Wingman first before trying AC7 on PC. In comparison, this game feels like (really it just IS) a a low effort port of an otherwise great console game, whereas PWM feels like it was a purpose-built homage to AC for people to enjoy on PC.

The biggest issue with AC7 is the fact that there is no native ultra-widescreen support. I run dual 2k 3440x1440 monitors, and in a day and age where Ultrawide screens are becoming more affordable and commonplace, it is inexcusable to resort to letterboxing players with these aspect ratios. It especially makes even less sense knowing that the game allows you to natively scale texture detail by 200%. it's such an issue that you have to download 3rd party software that unlocks the game from Steam DRM and use a python executable to force widescreen support. Doing so, MAY result in you being incapable of enjoying multiplayer due to this mod being picked up as cheat software. The installer for the fix even states this. So fixing the issue has the potential to lock you out of playing half of the game. While I will admit this is a very specific problem to Ultra-widescreen users such as myself, it is still an inexcusable oversight from such a big developer. 

Further indications that AC7 on Steam is just a poor excuse of a PC port, is the fact that the in-game mouse&keyboard controls seem to be bare-minimum "usable". This game doesn't just have "full game pad support," to enjoy this game you essentially MUST use a controller to experience it to it's fullest extent. Drawing comparisons to PWM again, that game's m&kb controls are not just serviceable, they can be an optimal way to play if you so choose. The game's menu UI also has no mouse support and you must use your keyboard for menu controls. This may not seem like much, but it shows again how much effort was really put in to making this accessible for PC users. To take it to another level, the game assumes you will be using a controller to such an extent, that the in-game control tutorials from the first few missions will display controller icons for keybinds even if no gamepad is recognized on your system. The final straw for me was that there is no way to invert my lateral movement on mouse, AND there is no way to change keybinds while in a mission. You MUST exit to the main menu from whatever it was you were doing to then adjust your settings. More low-effort port clues.

Is the game good? YES, it can be amazing, but only if you're expecting to play the game exactly as though you would on a console. but with my specific setup, it's only a chore to play with clunky controls, has terrible PC hardware support, and bad UI contextualized for console/controller players. If you are a PC player in a similar situation as me, pass on this, and pick up Project Wingman if you haven't already. In many ways it is the better game, at least for people who want to enjoy a arcade fighter game on the PC.

I spent ~20€ on this, and I think I got my money's worth, but I highly advise against buying this at anything but a severe discount.

The music is good, but not as part of the game. I can highly recommend getting the OST, but not the game. The flight controls are fine. That's the best things I can say about this game.

I can kinda see what the game is going for, but it's not working. Every mission has some gimmick or another. The amount of instantaneous fail states is extremely punishing, and checkpoints in missions are very badly paced.
Allied units are useless in combat, and the player has to solve every little issue. Just as an example: I left a single helicopter enemy surrounded by ~10 allied air and ground units. The allies lost, stating that they were "surrounded" and had to surrender.
The game tries to make the player feel like some one-man army, but it only makes allies seem like incompetent idiots.

The difficulty curve is also very harsh. By mission 6, the player either has to be a masterful pilot, grind prior missions for better equipment, or use DLC jets.

Missions often feature hazards, which is fine, but they stack them too much. One of the early missions requires flying in an area with thin, high mountains, while fighting the strong winds in the valleys, and having to react to randomly getting struck by lightning, all while trying to kill an opponent that is far more agile than the player's planes could ever be. Two or three of these things would make for a fun challenge, but all four just lead to frustration.

The onboarding process of Ace Combat 7 is very, very weak, not even teaching the player that they have a machine gun on their plane. I found this out on mission 18, by checking the controller layout.

I love the Ace Combat series but was bummed out about the features of the game. I really wanted to love it but just didn't. I don't play multiplayer but was expecting a immersive single player arcade experience. Unfortunately the game was a disappointment with the limited time I had with it. For example:

No Ultrawide support:
I got it working using the github easy but sad to see no native support.

Canopy:
Wet effects look like white dots that show up instantly compared to Project Wingman water effects which slowly accumulates and streak transparently. Also the FOV in the canopy is really small.

Sound:
I like to turn down the BGM to zero so I can hear the sound of fighter, guns spraying, missiles firing, systems locking on, planes exploding, and the radio transmission. But most of the sound was really quiet and muffed. I was really surprised there was no sonic boom or the effect after breaking the sound barrier at 700mph. I was also surprised there was no boom sound when going head to head with an enemy fighter jet and passing it extremely close. 

CONTROLS:
This is what caused me to refund the game. I use Battlefield controls: joysticks for all movement and throttle so I can use my triggers for gun and missiles. I do this so I can adjust and sustain the angle of attack. I only play with expert controls since Ace Combat 5 and I use my guns 90% of the time compared to my missiles because of the immersion. This is how I like to play. But the gun play for the planes are not great. The crosshairs keeps flicking back and fourth too fast which makes it hard to adjust. I prefer the Project Wingman's gun play that depends of positioning and angle, and shooting ahead of the target. Project Wingman's crosshair does not snap back into the middle of the screen unlike AC7.

Overall I really wanted to play the campaign and enjoy it's story but the immersion and controls is what disappointment me because I expected from a triple A game for the quality compared to a indie dev team for Project Wingman. I hope to see AC8 with these features. Razgriz out!

I am not a real war game fan or an aircraft fan. I had flown aircrafts in the Grand Theft Auto games or Just Cause 2 or 3 but you do not have to be an aircraft expert or a huge fan of it to love this game. It's one for everyone. 
First of all, the epic music is creating a cinematic Hollywood atmosphere. It gives power to your heart to beat faster. Furthermore, the cut scenes between the missions are also amazing. So the biggest mistake during playing this game you can make is to skip the cut scenes. They are the half, while the missions are the other half of Ace Combat 7. Yes, sometimes they are a liitle bit long but you just have to consider them as a movie and you will love it.
In conclusion: Do you like epic cinematic movies? Do you like epic music (e.g. Hans Zimmer or John WIlliams)? And do you like to feel the freedom. It does not matter if you like to feel the freedom of the streets, the freedom of the skies or the freedom of open world games. If you just like the feeling of beeing free, this game is one for you. Play it and enjoy the freedom of the skies, the cinematic cut scenes, the epic background music, the complex story of allies,  alliances, enemies, tactical actions in a modern war with tanks, the ugly sides of wars and of course the amount of different aircrafts from different companies and countries.

This is primarily a review of the campaign. 

While the core gameplay is okay (not much different over previous iterations for better or for worse), the campaign is astonishingly bad. I don't mean the writing, which is delightfully cheesy and awkward, as is the voice acting. But while a handful of the missions are fun, the bulk are tedious and frustrating. It's like they deliberately set out to design missions that take the fun out of flying a classic combat aircraft into battle. Hope you enjoy destroying ground targets under a tight time constraint, because that's the bulk of what you'll be doing. 

Whether it's lightning strikes causing your plane's electricals to malfunction, or random gusts of wind pushing your plane sidways into rock formations, or sandstorms or IFF malfunctions rendering your radar useless, it seems that the campaign is designed to make air combat feel like aggravating busy-work. I get that there's a need to have variety in missions, but the frustrating part is that every once in a while you get a fun mission thrown your way, requiring some trick flying or having to mark targets for bombers. Then the game stumbles over itself to throw in some monkey wrench into the whole thing which instead of enhancing the experience by providing a new challenge just frustrates the whole experience.

One of the best game in the franchise and highly recommend, especially if it is on sale and it does go on sale quite often. Bought the Top Gun Maverick DLC and the F-14 definitely helps in campaign mode. Whether you’re a rookie or a veteran, I highly suggest you give it a shot.

Pros: 

- Most likely the best fighter game ever 
- Better graphics than previous Ace Combat titles. Flying through clouds has a nice condensation effect on the cockpit, facing the sun will blind you, missiles can unlock while target flies through clouds, getting struck by lightning blurs your HUD. Play on a wider screen, not the Steamdeck if you want to enjoy it
- Very challenging campaign. It can take a couple of tries for certain missions. Obtaining S rank is also a little harder than in previous games. It can be a little frustrating to learn expert controls if it is your first time but don’t give up!
- Story is intriguing, it takes place in the Strangereal, the cutscenes are made to reflect the atmosphere in preparation to each mission but dialogue could be worked on a little more. Some conversations sound a bit flat.
- Many DLCs including experimental aircrafts from previous games with crazy special weapons to obliterate and conquer. 
- Interface is nice and clean, soundtrack is fire like always. Charge Assault and Daredevil are my favorites (Thank you Kobayashi!)
- Brings you back core memories (Stonehenge, Farbanti, basically invading Erusea again)
- Great variety of mission style: Obtain X points in a time limit, Escort an ally, Destroy refueling platforms, Fly through a tunnel, small and gigantic targets to take out etc... (you will need a variety of aircrafts to fulfill each mission like air-to-air or air-to-ground) This is what makes the game more dynamic, you can’t beat with only one loadout
- Great number of drones to shoot down in a gigantic furball. It can be annoying at first but just get to the 8AAM and you should be fine
- Customization is nice, wish they had some more skins but there are many emblems/nicknames to compensate. Named Aces require some work to spawn them, but hey that skin is worth it right? 

Cons: 

- Multiplayer is dead. If you want to play PVP, you’ll have more luck on PS4. The most lobbies I have seen so far is 2-3, or am I doing something wrong, and that is during the peak hours (10AM EST, no idea why). Multiplayer needs a make over as you can simply get shot down instantly by someone with a top tier load out.  Also no cross platform play
- Definitely not a game with realistic physics, but that’s what all AC players should know by now. Speed is through the roof
- Anything above Normal difficulty is trivial, they need to make it more difficult/aggressive
- Kinda wish they added few more planes in the vanilla game like the F-117 or the AV-8B one day. No Chinese planes, probably due to legal and political reasons
- No way to modify the controls in the game as I was used to old games mechanics on PS2
- The game crashed for me a few times. I suspect my GPU takes a huge hit and had to lower the settings (currently with an RX480)
- No wingmen control like in AC5 or AC0 
- Story is linear, no choice of missions like in AC5
- They need to add Danger Zone to their soundtrack

All in all, if you are an AC veteran: Buy it
If you are a Top Gun Maverick fan: Buy it
Newbie? Just buy it

The campaign is 20 missions, it took me about 3 game sessions to finish it. I loved my experience with this game. 

What I like is how the campaign can be fought using your favorite aircraft, my Rafale kept being good even till the final mission.

I didn't realize you can make a game about fighter jets not fun.
Prepare to be engaging ground targets 80% of the game, while being on a timer. Anything except bombers/multirole fighters seems useless in campaign.

The hardest boss in the game is [spoiler]not crashing into the ceiling in the final mission[/spoiler]. Every other encounter is just endless flying in circles with the missile alarm going off in the cockpit.

Also as many mentioned, no flight stick buttons remapping. On a Logitech X52, high-G turns end up on the stick body button, forcing you to hold the stick in a very awkward position that makes your hand hurt after a while.

I'm just happy it's over.

Not entirely sure why people enjoy this series so much. You can't use TrackIR with it, so using a Joystick is pointless. Using a gamepad isn't fun for Flight Simulators. They have some sort of flight dynamic where there isn't gravity, but there kinda is. You'll fly completely stable as long as your wings are level, but if you roll at all there is just the slightest bit of pull towards the earth. Really difficult to get used to it, and precise movements required to get guns on target are extremely difficult. Especially with how 30g are considered the upper end of what's humanly possible in this game's lore, the enemy just dances around and pulls out of your sight... Can you imagine that? 30 times the force of gravity.. Jeez.. I really don't recommend this if you are used to actual Flight Sims. If you're a hard-core DCS player, forget it. All in all I have to say, play Project Wingman instead. It offers a lot more in gameplay and aircraft variety, and setting up TrackIR for it is a hell of a lot simpler(I never managed to get it working for AceCombat, with the 50 step tutorials you need to go through)

I've bought this game 3 times so far, including all the DLC. It's worth every penny. While the game exhibits the occasional bit of weirdness it successfully escaped development hell and ended up being a true follow-up to the PS2-era Holy Trilogy of Ace Combat 04, 5 and 0. The callbacks are a joy if you've been with the franchise for its 28 years, but even if you've never heard of the series before the controls are perfected, the soundtrack slaps. Torres is a truly deranged but excellent villain. The Stonehenge Defensive - releasing 17 years after the Stonehenge Offensive in AC04 - is a masterpiece.

This is easily one of the best Ace Combat games I've had the pleasure of playing. Personally, I rate this game among the original trilogy. The singleplayer story in this game is fantastic and provides a fair amount of replayability. However, if you're getting this game for its multiplayer then I would not recommend it. The multiplayer servers are practically dead for the most part, and if you are lucky to find a match, hope that you don't find one of the many hackers that unfortunately plague this game. Don't get me wrong, the multiplayer is fun if you either play in private lobbies with friends or you manage to find a match without hackers, however, the main focus of most Ace Combat games has never really been about the multiplayer, but rather the singleplayer. I absolutely recommend this game for its singleplayer alone, although I would only recommend buying it if there is a sale as there is not much else other than the story that you can really do at this point.
Edit: After playing through all the DLC missions I can easily recommend them to anyone wanting more story. The multiplayer is still very dead though.

It was fun at first but the constant cliche & cringey banter over the radio between your useless AI squadmates gets annoying fast, and after zoning them out I missed a couple mission updates only to see "MISSION FAILED" because I wasn't paying attention. The missions got repetitive fast, and after trying the 14th mission I uninstalled it. Why? [spoiler]Well first, you have to fly through a canyon at low altitude and avoid spotlights. Sounds fun, until you magically get spotted at the end and have to go all the way back. Then it's a constant back-and-forth between it being dark & rainy and too bright because of the spotlights shining directly at you. Having to destroy all targets in the landing zone means you need to do some strafing runs until a hill previously obscured by the glare of a spotlight appears out of nowhere and you crash[/spoiler]. After 6 attempts I finally managed to get everything done only for the game to freeze just before debriefing.

Mission 12 was another annoying one towards the end as [spoiler]you are tasked with destroying the propellers on an Arsenal Bird. The problem? A constant swarm of drones getting in the way of your ability to lock on to the propellers along with a never ending stream of missiles from said drones hammering on you, all made worse with a 2 minute timer.[/spoiler]

If you like repetitive missions with useless banter between helpless AI overshadowing the sound effects, music, and helpful dialog, then give it a shot. I personally don't see myself playing this game, or another AC game, ever again.

They use references from Ace Combat 5 to make this seem interesting. Which means they used fan nostalgia to gain interest. Which has seemed to work, except that's literally all it is

They had an interesting story setup, and that's what got me into it. Then by the end it makes literally no sense.

You have like 20 planes hovering over, let's just call it the Ark Bird. Guess what those other 20 planes do? Nothing

Once you take down the unmanned fighters they just hover above the ark bird, and maybe on occasion fire a missile that does nothing. Worse, they muck up your radar. So while the arkbird is firing a bajillion missiles at you that can flip around, and are better than qaam missiles, you can't see them on your radar when there's 20 planes that aren't being targeted by said missiles sitting there

Better, your supposed to do all these maneuvers and such to take it down whilst, again, you have all these planes to help you where we could just shoot it with missiles to kill it. But oh no I forgot it has a shield that...doesn't get used again during your battle with it.

Better yet, right after, a girl randomly decides, I'll jump off this really high spot, and it's fine cause I have a parachute. Why is she jumping you ask? We don't know. All we do know is she gets shot out of the sky by one of these new unmanned fighters that was supposed to not be produced by doing the same mission you just did. Why they shoot her in midair is also not explained.

It's a random set of events that continues to get dumber and dumber as you go on.

And oh, when those two planes appear, the mission just ends. We just for some reason leave to land on this random aircraft carrier, that just happens to have the admirals name from the last game on it, as well as apparently (quoting the game) a buttload of planes, which makes me think of ww2's aircraft carrier to hit Japan. And that is the only time I've seen that.

This...made no sense

Oh, and the Ace pilot you fight against through the game that you fight literally in the beginning for some reason, he just randomly shows up at one point, you shoot him down, and that's it for that story with him. No interest increased in the story, nothing. Biggest villain, just gone.

You don't even know why your playing at that point except for gameplay. Except once you do the next mission you encounter Mary Sue levels of dumbness and really story to question if it's worth it to do the possibly last level

This was my first Jet game and I really enjoyed it!

Set in an Earth-like world but featuring real jet planes, the game is a great 'arcade' game as opposed to a simulator.

The main story features 20 missions plus 3 dlc missions and enemies comprise both air and ground targets. Aside from standard missiles the player can utilise a wide array of special weapons and plane parts that act as perks before starting the mission.

Missions are varied, sometimes its pure dogfights, sometimes you have to use a particular weapon to destroy certain ground targets, sometimes you have to fly through valleys or avoid radar detection circles and sometimes you have to destroy a set number of targets in a given time.

There are 4 difficulty levels, and admittedly once the player has become accustom to the game the challenge really comes from a few 'boss fights' in which the AI makes for difficult dog fights especially on Ace difficulty.

The story was fairly interesting however the soundtrack is honestly one of my favourite aspects of the game.

Multiplayer is still somewhat active as of writing this however you will need to arrange times with other players if you want to play team death match as opposed to regular death match. 

Multiplayer is fun however unforgiving to new players who do not yet have the best parts to attach to their plane, this along with the fact that some of the best planes and special weapons are locked behind DLC adds an unfortunate imbalance to the experience.

Overall I would recommend it both to people who enjoy jet games and newcomers like me.

It's fun yeah, but I've since played Project Wingman, and PW is FAR superior to this game, let me elaborate.
In AC7, there are basically no options besides graphics and control scheme, there's no FOV or camera options, which is very important in a dogfighting game. The camera is stiff and weird in AC7, and the FOV is way too low, (It can be changed with Cheat Engine, but it's a pretty big hassle.) 
The missions in this game are good, mostly, there are annoying "Protect the character who can't defend themselves!" missions, there are some missions where you can't tell which plane is on which side, and those suck. Overall I don't enjoy the missions in this game.
Now I'm gonna talk about Project Wingman, and why you should purchase it instead of AC7.
The aforementioned problem with settings in AC7 is removed in PW, you have FOV sliders for 1st and 3rd person you have more settings for your controls, even a War Thunder style mouse control thing, which I love, there are options for everything that AC7 neglected.
The camera in PW is absolutely wonderful, especially with the War Thunder controls, and helps you to realize just how bad AC7's camera is.
The petty missions in AC7 aren't present in PW, you don't have to deal with your teammates getting themselves into trouble and have to do everything over again. In fact, you don't have to worry about your team at all, they just sit there and take out some aircraft for you. 
Final note on PW, Prez is awesome, 'nuff said.

Conclusion.
AC7 is pretty sick, and I do recommend it, but PW is just a better experience.

Honestly, im mixed on this game. On one hand, the game play is incredible, the art design is beautiful, and the story has great moments that I'm never going to forget. On the other hand, certain gimmicks for levels don't really add anything and are negligible at most and sometimes downright annoying at worst. I think the best one (imo ofc) happens late game after a certain event, and really played well with the tone of the story. Another fun one is the canyon run, just a really good concept that's challenging but also one of the most satisfying. However, wind mechanics, lightning, and sandstorms really only feel like they drag out a standard mission for too long and are just not very fun to play around with. Another element is the story, and i'll be honest if you haven't played any Ace Combat games or know any of the lore of the games, your going to spend the majority of the game confused. It doesn't help that 2 separate factions on different continents but in the same faction hold the name Osea and Usea and operate closely with each other. I didn't realize they were different factions until my second playthrough, though then again I'm not exactly a paragon of intelligence. The story overall suffers from this, which is a real shame since the actual message and narrative are very interesting and thought provoking. What does stick the landing though will be enough to invest you and keep involvement until the very end. The actual gameplay sections of the game are incredibly fun, and man are the bossfights a good challenge to overcome. Overall, while flawed, this campaign is still a blast and I would recommend checking it out.
As for the multiplayer, its a pretty mixed bag. Theres only 2 gamemodes, TDM and BR. Its pretty shallow in this aspect, and I'm sure a few extra gamemodes would have really increased the variety and overall enjoyment, such as a VIP or eliminate objectives on the enemy team, which would give more utility to the wide sandbox of aircraft. As it stands now, if you arn't running at least a 4.5 generation fighter with QAAM's SASM's, HCAA's, or Lazers, your gonna have a bad time. Theres nothing to mix up the objectives from simply kill other players, so obviously people only use the weapons that most efficiently kill players. At the same time though if you've got some buddies to spar against, this can be a really good time. The community as a whole isn't very toxic, and matchmaking in short bursts can be a good time.
TLDR: Campaign is flawed but fun, multiplayer is difficult to get into but with friends is very fun. I hope this review helped out

[i] An arcade-like, fast paced piloting game with a multitude of things to do & jets to fly. Although it has it's flaws, I'd say it's a must have for all piloting enthusiasts! [/i]

If you're a hardcore aviation gamer, or just a newcomer who's looking to get introduced to the field of flight, this game is a must-have. Do note, though, that ace combat 7 has more of an arcade like flight system, and doesn't introduce much realism to the game. If you're looking for realism, I'd recommend [url=https://www.xbox.com/en-US/games/microsoft-flight-simulator?ef_id=_k_Cj0KCQjwj_ajBhCqARIsAA37s0y1KhCXo1A92PybiwfpqUU5YBmH_Z28cR_c6f3aWhyFnNgyuixz3zwaAtEtEALw_wcB_k_&OCID=AIDcmmiixzwwab_SEM__k_Cj0KCQjwj_ajBhCqARIsAA37s0y1KhCXo1A92PybiwfpqUU5YBmH_Z28cR_c6f3aWhyFnNgyuixz3zwaAtEtEALw_wcB_k_&gad=1&gclid=Cj0KCQjwj_ajBhCqARIsAA37s0y1KhCXo1A92PybiwfpqUU5YBmH_Z28cR_c6f3aWhyFnNgyuixz3zwaAtEtEALw_wcB] Microsoft Flight Simulator [/url].

Although, it's price is pretty heavy, so if you don't have any extra cash and need to budget, I wouldn't recommend getting this game until you truly feel like you could benefit from it - or you have earned enough cash for it not to affect your real life.

I bought this on a whim seeing as i have never played a flying sim before and i gotta say as a newcomer it was extremely fun, i really feel like the game HAS to be played with the original controls to be really enjoyed as losing yourself while dog fighting at 360 degree angles is only experienced in this mode and learning how to fly has a pretty big learning curve and dog fighting even more but discovering every small technique that give you an edge during fights is extremely enjoyable. 

Apart from gameplay the story ive heard has always been infamous and compared to MGS in terms of cutscene length, its certainly similar but they lack any enjoyment in terms of character and dialogue, they're mostly a bore which help setup some context with whats happening during the war and why. they're also followed by briefings that can go on for a while, i found myself skipping the cut-scenes after watching the start of them as that was enough to understand what was happening but they are mostly disconnected from what you're doing the game, the briefings whoever held my attention better.

i usually dont write reviews, but my experience in ace combat 7 has compelled me to write one. you see, ac7 is like a movie, that once you finished it, you wish that you could forget it and re watch it again. same thing applies to this game. the story, the gameplay, the soundtrack, its simply beautiful. this is one of the more memorable games that i have played, rivaling that of skyrim or farcry 5(dont judge me), before getting it, i thought constantly staying in the air would be boring, but the action and the amount of things you can do in a mission is just insane. unfortunately,  the amount of time you can spend on the missions is underwhelming. i could finish it in a day. the game offers 3 extra dlc missions which take place during the campaign.overall, ace combat 7 is on of the best and most memorable games that i have ever played. hoping to see ace combat 8 soon. get it, you wont regret it.

I Love You, Colonel Sanders! A Finger Lickin' Good Dating Simulator is a dating sim developed by Psyop. The video game was commissioned by the restaurant chain KFC and released for free on Steam on September 24, 2019.[1][2] A parody of conventional dating sims, the primary objective of the player is to develop a romantic relationship with a fictionalized version of KFC's founder Colonel Sanders, portrayed as an attractive classmate at a cooking school.[2]

The release of the game follows the reintroduction of Colonel Sanders into KFC's marketing campaigns in 2015, and is part of the company's strategy to make the Colonel a "part of pop culture", reimagining the historical figure for modern times.[3][4] The game successfully received public attention due to the "can-you-believe-it" premise both before and after the game's release.[5]

Played through the game blind, finished it in around 16 hours
Did I have a blast? Yes. Yes I did, it was so, so worth the money, even if I bought the game on sale
The story is really amazing, bright and all sunshine and rainbows, however, it takes a quite dark turn into a lot more depressing setting.
You can buy planes (with in-game currency, shocker) (in game currency is easy to get, no real world paying), but not just randomly, because it's all an aircraft tree, so if you want a shiny F-35C, you'd also have to get some other planes, which are all worth.
I kind of recommend finding a way to record your gameplay, just to see how you flew your planes when you started, and how you fly your planes when you finish the game

Slight spoilers ahead:
Story starts at a low skill, enemies are easy to maneuver around and kill. Then a twist happens, skill ceiling goes a tiny bit higher, and your character is at a low point in this career. You then gain more popularity for your skill and become a well known and liked ace pilot.

Once you finally finish the game, you can restart the story with all the things you have unlocked, so if you want to fight barely flying planes with your high-end, futuristic jet, go ahead. 
Once you finish a mission, you can replay the mission on a different difficulty, or in free flight, which is a very neat option because it just spawns you in the map, with no enemies or missions

TLDR: Game good, buy if you can and want.

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.
