Normally I don't write reviews, but ... Ace Combat got my attention because of the funny drum game and the few Ace Combat themes in there, just like another namco game i've played before *cofcofScarletNexuscofcof*. My favorite was Roca Roja, and I heavily considered playing this game because I heard more of its soundtrack and fell in love with it.
... Buuuut I never actually bought it because I couldn't really afford it, and there were more games that I had already saved up for (latin american struggles).
Fast forward lots of months, I'm talking with a friend ... And she asks me if I want this plane game (big thanks to her. Of course I said yes because hell, I listen to the soundtrack every once in a while and I LOVE it. 
I start playing this game, she gives me a few tips (I only listened to like half of them - that's why I play on expert now !) and ... I start making quick progress on the game.
Look, I *know* that 12.4 hours don't say a lot sometimes, but ... I am obsessed with this game now. Not even a week has passed since I played for the first time and I'm a really busy guy.
I'm really into this game's story and I think I'm in love with Trigger's character. I also like the gameplay A LOT and I'm currently on mission ...13, I think.
This game has given me a few headaches but I don't really care. It's stunning ! It's a really nice experience, this game made my old special interest with weaponry and planes rise up again and it makes me happy.
Hell, this had such a huge impact in me that I now dream of PLANES ! And I ... Also hear "Caution ! Pull up !" in my mind a lot .... It's still nice tho.
It may have a LOT of objectives but shooting them down is real fun.

After all of this I can only say ... I like this funni plane game a lot. I'm really thankful for such an amazing game and soundtrack, the devs did an amazing job - shoutout to them !!! It's evident that this game was made with lots of love. Truly an amazing experience. :>

Compared to other games in the series, 7 has a couple of pretty bad stages and the bosses don't quite manage to live up to the high standards set by some older games (Aigaion, Morgan, Orishina), but it's still overall one of the better games in the series. It's really just too bad that 6 isn't on PC.

I bought the complete edition on my Xbox originally and wanted to experience on my PC as well so I picked up the complete edition again on Steam. I love this game, and my biggest complaint is that I wish it were longer. You will probably put about 15-18 hours into the campaign if you've never played it before, and can beat it in 10. The DLC missions are longer than the campaign ones by a pretty substantial amount.
Everyone shits on the story and I think that's fair. The world building doesn't really exist and the characters are basically one note but it isn't offensively bad, just a bit boring.
I would say that I love it enough to buy it again but I've already bought it twice and beaten it 4 times total. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has even a passing interest in arcade flight gaming.

ACE COMBAT 7 is Modern ART

The story, the gameplay, the soundtrack and music and the graphics, everything are in place. I just don't know what to say.

I'm a 26 yrs old salary man surrounded by gamer friends who spends more time on different titles than me, At this point in life, I am very burnt out of gaming, most titles just doesn't get to the point where I would play til the end of the game anymore. But ACE COMBAT 7 is a different story, Gaming is now fun again after roaming the unknown skies.

Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown has to be the most well crafted arcade air assault game ever made. I highly recommend turning on expert flight controls as the default controls in the game are far different than previous Ace Combat entries. I think playing without expert controls is like playing DOOM without the ASD keys, it's extremely limiting. Without flight controls, your aircraft can't roll or really make those high G zero turns.

I can't wait for an Ace Combat 8, been playing these games since I was a little kid. The story can drag on a little in place, the narrator goes on for far too long in some cut scenes, but all in all, it was a very fun experience for me. It was also really cool to get updated on aircraft that's been developed over recent years and how far along certain prototypes are. Of course, with Top Gun 2's release, I was rocking the skins and finding myself saying stupid cheesy lines from the movie. 

I think one other area of improvement would be to allow the controls more free-flow during replays after missions, other than that, I think the game is pretty damn good. It's not technical enough like a virtual simulator, but it's technical enough to make you feel like an accomplished ace pilot.

Like the Previous Ace Combat games before it, AC7 Is an absolute blast to play. With a great story, Dialogue, And gameplay, It is a masterpiece that in terms of gameplay, I would consider 10/10, For this review however I gave it an 8/10 for one reason- Price. The game is coming on five years now, And it is still being sold for 60$, And thats BEFORE any DLC which can easily make the price jump to over 120$. In my third playthrough, I did hard mode and a No-Hit challenge for the entire campaign, And even with this difficulty the time it took for me to finish it was about 10 hours over a few days. While it is an absolutely lovely game, I personally would only recommend waiting until a Sale to get it for a little cheaper as 60$ for the base game 7-8ish hours of campaign gameplay is in my opinion a little too pricey.

Anyways today I will be discussing Ace Combat Lore
So several million years before the dawn of man,
(That is technically where the lore starts)
So The Ulysses asteroid
which is real
Does a funny dance and leaves the orbit of jupiter
Some smart person with a telescope looks at it and goes "Yeah that'll fuck up our shit"
So as a sane and normal response, the Osean Federation (The U.S. but Japan) decides to build Stonehenge
A twelve piece, rotating multi targeting anti-aesteroid Railgun Artillery emplacement in the middle of the desert
It's supposed to be able to cover the entirety of the expected Ulysses impact zone
About a year after the discovery of Stonehenge, a country called belka snaps
Belka was basically Germany
Their economy went to shit
Lost a bunch of money
Sold territory
Trying to survive
Some territories vy for independence
One, Ustio, is supported by Osea
Who is the US
After becoming independent, Ustio finds a SHITTON of resources
Ace Combat is Japanese, so the Japanese perception of erica
All the cool freedom shit none of the bad
So Belka, a country renowned for their air force, says fuck it
They proceed to invade anyone they can
This includes Ustio
This is where the events of AC take place
Ustio hires Galm Team, two mercenary pilots
Galm 1, Cipher, and Galm 2, Pixy
(There are 16 Ace Combats)
(7 mainline)
8 actually
5 is my fave
7 is great tho
Anyway so Galm 1 and 2 proceed to wreck shit
Ustio goes from being almost completely overrun to fine in like 2 months
Then the Allied States (Ustio and Osea and everyone but Belka) push into belka
Then Belka decides to do a power move
They whip out their giant fucking laser
BECAUSE THEY HAVE AN ANTI-ICBM LASER
Built during the Osea-Yuktobania Cold War
This is 1995
It's called Excalibur and it's bigger than most buildings
Of course, this is after busting like 18 megastructures
Anyway so Galm Team attacks and destroys Stonehenge
Then they go to this nice little town called hoffnung
No wait shit Excalibur not Stonehenge
Hoffnung is a little industrial city
So Galm Team gets sent in to escort some prescion bombers
Except sike they aren't precise
And they don't mean to
So the city gets whacked
The Belkans go "Oh Shit"
And, as a perfectly normal response
They burn the rest of it down without evacuating civilians
So Galm 1, Pixy, gets the sad
So pixy, your wingman, is lagging behind as you get sent to another mission
He's sad
OUT OF NOWHERE
Belkan bombers "headed for Ustio" armed with WMD's are spotted
You get sent to intercept
Cipher shoots down all the bombers because
And then Belka calls everyone a bitch and shoot themselves in the liver
BY NUKING 7 OF THEIR OWN, UNOCCUPIED, CITIES
TO CREATE A BORDER
Northern Belka is basically switzerland
With a nuke border
So in the confusion, Pixy goes
"Fuck this"
And tries to shoot down Cipher before fleeing
Belka just kinda disintegrates after nuking themselves
They get their shit rocked
BUT NOT BEFORE THEY USE A GIANT PLANE
THE XB-0
Imagine if someone tied a US military base together, wrapped it in Armour, and slapped wings on the bitch
That
It's being defended by Espada Squadron
Who are from Sapin (shitty spain)
But Sapin's fighting Belka
So it turns out that due to the war there's now this Massive Terrorist Organization thats full of fed up soldiers from everywhere and like the entire belkan military
Anyway so they're gonna nuke the whole world with a super MIRV
Because Posadism
They hate borders
And wanna reset the world
So Cipher goes to destroy the launch facility
Which is a dam for some reason
And they do
But SIKE
Pixy's here and he wants to kill you
He's got this dope new plane called the Morgan
Shit's got Lazers, Pocket nukes, and an ECM system so powerful that it can jam bullets
So Pixy launches the big fuck
And Cipher has to shoot him down from the front because the jet intakes are the only weakness
And pixy gets his shit rocked and the nuke gets fucked
Detonates mid air and somehow is fine
Anyway so in 1997 they realize the Ulysses Asteroid is hollow
Turns out it's range is doubled
Yuktobania (USSR) decides to also build a bigass railgun, the Chandelier
Because Stonehenge now can't protect everyone
The country of Eursea (kinda modern russia) builds a shitton of bunkers
Yeah impact is doubled
Thats game 1 of like 5
Oh shit I forgot the Civilian murder
Anyway
So the estimated impact now covers the continent of Osea
Eurusea tries to build Megalith, an Anti-Asteroid ICBM launch silo, but it's not finished in time
So in 1999, the Ulysses Asteroid Enters Earth's atmosphere and begins to break apart
Loads of chunks fall to the earth
The ones that would land in empty areas are ignored, while Stonehenge attempts to shoot down every asteroid heading for a populated area
Bad News - A sizable chunk is headed towards Farbanti, the Capital of Erusea
Stonehenge gun 7 goes to shoot it down
40 seconds before firing, turret 7 is knocked offline by an asteroid
The Chunk slams into one of the most populated parts of Farbanti
The crater creates "The Sunken District"
Oh yeah and Osea was fine
Cause Erusea and Stonehenge are on the Continent of Usea, but Osea itself is vibin on also Osea
So Basically Erusea decides "Fuck It" and goes to war with the ISAF
(Independent State Allied Forces)
So as a first strike, in 2003, Erusea takes Stonehenge in a surprise attack
Some erusean Genius goes "Hey guys you know this 1km long anti-asteroid railgun that shoots at like mach 7? What if we pointed it at planes?"
And so they do
Basically gaining Continental Air Superiority overnight
ISAF flips their shit
Erusea bad
So ISAF GHQ and any survivors from the entire continent regroup on North Point
Which is Britain but somehow worse
Anyway ISAF are getting their shit rocked
So Erusea decides to finish this and sends over a wing of strategic bombers to wipe ISAF GHQ off the map
But they're intercepted by an ISAF pilot
Mobius 1
The only member of the 118th Tactical fighter wing
Anyway Mobius 1 proceeds to wreck shit
ISAF then mounts a series of offensives to destroy Erusean Logistics
And then the Aegir Fleet, which is this big ass fleet the eruseans have
Anyway so Mobius 1 destroys several small countries worth of infrastructure
Then they mount an offensive on the Aegir Fleet, which can't move cause they blew up all the fuel
And they wipe it off the map
Also after this mission there's a cutscene where the pilots sing the ISAF National Anthem for like 20 seconds
It has a Voice Actor you never hear before or again
It's suspected to be Mobius 1
Anyway Mobius 1 keeps wrecking shit
No just a pilot
Apparently a rookie too
The only one to either A.) Survive Stonehenge out of a wing of other pilots, or B.) Be the only pilot sent to an entire wing
Yeah Mobius 1 is player Character
Anyway Mobius 1 does some more Pilot shit, and eventually is sent to destroy Stonehenge
Which works
And Mobius 1 is sent to singlehandedly defend two defecting passanger planes who Erusea is trying to shoot down
Basically ISAF rocks Eruseas shit
After the Battle of Farbanti, Erusea surrenders
But these cool and hip Erusean Zoomer Officers decide to be wacky
They decide to use the (just finished) Megalith
So Mobius 1 is sent to destroy it
In the only way Ace Combat knows how
A tunnel run
4, actually
so, from where I left off
Mobius 1 destroys Megalith (which has a pog theme)
and established peace forever
anyway 5 years later there's another war
This time Its between Yuktobania and Osea
Before the war, Yuktobania and Osea were working on the Arkbird project
which is a Space Station but it's a plane
anyway so a Yuktobanian SR-71 is spotted over Sand Island
The Wardog Squadron of Sand Island is sent to intercept
A Yuke Squadron is sent to intercept them
They fight but both nations cover it up
Wardog Squadron is then sent to disable a Yuke spyboat
Oh yeah Wardog are all rookies except for the captain because everyone else got ganked by Unidentifed Aircraft
The Yukes defend the spyboat and shoot down the captain

Ace Combat 7 fulfils a power fantasy I didn't know I had-- hero of the skies, ace pilot. You'll feel like a badass every second you're in the cockpit of a plane.

It's a stupidly fun game with a high skill ceiling for those who stick around long enough and want to get invested in the game's systems, but simple enough that you can dive in without knowing anything beforehand. 

The story is a sort of Metal Gear Lite political drama with a cast of fun characters that are all pretty well voice acted, and while the dialogue is a little hammy, it's by no means a bad thing. 

Also, this game's music goes fucking HARD. Everywhere. All the time. It's fantastic.

My two biggest criticisms would be that the main currency is kind of hard to gain for like, 90% of the main campaign, so you won't have a lot of freedom to unlock a huge variety of planes and weapons to try them all out without a bit of grinding, and that the game itself is pretty short-- only 20 chapters excluding the DLC. I'd absolutely still recommend picking up both on as big of a sale as you can find.

I like the game. It is an arcade air fighter simulator. My observations: (1) Spraying dozens of enemies with missiles is a good fun. Solid gameplay. (2) The flight physics are not realistic but that is not the point of this game. (3) The story is average, peppered with some pseudo-spiritual undertones, which are quite common in movie/games productions from Far East. (4) The single-player campaign is very short. I finished the game in 11 hours and I don't find this acceptable.
TLDR; Fun game but very short. Only buy when discounted.

First time ever playing an Ace Combat game, although I've played similar types of games. In the sense of an arcadey type airforce game. But this was my first time with a joystick and throttle. (X56 HOTAS Logitech) 

The game is quite fun, once you work the controls and such out, get them down pat. And able to execute them quickly and effortlessly, missions are a breeze. Some missions require more braincells to work out you should favour an ATG jet opposed to an ATA jet. 

As well as sometimes needing to line a shot up/missile up to hit a target properly. 

But there only issues/things I would say that are more or less negative/make the game feel unfair:

On Point missions (You need to accumulate enough points to pass) You have a return line, this is sick. But sometimes the mission quickly goes from focusing on ground targets to dealing with swarms of Air Targets, if you are like me, and have very few aircrafts at hand, which are multi-role and can do both ATA/ATG effectively. (Either with multiple lock ons/bombs) then it becomes a case of trying to unlock aircrafts which are a middle ground, or simply buying a DLC plane to get really powerful weapons.
(They should give an option to pick a backup jet, on these missions so you can plan ahead, have a main ground attacking jet, then if the mission changes and jets swarm in, you can hit the return line, swap jets and continue on)

The controls for joystick are not clear. This really isn't a lot game devs can do, other than try to update to keep ontop of the new Joysticks/Throttles published by big brands (Logitech/Thrustmaster etc) so players have an easier time learning the controls and not be like me, where I realised the rudder control to go left/right whilst at a flat level, is to twist the throttle. 

Overall, a good 15 hours of fun.

This is obviously a popular title mostly from fans of the franchise.  For someone new to the franchise I agree with what most of the players who did not recommend this game are saying.  For someone who is mostly PC this wont be the game for you.  It is a bad conversion from a console game.  These have been mentioned by others but mentioning it again here.
-No mouse support at all
-Buttons shown in some of the menus are from a console controller so you have to guess which keys to push
-No joystick support (other than the one they sell)
-If you can get a different joystick or Hotas to work through hacks and what not you have to guess which buttons do what since there is no way to set them up the way you like - even if you have the expected joystick there is zero button customization
-The controls are designed for a console controller so using a joystick setup doesn't feel at all natural and you have to completely relearn how to fly compared to any other flight game
-It sort of has a stall feature that really doesn't do anything and doesn't make sense since you cant go slower than 600 knots despite having the throttle at zero
-You cant skip dialog even if you have done the mission previously and some of it is long
-No co-op
-In the missions not all enemies are red on the mini map so while you are chasing a red target someone that looks like a friendly comes up behind you and starts shooting.

The fact that they put zero effort into converting this to PC with no joystick or hotas support and still charging for a full price game is disappointing and an obvious money grab.  That and the flying just doesn't feel right.  Perhaps its too arcade style for what I'm looking for.  
Conveniently for the developers its obviously worked.  Video game players sometimes are too hardcore and will put up with a lot because they are fans of a franchise.
Will be requesting a refund as I have no such attachments to this franchise and now know its not for a PC player.

I bought the "ACE COMBAT™ 7: SKIES UNKNOWN - TOP GUN: Maverick Ultimate Edition" for 19,99€ while it was on sale.
And for that price I can recommend the game, if there's no sale I recommend buying the standard edition and then buy any dlc you have interest in after you finished the campaign.

Having fond memories from playing Ace Combat back on the Playstation 2 I finally came around and gave Ace Combat 7 a go. And I can say it was totally worth my time, it's an arcade action flight model that brings you right into action of dogfighting with several different planes.
Of which you unlock through an Aircraft Tree, each plane and their special weapons upgrades need points the player gets for playing through the campaign missions, which are all repeatable to "farm" more points.
Repeating campaign missions, separate single player missions or playing multiplayer are needed to ultimately unlock everything on the tree.
_______________

Gameplay
The gameplay is very arcadey which has always been a staple of the Ace Combat series and which is also the reason why I like this game so much, it's very easy to get into and encourages fast paced action.
Before you start a campaign it gives you the choice selecting a difficulty, which can't be changed mid campaign.
Hard - Normal - Easy - Very Easy
I've played the campaign on normal difficulty and having failed certain timed objectives in the campaign, crashing or being shot down a few times I can see why a Very Easy difficulty is even an option.
Some missions do not have checkpoints, meaning if you fail the last minute of a 15 minute mission you have to replay the whole thing again, there's no hand holding in that regard.

No hand holding is not something I like either however the friendly AI that accompanies the player is borderline useless, there's sadly no interaction between the player and his friendlies, other than maybe the few missions to protect them from incoming enemies.
You can't order them to do anything specific nor do they actively try to help you in a dogfight, it feels very much you are the only one able to save the day, which is probably the point by the devs but in my opinion a missed opportunity.

The majority of the planes are licensed real world Fighters and I can see any Fighter Planes enthusiast would enjoy unlocking, upgrading and flying them through the roaring skies.
Each plane has different characteristics, and choosing the right plane for the next mission is part of what makes the diversity so great.


Graphics
The ingame VFX and details are all focused on the planes and everything that is above ground, the highly detailed planes, the explosions and even the clouds that have a real volumetric appearance, which have gameplay mechanics to them, look and feel great for a game from 2019.
The ground environment is serviceable and won't blow you away but the hard ground is not were your plane belongs anyways! Ground environment and the different maps do look great from above though and you'll fly above deserts, green farmlands, mountains, canyons, oceans and dense urban environment.
What lacks in graphical fidelity on the ground is being saved by the diversity the game presents.

Sound
The overall sound design is good, planes closely flying by, missiles exploding or swooshing close by gives you a great feeling being in the skies with some of the most expensive military machinery.
Sadly your own plane, even though each plane sounds different even each machine gun sounds have a different pitch depending what caliber and rate of fire they have, sounds somewhat weak compared to everything around you, the audio mixing could be way better in that regard.
An example for that is no matter what camera perspective you choose to fly in the sounds your plane make give the same volume and direction, honestly it's the biggest gripe I have with the game.
Accelerating for example just doesn't give enough audio feedback to the player, flying 700kph or 2000kph is almost no audio change, the screen shaking and playing with a controller that gives you vibration feedback is trying to save that aspect of the game.
Oh and the music is freaking amazing, the OST for every mission is epic and gives you the feeling of how important and dire a situation in the current scenario is.


Story
Oh boy the story is probably the weakest part of the game, you play a mute and faceless pilot that just exists and all the other characters that are being portrayed in high quality pre rendered cut scenes are basically the focus, they interact with the player only sometimes by talking at you while you're in missions.
The overarching story is okay and there are a good amount of twists and turns, but truly at best nothing amazing.
Your squad mates are all so forgettable that even right now just writing this review right after finishing the campaign and a few multiplayer sessions, I already forgot their names and the game never even tried to become close with the people that your character flies with.
These are the people that you trust with your life and yet the writing and story implementation is so bad that they are the most generic disposable characters in a story I've tried to get into. BIG L

This is game enables new players to enjoy the game while leveling their skills at their own pace without endlessly grinding for credits and experience. What I appreciate the most is that this game values the client's time as well as delivering a great experience. This is important, and something a lot of other publishers nowadays miss. I highly recommend this game, especially for people who value their time (as it should be) as well as being part of the gaming community.

Ace Combat 7: A Disappointing and Politically Charged Experience

After playing Ace Combat 7, I must say that the game is not worth the investment. Instead of delivering an exciting fighting game with a compelling story, it falls flat with a subpar flying experience and a painfully predictable storyline.

Cons:

    Poor story: The game's narrative is riddled with anti-war political rhetoric, as characters continually discuss the horrors of war and the importance of peace. This is a departure from the thrilling combat experience players might expect.
    Weak male characters: The only notable male characters in the game are a stereotypical evil scientist who reforms and an old man who dies of old age. Neither adds much depth or interest to the story.
    Overemphasis on refugees: The storyline focuses too heavily on refugees, rebuilding a better future, and a queen character who inspires her subjects simply by talking on the radio. This detracts from the action and excitement of the game.
    Missing main protagonist: The lack of a strong, engaging main character leaves the story feeling hollow and uninteresting.
    Cringe-worthy cutscenes: The game's cutscenes are awkward and poorly executed, adding to the overall negative experience.
    Mediocre music: The music in Ace Combat 7 is average and fails to enhance the gaming experience.
    Predatory DLC policies: Mission 19 is incredibly difficult for average gamers to complete without purchasing overpowered DLC planes. Namco's approach to DLC in this game is predatory and frustrating for players.
    Politically charged: The game's heavy-handed political messages make it difficult to enjoy the gameplay without being constantly reminded of the developers' agenda.

In conclusion, I cannot recommend Ace Combat 7 or any future games from Namco or its Japanese director. The game's politically charged narrative, weak characters, and predatory DLC policies make it a poor investment. I regret paying full price for this game and will be more cautious about researching game directors and publishing companies in the future.

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't, by subtracting where it is, from where it isn't, or where it isn't, from where it is, whichever is greater, it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance sub-system uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is, to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is.

Oh boy, let me tell you about Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown. As a self-proclaimed aviation nerd, I must say, this game takes the cake for one of the most exhilarating air combat simulations I have ever played.

First and foremost, the gameplay mechanics are simply out of this world. The mission design is top-notch, providing the perfect balance of challenge and fun, and the flight controls are incredibly responsive and intuitive. It's no wonder why fans of the series keep coming back for more, I mean, who doesn't want to fly high above the clouds and engage in epic dogfights?

Now, let's talk about the planes. The attention to detail in the aircraft models is nothing short of astounding. The developers have done an amazing job in capturing the unique nuances of each plane, making it feel like you're flying the real thing. However, the game does lack customization options, which is a bit of a bummer for players who like to tweak and tune their planes to their liking.

As for the story, it's not the strongest aspect of the game, but it's serviceable enough to provide context for the missions. Honestly, the missions are so good that the story takes a backseat in my opinion.

All in all, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is a must-play for fans of the series and anyone who enjoys fast-paced, adrenaline-pumping air combat simulations. Based on my experience with the game, I'd give it a solid 9 out of 10.

I got this game initially after having played Project Wingman - a game I heard was exceptionally similar in controls and experience to this game. After 5 hours of experiencing the game, I've been left disappointed and feeling misled by the comparison so many have made. 

This game is objectively inferior, with a 3x greater price tag. The controls compared to Project Wingman are clunky and unresponsive, even comparing early game planes to early game planes; the enemies are gimmicky and feel borderline unfair, the drones this game uses as its main plot point in the early sections are so small even well placed missiles feel like a coin toss on whether or not they're going to hit; the gimmicks the missions use (especially 7 and 8, the point where I stopped playing) are annoying and only further contribute to the negative experience already brought about by the prior two points. 

These gimmicks, the lightning in 7 that messes with your ability to see or lock onto the enemy drones (which are already annoying to hit) is coupled with needing to keep drones off of allied planes, and if one plane goes down you have to restart that section of the mission. In 8, sand blocks your view of tiny trucks driving through a sandstorm, making it so you intermittently can't lock onto them unless you're within around 1000 feet. For reference, your plane can frequently exceed 2000 feet, and turns like the Titanic, so you'll find yourself circling these trucks aimlessly waiting for them to pop up on your radar again so you can *try* to get within the range to see them normally. Even worse, once you destroy 10 of the 20 trucks, drones fly in but thankfully aren't priority targets, and aren't actual threats to your survival due to firing missiles occasionally, and having no other means of offense. These, coupled further with a timer that, while not strict, is stressful, just leads to a disappointing, annoying, and lackluster experience. 

If you want to play a plane game with an engaging story, fun mechanics, good controls, and entertaining characters, play Project Wingman, which entirely lacks every fault I've laid out here. The experience brought by Ace Combat 7 is not worth its $60 price tag.

Hands down this is definitely one of my top 10 favorite games.

If your looking for a fun fighter jet game, but aren't looking for too much realism, then this is the game for you. I'd recommend 'Control Type: Expert,' for a more realistic feel. Overall it controls well and supports controllers and flights sticks very well (Although not all flight sticks work in the game). I just completed all the achievements for the game and I would still go back more more. There are some many more in-game achievements to get that will really put your skills to the test. The overall story is pretty good, not the greatest story in ever, but well written enough to keep you engaged. It has plenty of various difficulties that make it easier on new player, and a real challenge for veterans. The missions and boss-fights are great as well, and while a few missions are somewhat tedious (depending on your difficulty), it still an overall great time. Would absolutely recommend, although it is a little pricey. If money is an issue, they go on sale every so often, especially if a new fighter pilot movie like Top Gun Maverick comes out, so be sure to look out for those sales. Definitely a 10/10 game for me.

For a game called Ace Combat, you sure do wind up doing an awful lot of close range air support. Fun game though. Very arcadey controls.

If you'll let me talk about the story, it's tends to prefer to "tell" rather than "show", which is actually amazing at telling a story during missions and integrates the story well into the gameplay where a lot of information and action is delivered to you via comms, almost like a radio show. However, it carries over this "tell don't show" philosophy into the some of the SILLIEST cutscenes I have ever seen, which, depending on the person, might have been a positive, if the English voice actors didn't have such strange delivery during the cutscenes. 

Overall the experience was really hammy, but fun, imo. Feels way difficult by the end. 

I've done some reading on this game, and apparently, the development process for it was troubled all the way through. It would explain a lot of things about the story- the two squadrons probably would have been separate routes, and the difficulty probably would have had a less unforgiving ramp up rate. Overall, I still think it's a good game despite its flaws, even when not considering the development of the game. (Though I did personally get it on sale, so maybe try to do that)

Ok finally muscled through the last part of AC7. Final verdict from me is "good game heavily marred by the last 3 missions, which are all bad."  It's also probably the absolute worst flightstick plane game I've ever played. There were sections I was forced to switch to 3rd person kbm because there's just no way to use a flightstick and 1st person (with or without cockpit view) to do some of the missions. In fact, playing 3rd person just gives all your equipment larger lock angles and autoaiming on stuff like the PSL. 

The plot is insane but entertaining, whatever. I enjoyed all of the missions up to the end as well, but between insanely bad checkpoints, dumb as hell instant failure conditions/missions, and wild context swaps, whoever made the last few was a malfunctioning individual.

If you like flying games with flightsticks/etc, there's better options. Prepare to be frustrated at times. If you like flying in 3rd person with KBM, it's an easy buy. Especially on sale I feel I got my money's worth.

Ace Combat 7's story is nice, it follows a semi detached plot from the previous games, based in it's fictional world and global politics, as you journey through the story with some cool squadmates and face off against a badass ace pilot. But the narrative can be a bit off sometimes with a couple of characters narrating the story in the most botched way possible.
Narration aside, visuals are beautiful with meticulously designed aircrafts that are really enjoyable to look at during gameplay and replays. Audio design is good, it has signature Ace Combat dialogue design and music, with memorable tracks during some missions and mission briefings.

Gameplay is fun in general, BUT a bit frustrating if you're playing with keyboard & mouse, especially during tough air to air fights or with tricky mission objectives - better use a controller or you'll rage like I did during climactic boss fights. And the multiplayer's still alive and is really challenging, but has a minuscule player count, maybe 2-4 dozen players at a given time.


Overall an 8/10 experience, pretty good especially for a 4 year old game.

This was my first Ace Combat game. It was very pretty. The canyon mission was fantastic, bombing runs - OK, story mostly just there but the dogfighting... I just don't understand it.

The AI usually flies directly at you to get behind you. If you try to get behind them, you just both start circling each other. If you straighten out, they shoot missiles at you which forces you to circle more. You basically have to circle around aimlessly and wait until the AI straightens out to let you hit it. It's not fun, it's a dizzying waiting game. When the AI gets distracted by your buddies, it's mostly fine, but the "Boss" 1v1 dogfights are horrible.

The constant "WARNING MISSILE, WARNING, MISSILE" and incessant screeching of the missile targeting system put the final nail in the coffin. It makes the otherwise great sound game unlistenable.

I finished it over a course of a year. I took a break 4 times. It is pretty unique - there aren't many flight games out there, perhaps this is why. I like the idea of a flight game, but the reality is very different.
Remember: Stick with Trigger and you'll make it.

This game completely caught me off guard by how great it is.

It sat on my Steam wish list for a long time since it's normally not the genre of game I play. After a Steam sale (and being obsessed with Top Gun Maverick,) I decided to finally pick up. Right away I knew my mistake on waiting as long as I did to get it.

First off, the graphics are beautiful. If you have a PC that can play this in ultra, you're in for a real treat.

Secondly, the game play is a perfect balance for anyone who enjoys challenging missions but also likes just cruising around blowing up tanks from the sky. There's a few missions that took me a few retries and the handful of "boss fights" are pretty tough for any skill level in flying games. But it's not over the top difficult and makes it more enjoyable when you finally complete the mission. I was very impressed with how easy the controls were to learn and how you have a lot of options to play around with them during intense fights or missile dodges. I also appreciate how the lock on system is very responsive when switching between targets quickly.

The campaign story lost me around halfway through and then caught my attention again towards the end. I didn't play this game for the story, but it's a nice addition for those who don't want to just aimlessly fly mission to mission without a purpose.

I think a real high point in this game is the many different types of locations each mission takes you to. One mission you may be zooming past skyscrapers in a night time city. The next mission you may have to be carefully flying through a foggy mountain overpass while maintaining a certain altitude to avoid detection. It kept the overall experience exciting and fresh throughout.

The last mission is by far the most challenging (as expected.) Make sure to be properly upgrading your jets as the game goes on to make it a bit easier for you. With that said...the last half of the last mission blew me away by its originality and "high stakes."

After the campaign, check out multiplayer where you get to go head-to-head with actual real life war heroes (probably) who you don't stand a chance against. At the time of writing this, you can still find lobbies pretty easily, but limited to many options.

If you are someone who enjoys flying games or someone like me who just wanted a change of pace from the normal, I can't suggest this game enough.

[h1]Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown - The Perfect Combat Simulator[/h1]
As the great Starscreem, I have seen my fair share of aerial combat. And I must say, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is the perfect combat simulator for those who seek a true challenge. The game boasts stunning graphics, realistic physics, and an intense story that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Ace Combat 7's gameplay is nothing short of exceptional. The controls are smooth and responsive, allowing you to execute even the most complex aerial maneuvers with ease. The combat is intense and realistic, giving you a true sense of what it's like to engage in air-to-air and air-to-ground battles. Whether you're dodging missiles or unleashing your own arsenal, Ace Combat 7 delivers a true combat experience.

[b]Story[/b]
As a Decepticon, I'm not usually one for human stories, but I must admit that Ace Combat 7's storyline is engaging and compelling. The game takes place in a fictional world where a conflict between two nations escalates into an all-out war. The player takes on the role of an ace fighter pilot, fighting on both sides of the conflict to uncover the truth behind the war. The story is well-written and the characters are memorable, adding a deeper layer to the game's already impressive gameplay.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The graphics in Ace Combat 7 are simply stunning. From the detailed cockpit view to the expansive landscapes, everything is beautifully rendered. The attention to detail in the aircraft is particularly impressive, making each one feel unique and authentic. The game's use of lighting and weather effects adds another layer of immersion to the experience, making you feel like you're really soaring through the skies.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Overall, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is a must-play for anyone who loves aerial combat. The game's combination of realistic physics, engaging story, and stunning graphics make it the perfect combat simulator. As Starscreem, I can attest that this game is challenging even for the most experienced pilots. So, if you're looking for a true test of your aerial combat skills, look no further than Ace Combat 7.

This game was a joy to play, even for someone such as myself who has very limited experience with flying games. I personally chose to play on  controller, but I experimented with mouse and keyboard and that worked OK as well. The feel of the game is perfect: A blend of arcade and simulation flight that doesn't feel sluggish like a simulation flight game, but not too wild that there is no sense of realism. The plot of the story mode is borderline nonsensical, but it has a few entertaining beats, especially the final mission. Visually, the game is gorgeous, I initially was skeptical when I saw that the game was in Unreal Engine 4, but Bandai's art team has come in clutch big time, because the environments range from cityscapes to mountain ranges, all beautifully detailed and realized. Sometimes when the sun catches on the water or a plane the right way, a screencap from the game would look better than real life. I am VERY excited to see what Bandai can do with UE5. Combat is great, my one big complaint is that as far as I can remember, the game never even tells you that your plane has a machine gun, and that part of air-to-air combat feels like an afterthought. However, trading missiles feels fast and exciting. This game frequently goes on sale for ~10 dollars, and at that price, I don't think there's a single person I wouldn't recommend this game to. I intend on playing it again soon.

In my experience, some jet games have awesome multiplayer, but aren't meant for solo play. others, an immersive, rich storyline complete with detailed and thought out plots and characters at the expense of multiplayer. more still may be well rounded, but lack that extra stuff (dlc) that gets you comin' back for more. although i wouldn't say this game is a G.O.A.T, it is a LOT of fun, for beginners and vets alike. good points are:
-a wide array of secondary weapons. From air to ground to freakin lasers, it feels good to not JUST shoot only missiles.
-multiple enemy types, not just aircraft. multiple ship types, different ground targets, etc.
-a rich story, narrated from multiple viewpoints, and 20 missions, 23 with dlc.
-a lot of aircraft choices, each with their own unique charm.
-everything is well thought out. from defending a allied jet to refueling and landing sequences. you can be thrown off course if the environment is windy, or, your canopy can freeze, reducing mobility, if you're in clouds too long. heck, if it's stormy, you can get STRUCK BY LIGHTNING, and your HUD will glitch out. how many games do THAT?
-lastly, it goes beyond plane stats and ammo types... there are parts to upgrade your jet, like more speed, missile homing boosting, to stealth coating and even mobility enhancers, all of which can be put on or off at your convenience. it really makes you think.

if you want to know any bad points, the only i can think of are:
-in the story, the characters swear and cuss. a LOT. so if that's not your style, you may want to be aware of that... though you CAN turn off radio chatter volume, i dunno if it includes subtitles. not to mention, if your a first timer, it can be hard without it, i.e. mission updates, sudden orders, etc.
-you don't get all aircraft and parts right off the bat. there's an aircraft tree of sorts, and your mission kill points buy planes and stuff. thing is, it's a branching tree, and if you didn't buy plane A before plane B, you cant buy plane B. basically, you have to buy this to unlock that. if a plane you really want is at the very end of the tree, tough luck. you'll need aaaaallllll the other stuff first.


other than that? worth every penny.

Having played some of the previous titles such as the PS2 games and Skies of Deception on the PSP (Spending many MANY hours on my couch as a kid playing) coming into AC7 I was expecting it to be a modern version of what I remember but with a modern paint job. And for the most part this is what I got, it plays like I remember, feels like I remember and even has some of the planes I remember. On a broader spectrum (and for those unfamiliar with this series) AC7 delivers an engaging flight experience that's easy to pick up, tough to master but is entirely about the fun aspect and not demanding you spend 500 hours learning the actual controls of a Jet Fighter. You'll be in the thick of the action within minutes of booting up the game and you'll be presented an interesting and well narrated story through to the end. As long as you have a passing interest in fighter planes, you'll find enjoyment to be had here.

However on the downsides the graphics are starting to look a bit dated and hardware can certainly do more than what's asked of it here, overall though it looks alright considering this was originally for the PS4. Though my two biggest gripes with the game come in the forms of menu design and the lack of boss fights. I would like to see a return to form in the next game for the menu system especially for the hanger, letting you preview the aircraft you intend to buy and not having to wade through a tree that you can see only 1/20th of at any given time. As for the bosses, there are effectively only 3 bosses here to fight (Arsenal Bird, That One Pilot and That One Pilot V2), that wanes in comparison to earlier entries. Additionally not allowing the player to actually kill a boss until the game says so is really frustrating, seeing the hit markers come up repeatedly but no indication of damage and the enemy continuing to fly is a bit demeaning. 


Pros / Cons

✔ Great soundtrack
✔ Wide selection of Fighter and Multi-Role aircraft
✔ Interesting story (if a little short)
✔ Great narrative cinematics with solid voice acting
✔ Game runs as smooth as butter (2k Ultra GFX 144FPS+ always - 5900x / 3080Ti / DDR4 3200MHz)
✔ Mission variety is great, lots of different tasks and mission types
✔ Controls are well setup for a controller out of the box and the planes respond well to inputs
✔ Planes are very detailed with the interiors being fully modeled and visible from outside the cockpit
✔ Solid graphics for a PS4 title

❌ Very few boss fights
❌ Game doesn't let you win some of the earlier boss fights until it wants you to win 
❌ Poor selection of bombers - A10 and SU are the only options, seriously?
❌ UI layout for menu's and Aircraft tree suck (Old PSP hanger was better!)
❌ MRP is a bit of a grind to unlock the base tree. MP items should've been more expensive.
❌ Graphics look dated even after 4 years

Overall: 7.5 / 10

All in all AC7 7 is a great game with enough content and depth to satisfy the casual plane enthusiast, and would make a great entry point for someone who wants to play more Aircraft related games or is interested in the AC series.

[strike] The gravitational force equivalent, or, more commonly, g-force, is a measurement of the type of force per unit mass – typically acceleration – that causes a perception of weight, with a g-force of 1 g (not gram in mass measurement) equal to the conventional value of gravitational acceleration on Earth, g, of about 9.8 m/s2. Since g-forces indirectly produce weight, any g-force can be described as a "weight per unit mass" (see the synonym specific weight). When the g-force is produced by the surface of one object being pushed by the surface of another object, the reaction force to this push produces an equal and opposite weight for every unit of each object's mass. The types of forces involved are transmitted through objects by interior mechanical stresses. Gravitational acceleration (except certain electromagnetic force influences) is the cause of an object's acceleration in relation to free fall. [/strike]

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is - whichever is greater - it obtains a difference or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position that it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is now is the position that it wasn't, and if follows that the position that it was is now the position that it isn't. In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation. The variation being the difference between where the missile is and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was. The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows: Because a variation has modified some of the information that the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it know where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice versa. And by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

As much as I wanted to enjoy this game, I just didn't...

People can talk about it being a "simulator" all that they want, but it's not as if this game has a "race" type mode or agility courses to test your flying skills in. It has a story mode and multplayer, both centered around aerial combat, so I feel confident judging this a videogame and not some transcendental modern jet aficionados club.

There is no "skirmish" type game mode, which would go far in providing replay value and fun. A nice, random map with some enemies in random positions to keep things challenging and engaging would make or break this game. Since it doesn't have a skirmish mode, well...

Multiplayer is solely the domain of head to head competition. That's fine for some, but I'm not interested in that. I rarely play online multiplayer these days as a matter of course, but being that this is a game with literally dozens of aircraft and customizable loadouts for each and I don't need to be clairvoyant to know I don't even want to attempt to see if it's balanced or not.

The campaign is...okay, I guess, at least your first time through. They way events play out and the way people talk...well it feels to me as a "westerner" the way I imagine a Japanese individual would on hearing a weeaboo talk about "honor" and "the blade." I find myself wincing every so often. 

It's a shame, since there are a lot of neat things at play. Seeing a sliding padeye in the carrier hangar was a nice touch for me. If you don't know what that is, don't worry, because it's not important. It was just a neat thing for me to see and I'm sure plenty of others will find something appealing to them.

Outside of that, though, the actual gameplay is where it soils the bedsheets. It really has no other speed than to go "Oh hey! You want a challenge? Well here's a missile every other time you go to shoot the bad guys!" That might not sound like much, but since your allies rarely do much and the enemy is spread out around the map it can get old very quickly having to break line of sight yet again to evade yet another missile.

From the standpoint of a "game" it would've been better to just follow the war, storywise, and have you control faceless, nameless pilots in the cockpit Battlefront-style. As things stand I find myself desperately dodging missiles again and again until the game finds yet another excuse to block my vision, whether with sandstorms or clouds. Eventually it just gets to the point that it is "challenging" in the same way it'd be a challenge to knock a brick wall down with my scrotum. Sure, I could do it, but why?

Maybe this is normal for the franchise, but I don't care. I didn't pay $60 for name recognition, I paid for a game. If I even need to ask myself if I'm having fun, there are already serious problems, but I just find myself getting mad trying to play this. Every little thrill from the "jet pwane simuwator" is brought down by frustrations and annoyances. 

Aside from an appealing soundtrack, there's nothing that I'm really looking back on fondly from the 20 hours that I've put into the game.

Half the missions are insane, high octane jet action where I'm in white knuckle dogfights against daunting opponents or weaving through harrowing valleys. Tragically the other half of the levels were designed by some interns or something and they consist of blowing up x amount of ground targets before a timer runs out and it could be a skill issue but every time I play those levels i get 99% of the required points before the timer cuts me off and boots me back to the beginning. Sometimes the devs throw in a wildcard and have you crawl around in 0 visibility conditions waiting for your radar to lock onto something like you're playing the electrifying game of beach metal detector. Other times you get to have your eyes glued to your minimap to shuffle your way through a maze of radars. Honestly i'd rather the game was just half the length and pure action instead of these filler/gimmick missions I'm uniquely bad at but nothing's perfect and the good half of the game is really really good.


The graphics/visual presentation and story are unmarred though and they're the elements that kept me playing when I was only scoring 14950/15000 ground destruction points for the 10th time in a row on an interminable air to ground points mission.

I picked up this game on a massive discount and I think that is the price it is worthy of, if like me, you are only gonna play the single player campaign part. Here are some pros and cons:

Pros:
1. The gameplay is very smooth and fun, there is no way dogfighting could not be fun
2. the variety of planes is great, it was super cool to fly planes like the Berkut.
3. The design and graphics of the game are beautiful and somehow were not too heavy on my aging gaming laptop.
4. Details like lighting, weather, plane roles... were well implemented
5. A10 go brrrrr

Cons:
1. The story was written by a 2 year old and at some point stopped making any sense. Towards the end they cram so much information and characters, most of which were completely meaningless and stupid
2. The characters are not even 1 dimensional and bordering on cringe inducing.
3. Speaking of cringe inducing, wtf is wrong with that dialogue? WTF IS WRONG WITH THOSE CUTSCENES??
4. The ally AI is completely useless, while enemy AI is fixated on you. After my last session, i fell asleep hearing the "WARNING MISSILE LOCK" lady in my dreams. The only time something happens to allied AI is when the script wants them to be killed or to get a kill.
5. Some missions are just weird. Flying a stealth mission in a valley while only worrying about search lights? I never knew jet planes were that quite. But i guess this was my least concern.
6. You need to play like 4 missions perfectly to have enough MRP to unlock a plane, and if you are expecting to unlock all the planes you must have nothing else to do in life but replay the missions over and over. Best you can do in one playthrough is reach the last gen aircraft by following one line.
7. You cant customise your plane's looks until yyou finish the campaign, yet they keep unlocking stuff for you.
8. I finsihed the campaign in around 7 hours and yet i had absolutely no idea what the story was about except that DRONES BAD

Overall, if like me you picked up this game on like 80% discount it is probably worth it if you are planning to only play the campaign.

I own a missile for homeland defense because thats what Woodrow Wilson intended. Four bandits break into my airspace. Scramble Scramble as I grab my helmet and AIM 9x Sidewinder. Blow a softball sized hole through the first bandit, he's dead on the spot. Draw my AM-RAM on the second man, miss him entirely because he notched it and it put bulls on a civilian airliner. I have to resort to the Patriot missile system mounted at the airbase below. "Tally Ho Pads!" The surface-to-air missile shred two men in the blast - the sound and falling metal sets of car alarms. I then resort to dogfighting the last bandit, select my m61 Vulcan 20 mil, pull him into HUD and fire! He bleeds out on the cockpit waiting for ejection because 20mil high explosive is impossible to stitch up; just as I get a bingo fuel warning. "BINGO, BINGO"

Pretty fun air combat game with a campaign that has a pretty wide range of scenarios (dog fights, air strikes on the ground, etc.) The story can be a little cheesy, and you're put into some morally questionable (read "bad") situations sometimes, but it's serviceable. I'd say the soundtrack is fantastic.
I like how the game lets you toggle between third person, first person, and cockpit view, depending on your preferences. I think the fact that the game shows you a replay at the end of every mission is a sign that the devs knew that players would want to watch how they were flying and even take some screenshots.
As a newcomer to the series, and games of this genre as a whole, I've only been playing on easy difficulty tbh, but I'm having a fun time playing it regardless. Once I'm confident enough, I might try another playthrough on normal or even hard.

There's never truly a poor mismatch in aircrafts, unless it's say... a Darkstar. Darkstars are DLC and also need specific builds to counter them because they're simply too fast, and this is my only gripe with the game. Otherwise, I think it's great and I highly recommend anyone, new to the series or a returning veteran, to consider picking this up.

The campaign recycles a myriad of missions from previous AC games (even Assault Horizon), except they are lazily done this time. The story relies on characters A, You don't care about B, Have immortality.
You are constantly looped from "The rookie that doesn't know anything, despite killing literally everyone by yourself" to "You are the only one capable of doing anything, you are a hero".
Too many side-threads in the story means it might be interesting to some, but too shallow for others.
On replay it can get frustrating waiting for people's conversations to run out, so you can play (as essentially you are completely barred from completing objectives in some cases). The two main antagonists are an old man, who has god mode turned on and machines. To counter said machines, high-G turns from a button press were invented.

Plane variety is fine, but come on, this is nowhere near what we've seen in previous games. Besides, so many planes are paid DLC, at insane prices. I bought the ultimate mega giga deluxe edition for 80 bucks before release, yet I still don't own half the released DLCs and would need to shill out another 103 dollars (or just 83, if you don't consider the Top Gun stuff to be anything more than a novelty) to have everything the game has to offer.

Ultimately, this game is very popular as the first mainline Ace Combat game to release on PC, but it's a sore disappointment for me. A plain old cashgrab, disgustingly filled with DLCs, recycled content, lack of creativity and just generally nothing much going for it.
The graphics are amazing, the gameplay is good - but scripted events can get old fast. Not a lot memorable about this game. I like that they tried making the old AC formula a bit more fresh with the high-g turns, but if it stays for a new game, I hope they refine it a bit more.

In recent memory, Bandai did the same thing with Elden Ring (they rushed to release the game with unfinished quests for example, lots of recycled content, but atleast FromSoft can work on it without cashgrabs after Bandai stops pissing on them) and banked on the goodwill of the people to sell. This is nowhere near the quality of what you'd expect from an AC game, but atleast it made me like Assault Horizon in comparison.

This game can be fun at times the input controls are brainwrecking as this is just a shameless console port, there is not even a way to do any customization of a Hotas and this is game that's all about flying fighter jet, its just insane.
In the game menu's there are only icons for console controllers and that's it, you cannot use an analog rudder and don't even think about using a separate throttle with its own connection. You will need to use the steam controller input configuration to use your joystick at all.
To sum up this mess is simple, the developer made a cheap port to the PC without putting in a minute of thought about other controls than a console controller.
This game could have been a fun and simple alternative to DCS and any other decent flight game. But the controls are worse then old DOS games like Wing Commander or EF2000
If you play this game with a decent Hotas the game will even be harder then when you have a console controller as things only partially work and you'll need to be pushing the stick to end of limits all the time.

The about the game itself
There are many cool planes in this game that look great, like the F14,F15,F16,F18,F22, Mirage 2000, Gripen, Eurofighter, Mig29, SU 30 etc. This is just great for modern military fighter jet lovers. So that's definetly a plus.
Except for the realistically looking planes there is nothing realistically about flying them, except for the fact that you can stall, crash and your turn ratio gets worse if you speed is higher. The stats of the planes themselves do not even somewhat resemble the real planes. Due a progression tree with incrementally better fighters you need to unlock.
And if you get the ultimate edition or some other DLC there will be planes with the best stats already which you can use in the campaign to somewhat cheat to the top

There is a story line that is somewhat interesting and insanely weird at the same time. The story line is totally irrelevant to the game and can be skipped if you want to.

If you get this on sale its OK I guess but don't pay full price for this console port.
If you have one play it with a console controller of be prepared for much frustration if you want to use that Hotas as you'll need to invest some time to get it working and then its working only half.

Pretty good entry point to the Ace Combat franchise, and very enjoyable in and of itself. It does away with most of the frustrating design choices from earlier titles (though some other features like Wingman Command are missed somewhat) and pairs it with a story that's interesting both for newcomers and longtime Ace Combat fans, marking the return of its iconic "Strangereal" world. I would recommend playing with Expert controls even if they might take longer to get used to. I'd also recommend getting the three DLC missions (Unexpected Visitor, Anchorhead Raid and Ten Million Relief Plan).

First this is NOT a simulator, if you're looking for that, this aint it. But if you're looking for a fun singleplayer game with licensed and realistic aircraft blasting targets on land, air, and sea... this is a highly entertaining. Its basically a non stop action movie where you roleplay as a fighter pilot. To its credit, you do have full flight controls on "expert mode" and you can fly in cockpit view so you can make it seem fairly realistic if you choose. There is also a big tech tree of planes to unlock and upgrade parts to customize your aircraft and ordinance loadouts. Not sure if its worth it full price but on sale, HELL YES.

This is not meant as a review to hate on the game, because I really do want to enjoy the game and experience what it has to offer. I really enjoy the story and the banter between the characters in the 7 or so hours I've played but I really struggle to get to means with the controls.

It has a Standard and Expert control system, which is basically if you can control yaw and pitch with the left stick or only yaw. Problem is that you either fly with training wheels or have so much control that it ended up giving me motion sickness whilst playing, something I've not experienced in any game until now.

Id say try it for 2 hours and see what you think. If you can't handle the expert controls and don't feel that you can do so in the time given and/or it begins to give you motion sickness, then this game will not be one you will enjoy.

Good game, bad DLC policy.

In the older games 70% of those DLC planes would be in the main game, you don't even get early game classics such as the F4 Phanton. 

Later the game offers you a dozen variants of the same plane instead of just giving you a new one. That's very disappointing when you realize the PS2 games simply had more planes, and thefore you always had something fun to unlock. Otherwise It's the Ace Combat  everyone loves. 
However I wished they released more mission as expansions (like a whole campaign), maybe throw a different game mode here and there... I feel there's  a lot of potential in the ACE COMBAT franchise that's not explored properly.

I wanted to like this game.  I knew it wasn't going to be a flight sim, but that's okay - a little arcade-ish fun is fine.  The story is deep but fits the arcade-ish feel (a comment about an F-15 pulling 30g and not having seen anything move that fast, for example). It is very pretty - the graphics are great.  What absolutely killed the game for me is the controls.  If you're using a flight stick and a throttle things work, but there is no way to customize the controls or even know what they are except for trial and error.  The other problem is in how the airplanes are depicted- the famously unmanueverable F-104 is in the same ballpark as the supremely agile F-16, which also has the ability to go >2,300 knots at low altitude.... more than double its real world speed even at high altitude.

The game is very cool, but it has a few flaws. This was the first time I played an Ace Combat Game and I played the full campaign + 3 special missions. Here are my thoughts :

PROS :

+ Very beautiful graphics
+ Very well polished : clean, no bugs, high framerate.
+ Very fun core gameplay. The combat & flight are quite arcade, which make it closer to an Action/shooter game rather than a flight simulator game, and that is cool. Also, I don't like games that require a 3hrs tutorial, and this one is very quick to learn & enjoy. To sim players : it is not meant to be played with a joystick, it is made to be played with a gamepad (because it is a franchise coming from consoles).
+ Fair amount of content for a AAA game that is not an openworld. I spent more than 20hrs to finish the main campaign on normal difficulty. A couple more hours for the special missions.
+ Missions diversity. They really tried to find different ideas for every mission, and the game does not feel repetitive.

CONS :

- Progression tree (that unlocks new planes and gear) is nice, but poorly balanced. I really wanted to play the F22 raptor and did not manage to unlock it before the end of the campaign. I did not completely rush it though, I bought a few other ones along the way to try different gameplay options. But the last planes of the tree are so expensive that they require hard savings along the campaign if you want to have a chance to play them. Quite frustrating, because as players, we just want to try everything that the game has to offer.
- The lore. I am fine with the overall story, but there are way too much unnecessary dialogues and cinematics that interfere with the gameplay. NPCs keeps spaming the radio during combats which is very anoying when you try to concentrate on a difficult fight. Many things in the cinematics and the briefings do not teach you anything interesting or useful, and just feel like they are retaining you from entering gameplay.
- The weapon system could have been better. The game only allows you to take 1 weapon on top of standard missiles. But many missions contain at the same time Air combat + Ships to destroy + Ground targets. On top of that the briefing almost always fail to inform you on the type of targets you will really encounter during the mission. So in the end, you often feel frustated to not have the right weapon at the right time. It would have been way better if planes could handle several types of special weapons at the same time (like in Project Wingman), at least for the later planes in the progression tree.
 - Some frustrating gameplay mecanics. As they tried to diversify missions, they added additional gameplay contraints : storms that can blur your HUD and constraint your movements or IFF loss that prevents you from identifying your enemies. I am fine with the Idea, not the implementation. I found myself restarting missions several times because the game was forcing me to fly in the storms during fights, which lead to many frustating crashes. IFF loss is awful : you have to keep your crossair on every target for 5s to identify them, which is just horrible when you have dozens of ground and air targets that are already shooting at you. At least they could have implemented it so you identify targets immediately when your crossair passes on it.
- Boss fights are not fun at all. The enemy makes impossible moves, and you cannot deal damage to him before the game decides you can. It just feels like boss fights are scripted, and the enemy would kill himself at the defined point whatever you do something or not.

IN THE END :

I still recommend the game because it contains a good load of fun. I just hope that they will fix the few design flaws for the next Ace combat game.

Ace Combat 7 is an arcade dogfighter game, with fantastic aircraft handling, combat and visuals; which is wonderful as there are so few of those. I loved HAWX many years ago and have often looked out for a more modern version. The flying, sound effects and controls are all excellent and I REALLY enjoy the gameplay. The major drawback is.. everything else. The voice acting, the writing, the endless cutscenes all detract from what is otherwise an extremely enjoyable air combat game. The first half hour is one 10 minute mission, and 25 minutes of cut scenes. Multiplayer is dead, and I completed the campaign in 11 hours, so I can't recommend paying 60 euros for it.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Looks fantastic
- Really good controls
- Sound effects and combat feedback are excellent
- The game makes you feel like a badass
- Blowing up targets on the ground is especially satisfying
- 20 campaign missions
- The voice acting is good, but the writing isn't
- Large number of planes and equipment to unlock
- Using numbers to designate planes makes them difficult to tell apart
- Really satisfying to fly around blowing stuff up
- Good variety of enemies between different planes, ground vehicles, planes and boats

[b]Cons[/b]
- The nation names they chose are confusing. I spent most of the campaign wondering who's side I was on between Erusea and Osea, which sound very similar
- The Aircraft Tree where you unlock new planes and weapons does a terrible job of showing you the differerences between planes
- Waaaaaayyy too many cutscenes
- You can really tell the voice acting and writing for missions was translated. Sentences make almost no sense, topics change immediately (even between sentences), voice intonation is totally off - like they got someone to read each sentence in isolation then glued them all together
- No checkpoints in 20 minute missions, and no repairs. I regularly get shot down right before the end of a mission which is really frustrating having to play through the whole thing again
- If there IS a checkpoint, and you die after reaching it, you get all your health and missiles back
- The difficulty spikes a lot. Some missions it took me 6 attempts (with no checkpoints) to finally complete. Some I did with no thinking at all on the first try. Fleet Destruction is a good example - it took me a long time to work out how to get enough points without being shot down. Followed by a mission where you just fly through a canyon then shoot down a small number of helicopters.
- The boss fights are boring. There's a few missions where an enemy plane shows up that defies the laws of physics, jinks out of the way of missles and is impossible to hit, so you just fly around aimlessly for 10 minutes trying to get an angle to shoot at it

This is a fun game, and a great port from the console versions. This is not an aerial combat simulator with all pilots and environments acting the way would in the real world. However, it's realistic enough to make you feel like you're in exciting dogfights with all kinds of aircraft based on their real world counterparts. Now, there are indeed some fictional aircraft that fly and bank more like magic flying objects - which gets super annoying sometimes. And don't expect your wing-men to do anything. NO OTHER PILOT IN THIS ENTIRE AIR FORCE WILL HELP YOU DO ANYTHING! They are props to make the combat look more realistic. You are the only pilot that matters, and you have to do everything in every mission single-handed. Of course, that's to be expected because, again, this NOT a simulator. 

The game's plot is that you're a criminal forced conscripted into military service against your will, and who is mistreated until you prove yourself worthy of a pardon, and where they put you BACK into service with the regular military. You will strike military and civilian targets all over. And if all of this sounds like a BUNCH OF WAR CRIMES, you are CORRECT. The game's plot is just one huge WAR CRIME, that you ignore for the sake of having fun. 

And fun this is. I had to take it in small doses, as the missions get more hilariously challenging - because your superiors have no idea how to execute joint strike operations, sending in jets where helicopters would be way better. But, whatever - Just have fun, and ignore that you were forced into military service for 1/2 the game.
Fantastic game, really cinematic, not really realistic but that is the whole point.

ACE COMBAT 7 is the first AC I've played in well over a decade; and I do recall enjoying the one(s) I've played in the past. 

Playing 7 now, I find myself going back over and over - even after finishing the campaign three times now. 
Completionist Mode has taken over -- Incredible replayability. 

My biggest 'issue' being the incompatibility with any joystick, other than the one sanctioned by the game. Fully understanding that the game was never designed to be compatible (plug n play) with whichever peripheral one might want to [nose]dive in with; the lack of any update to the game, even opening up more options is where I get a little bummed. 

However, this does not abate my desire to play or the rush and enjoyment I experience while playing (just need to do some research, take some specific steps, and it should be doable!)

- The story is a little hit-or-miss for me (including the DLC missions.) A lot of unfinished business, if you will - curiosities left wafting in the proverbial wind. In the end, it has it's blockbuster missions, several opportunities to really implement your cunning and wit, strategize, and so on.  After a couple of completions, you are also [likely] left with some challenging challenges to conquer (medals, player stats) 
-Multiplayer, I've only spent a handful of sorties-worth playing so far.  Initially, it was unexpected and in the face. Everything is ramped up to 10. A little time (a few matches) will have you more capable of survival; a sizable store of earned credits (from campaign, freeplay) will bring you up to par even quicker - just keep in mind, some people are stupid-good at a game like this (yes, even without actual cheating - the full use of a three dimensional space governed by [artificially simulated] physics quite closely resembling that of our experience(s) in the real world, is well complimented by a good grasp and understanding of it.

In no way is a firm understanding of physics required to enjoy this or any other flight simulator, but it can be a benefit. (lol)
