I beat the game, but felt many of the missions I wouldn't want to play again. I put the game away for a while, and came back for a bit after watching Top Gun, but the missions here are still bad. Frankly I felt dogfighting in Star Wars Squadrons was better than AC7.

The game framework has a lot of potential- Nice looking aircraft with differing special weapons that make them perform different (ex: the aging F-14 can still outperform an F-35 in bomber interception with its phoenix (LAAM) missiles, A F-18 carries LASM that make it great against ships, however an F-35 or F-22 will be better in dogfighting with better agility).

However a lot of the missions are made annoying by gimmicks- short time limits, sand storms/thunder storms blinding you and hiding enemies while the clock counts down, missiles out of nowhere if you leave the clouds that are not evaded with flares , tunnels not much bigger than the collision boxes of many fighters on mission 20 (get the ground defense upgrade it seems to make the plane collision box smaller), etc.

A comment I read about another game holds true here: "it's not made to be fun, it's made to be a challenge" basically instead of crafting a well balanced game they rely on a player's inability to accept the "mission failed" prompt, and just put it down. In the absence of a better option (not a lot of good flight combat games on Steam) I have kept working on getting past some missions over time in the hopes the next one will be more fun- usually not though. Remember when games used to be made to be both fun and a balanced challenge? Many flight sims back in the days of XP were better.
Several years later and it still doesn't support ultrawide. The fan made work-around to get ultrawide working is a PITA too.
cool planes

Ah, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown, a game that once again reminds us of the sheer beauty and destruction that can be wrought through human action. As an Earl who holds an extensive collection of video games, I've played all sorts of flight simulators, but this one truly stands out. Not because of its beautiful graphics and immersive gameplay, but because of the existential questions it raises.

Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown explores the theme of human agency and responsibility, which is reflected through its intricate story, where the characters are forced to question their own actions and their effect on others. The game, through its portrayal of warfare, poses a philosophical question about the very essence of humanity and its capacity for destruction. It asks us whether or not we should accept the destructive power that we wield or use it for the greater good.

Moreover, the game delves deep into the concept of free will, as it allows the players to make their own choices, affecting the outcome of the story. By offering players the choice to make decisions and follow their own path, the game highlights the importance of individual will and the impact it can have on the world.

In essence, Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is more than just a video game; it is a thought-provoking experience that challenges the player's perspective on human action and morality. It reminds us that we have the power to make choices, and with that power comes great responsibility. For this reason, I would say that Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown is a must-play for anyone who values introspection and reflection, as it will undoubtedly leave you with a deeper understanding of the nature of human existence.

Never thought I'd see the day that a Strangereal [i]Ace Combat[/i] game would be available on multiple gaming platforms, including PC.

I remember playing the PS2's "Holy Trinity" ([i]5[/i], [i]Zero[/i], and [i]4[/i]--in that order**) at a time when the seventh generation of video game consoles (PS3, Xbox 360) were starting to "trend." Even with the Trinity's now-archaic graphics, they still had a charm that stayed with you. Was it the admittedly cheesy, yet lore-rich stories and worldbuilding? The memorable, memeable and anime-like characters and antagonists? Was it how the games made the player character feel like an actual ace? Was it Keiki Kobayashi's awesome music? Or perhaps it was the lovingly rendered combat aircraft with their unique quirks and weaponry?

(**Side note, I also played a bit of [i]6[/i], but wasn't able to clear it--much less play with the DLC planes--because of the whole "console exclusivity" thing back then.)

In any case, I wondered when I could return to Strangereal, and what it would look like if it were available on multiple platforms with current-gen graphics.

[i]Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown[/i] is the answer.

[b][i][u]Ace Combat 7 - The Good, Bad and Ugly[/u][/i][/b]

[b]The Good:[/b]
[list]
[*] The return to Strangereal. And all the tropes/lore/worldbuilding related to it.
[*] Nostalgic call-backs (and some calls forward) to previous games.
[*] Breathtakingly good graphics. And I thought [i]6[/i] would hold the gold standard for good [i]Ace Combat[/i] graphics.
[*] Weather effects that can affect your flying. Clouds reduce visibility and cause your plane to ice up, but nerf lasers and can help you lose enemy missile lock. Crosswinds can mess up your flight path, lightning can mess up your HUD (and lower your altitude), and sandstorms combine the worst (and best) of clouds and crosswinds (thankfully only in that one mission).
[*] The music. (Keiki Kobayashi does it again!)
[*] A good set of challenging, yet rewarding DLC missions. ([i]"If I can't watch Marine-chan..."[/i])
[*] Free-LC. As much as I hate the "Modern Gaming(TM)" trend of overwhelming the buyer with a truckload of DLC and MTX, I do appreciate Project ACES not leaving base-game fans in the lurch with free-LC skins and emblems.
[*] The [i]Top Gun: Maverick[/i] collab. It's a good bet that the genesis of most present-day military aviation fans was from watching the seminal late 80's film, [i]Top Gun[/i], and that same movie also inspired Project ACES. Talk about coming full circle.
[*] A small, but fairly active modding community. (Though sadly only on PC.)
[/list]

[b]The Bad and Ugly:[/b]
[list]
[*] No "Definitive Edition." The closest thing is an "Ultimate Edition" that's available only in Japan, and even then doesn't include the "F-4E Phantom II + 3 Skins" DLC pack. What is this, Ubisoft? (*vomit noises*) And on that note...
[*] The aforementioned "Modern Gaming(TM)" trend of overwhelming the buyer with a truckload of paid DLC. And then there's the FOMO-inducing uncertainty over how long the [i]Top Gun: Maverick[/i] DLC will last. (Flashbacks of [i]Ace Combat 6[/i]'s [i]iDOLM@STER[/i] DLC planes being removed from the Xbox LIVE Marketplace in 2016.)
[*] A bare-bones Multiplayer mode with a non-existent anti-cheat system. No additional (co-op) multiplayer game modes (a-la [i]Ace Combat: Infinity[/i]), an option to create private rooms with passwords (if any), and griefing cheaters who hot-join to ruin the multiplayer experience for an already dwindling playerbase.
[*] Multiplayer multi-platform crossplay? Zilch (though probably for the best under current circumstances).
[*] Nerfed superplanes. But out of all the superplanes that got hit hard by the balance nerfbat, none have it worse than [i]Zero[/i]'s ADFX-01 Morgan. (Partly because of the weather effects [affects TLS], partly because of multiplayer balancing [MPBM].)
[*] Not really a fan of the 8AAM/AGM, especially with its tendency to sometimes lock two or more missiles on one target (only useful if a target's pretty tanky like F-22s, Su-57s, MiG-31s, YF-23s[?] Tu-160s, actual tanks, Aegis Ashores, large cargo planes or cruisers/battlecruisers) and waste ammo. And if there's a 6AAM, why isn't the 6AGM a thing? (The number "6" looking like a capital "G"?)
[*] In-game Music Player doesn't play multiplayer music from the older [i]Ace Combat[/i] games and the [i]Top Gun[/i] music remixes. (Unless those are unlocked by, well, playing multiplayer[?].)
[/list]

[b][i]Other Notes:[/i][/b]
[list]
[*] If you do want to buy the DLC, go for the Season Pass and then the DLC plane packs/bundles to get the most bang for your buck. Wait for a sale if you have to, the DLC bundles have gone as low as 50% off so far.
[*] I'll be doing DLC Pack/Bundle reviews on their respective pages. 
[/list]

[b]My Anniversary Updates Wishlist (Better Late Than Never):[/b]
[list]
[*] Comprehensive multiplayer updates (anti-cheat and create private rooms with passwords included).
[*] Rework the Onboard Self-Defense Jammer part as a way to increase countermeasure (chaff/flares) and IEWS charges (at least for single-player). And/or include a new part in the multiplayer aircraft tree that does the same thing (keep it at lvl. 1 if it's too OP to go higher).
[*] White, Black and Grey digital camo skin for the MiG-29. (a.k.a.: The Ghost[s] of Kyiv)
[*] [i]Iron Eagle[/i] skin for the F-16.
[*] A friendly shout-out to [i]Project Wingman[/i] in the form of Monarch's (two-seater) plane skins.
[*] Emblems for the rest of [i]iDOLM@STER[/i]'s 765 Pro and 346 Pro girls, or better yet:
[*] Bring back the [i]iDOLM@STER[/i] plane skins as free-LC. (Bonus points for contemporary versions of the 765 Pro girls, new skins for the 346 Pro girls, and colored missile trails.)
[/list]

[b][i]The Verdict/TL;DR:[/i][/b]
- A welcome return to Strangereal with a single-player experience that's reminiscent of the PS2 "Holy Trinity," but somewhat bogged down by rudimentary multiplayer, multiple paid DLC (while acknowledging there are worse examples) and the lack of a "Definitive Edition" that includes all of them.

[b]4/5 Stars.[/b] (If all DLC was included in one big Definitive Edition, this would at least be a 4.5, if not a 5.)

Thank you for reading!

DE NOSTALGIA A VACA LEITEIRA - COMBATENDO OS VERDADEIROS 'ACES' EM MAMAR EMPRESA OPORTUNISTA

Meu primeiro contato com mundo do Ace Combat foi pelo Ace Combat 3 (NTSC-U) nos bons tempos de PlayStation 1. Lembro-me perfeitamente do meu amigo me emprestando esse jogo, falando que era de "nave" e que era bem difícil (não saiu da terceira missão) e eu topei pelo suposto desafio. Com falas iniciais de "Engage" ou "Intercept", "Bullseye", "Caution, damage" durante missões, dentre outros, fui me divertindo com a vastidão de fases que o jogo proporcionava, junto a diversas aeronaves diferentes de nosso mundo (algumas somente similares em visual). Strangereal não era uma palavra familiar, o jogo em si foi "castrado" quando saiu do Japão (2 CDs) e virou um mero Arcade como Air Combat e Air Combat 22, nem mesmo se tinha elementos de compra e venda de aeronaves do Ace Combat 2 (jogo que, ironicamente, conheci e joguei bem depois do Ace Combat Zero).

Na chegada do PlayStation 2, eu clamei pelos jogos Ace Combat de tal plataforma, tanto que Zero foi o primeiro jogo quando adquiri a plataforma e eu fiquei em todo hype possível para os outros jogos. Por algum motivo eu não conseguia encontrar o Ace Combat 4, mas o 5 foi deveras fácil.

Porém houve um choque um pouco desagradável, inclusive quando se tratou de enredo e narrativa.

Ace Combat 3 (NTSC-U) mal contexto tinha, somente um punhado de informações jogadas estilo Metal Black, G-Darius ou qualquer outro jogo Arcade dos anos 90 (ou meados de 80). Ace Combat 2 foi mais elaborado, mas Ace Combat Zero conseguiu se superar com seu vasto enredo sobre uma guerra que dividiu nações, opiniões e foi o tapete vermelho para o advento de algumas ideologias mais extremas. Com diversas nações envolvidas, muito se deu pra tirar desse jogo, assim como do 4 e do 5, mas com menos impacto.

Todavia, o meu ponto, agora, parte-se do "nichismo" da NAMCO em querer prospectar uma fanbase diferente com uma jogada de enredo estilo anime e personagens com características bem comparáveis ao Shonen. Apesar de ter sido lançado 2 anos antes do Zero, Ace Combat 5, com a tentativa dos desenvolvedores em promover uma "aproximação maior do jogador com os personagens", debruçou-se numa caracterização desnecessária dos seus aliados, empobrecendo um pouco a narrativa e preenchendo buracos de criatividade com clichés. Quando cheguei no Ace Combat 6 (fiz questão de comprar o Xbox 360 só para poder jogá-lo), decepcionei-me mais ainda com a evolução reversa que foi-me proporcionada, desta vez não somente pela narrativa e enredo fraquíssimos, como também pelas novas mecânicas desastrosas que aplicaram no jogo numa tentativa frustrada de dar aquele ar de "muitas unidades em combate para enriquecer o campo de batalha".

Recuso-me a falar sobre Ace Combat: Assault Horizon, quem já jogou e possui ao menos dois neurônios funcionando já vai entender.

Após um certo tempo e alguns jogos catastróficos, eles voltam mais uma vez com outro jogo exclusivo (eles não aprendem), chamado Ace Combat Infinity. Eu não tive interesse em comprar o PS3, larguei o Ace Combat de lado, mas fiquei com aquela falta de um bom jogo de aeronaves de combate. O jogo não foi muito bem aclamado, já que muitos jogadores raiz reclamavam de um uso de certo 'combustível' para realizar missões, fora as microtransações que infestaram o jogo junto às diversas atualizações. O jogo foi aceitável, mas poderia ter sido bem melhor (isso não querendo dizer que NAMCO e Project Aces estavam no desespero, mas já dizendo).

Depois de anos em hiato, e com o lançamento do ilustre Project Wingman, NAMCO se sentiu no dever de lançar algo ao mesmo nível, senão superior, mais robusto, com muito mais características e algumas do próprio Infinity. Fãs ficaram 'hypados' com o anúncio e aquele trailer daquelas aeronaves em combate, mostrando as bandeiras de Osea e Erusea, da mesma forma de (mais uma) outra aeronave gigante que serviria de "chefe" para derrubarmos. Houve pré-venda, muitos, inclusive eu, já adquirimos de cara na hora que ofertaram.

Mas foi outro desastre de narrativa e o enredo foi pior que Morbius.

Como se já não bastasse a decepção no enredo do jogo em si, recheado de 'cliches', momentos altamente cringe estilo Ace Combat 5, versão kumbaya, e péssima implementação de personagens que colocaram em risco a lore inteira do Ace Combat, implicando num "reboot" em alguns aspectos da série, destruindo a herança e legado de alguns títulos impressionantes, como 3, 4, Zero e X, o multiplayer conseguiu cavar mais fundo a cova da NAMCO (Bandai NAMCO agora), com dois modos absolutamente ridículos que tentaram seguir das febres do nicho dos First-Person Shooter, como Call of Duty e PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds, respectivamente, sendo Team Deathmatch e Battle Royale.

Team Deathmatch, como o próprio nome sugere, times (somente 2) lutando pela supremacia, porém somente abatendo uns aos outros (alvos extras, competição PVE/PVP? Esqueça).
Battle Royale, por outro lado, seria algo do tipo 64 aeronaves? 32? Mapa com 64x64 ou 128x128 quilômetros? 256x256? Você está pedindo demais. Dou-lhe 8 aeronaves numa embalagem de geladeira e olhe lá.

Última vez que toquei nesse jogo foi há quase 2 anos atrás. Esperei por muito tempo uma atualização, uma esperança de que o jogo voltasse a valer a pena de jogar e ser devidamente 'rejogável', mas, depois daquelas três missões do Senhor Dez Milhões, fiquei bem cabisbaixo.

E tinha como piorar mais ainda. Você quer um novo modo de multiplayer? Espere enquanto aloco toda a equipe para unicamente em banir jogadores que utilizaram trapaças e realizaram outras atividades maliciosas. Você quer mais aeronaves? Quer usar aquela sua favorita do seu jogo favorito ou uma pintura específica que você guarda no coração? Pague por eles. (Existem 'mods', para quem não sabe). Filme está para lançar? Por que não extrair mais leite desta vaca moribunda e esbelta?

O jogo tinha muita capacidade e até um mero jogo que começou com crowdfunding conseguiu ser infinitamente melhor, completo e com planos futuros a frente (planos que podem ser tão grandes quanto o jogo em si e eu pagaria com prazer se fosse DLC, assim como meu outro favorito, Stellaris).

O mais triste é ver que os desenvolvedores do Project Wingman se inspiraram no Ace Combat, eram fãs assim como eu e vocês, mas tenho quase certeza de que estão tão decepcionados quanto eu (e as mentes sanas da fanbase), tão decepcionados quanto Elon Musk quando Neil Armstrong, um herói para ele, disse que o projeto do SpaceX e vôos comerciais espaciais eram uma catástrofe.

Mas, é aquilo, se tem bajulador pra comprar e não se arrepender, sempre terá títulos catastróficos assim e status quo seguirá o mesmo, usando nostalgia para vender, mas sem entregar com sua devida dignidade.

Been a longtime fan of this series since the PS2 titles.
Already played through this plenty of times on PS4 + the VR Exclusive Campaign, but saw a too good steam sale and re-bought this for PC, including my idea of essential DLC's.

Regardless if it were on sale or not, I highly recommend this!
For a PC port, it's very well optimized!
Even a mid-range PC could handle this game, as long as you have a dedicated GPU or a decent APU.

As for gameplay, it is by far the best in the series.
Aside from High-G turns which were introduced in Ace Combat 6 (Xbox 360 Exclusive), you have clouds to deal with. The latter can affect your aircraft's overall abilities and maneuverability. It adds more strategy in the game vs. the previous titles. It's a double-edged sword to keep it short, but when used correctly, it can yield victorious results in a dogfight.

Of course this isn't Ace Combat without its amazing soundtrack, composed by the venerable Keiki Kobayashi!
There are moments where the soundtrack will either pause or intensify in certain story scenes/events in missions.

The story, it is basically what you would expect in an Ace Combat title. It always starts with a rookie pilot racking up their kills to a point they become feared by opposing forces and a rival of a venerable enemy ace from said opposing forces. Then you got your waifu figures, and cutscenes giving a glimpse of the opposing side, seeing who really sent the game's two nations into fighting the whole time.
#BelkaDidNothingWrong

There are quite a few things I wish were brought back into this however...
-Squadron Commands 
 *Introduced in Ace Combat 5, last seen in Ace Combat 6 with additional features.

-Squadron Plane and Weapon Selection
*Introduced in Ace Combat 5 but only limited to planes, Zero only lets you change SP weapon, 6 lets you do both.

-Plane Animations/Interactions while in the hangar or before a sortie 
 *Animations were a thing since Ace Combat 5 but interactions were introduced in Zero where you push a button and the plane will close its canopy while all the moving bits do their thing. (1/2)
 *The interactions were taken a step further in 6 wherein you could inspect the cockpit, and move the ailerons, flaps, elevators, etc. manually while in the hangar as if you were flying the plane but stationary. (2/2)

-Mission Choices
*Ace Combat 3 was the first to implement this with multiple story paths, Ace Combat Zero had its own solid concept which ace styles and operation choices, alongside with Ace Combat X Skies of Deception's mission paths that affect other missions and the story's outcome.

-Co-op or Versus Co-op
*Ace Combat Infinity had fun PvE modes where two teams of players fight against enemy AI and try to get the highest kill scores possible until the end of the match. Whichever team/squadron that has the most points wins. This would be a great ice breaker from the sweaty PvP Dogfights where meta planes, set-ups and etc. would be less of a problem and still breathe more life into the Multiplayer aspect of Ace Combat 7.

All these nitpicks aside, I knew that Ace Combat 7 went through development hell, considering its well deserved success at the end of it.
I'm sure some, if not most of these past features will be re-implemented in their next title.

This is the first time I played another Ace Combat since Ace Combat 2 on the Playstation 1 and I was actually suprised how little things have changed. I mean, the graphics are vastly improved obviously and there are some gimmick weapons now but the core gameplay is still the very same as well as the interface when flying around and locking missiles onto enemies. 
What I really liked was that they really nailed the atmosphere. I really enjoyed flying around and the game showed me how cool these planes are. 
I finished the game in roughly 15h which easily could've been less because of 2 reasons.
1. The game kinda gave me this constant feeling that I will not achieve the mission goal in time. The timer in the top left corner of the screen and the constant stressed out radio calls in my ear made me fly more risky. This basically lead to several re-dos of missions whenever I crashed or got shot down. And since the checkpoints are ackwardly placed that meant repeating a 10-15 minute part of the mission several times, Getting shot at is especially nervewracking when you can't clear out non-objective targets to give you more room to breath without risking a barrage of rockets on your ass, because you feel like the time will run out otherwise. Especially in combination with the fact that the missions take unexpected turns, it felt like I had to focus on objectives only without taking care of non-objective targets. 
Also the story is absolutly bonkers. I don't know if it it because of me skipping so many games of the series or the actual writing but after 15h and a whole campagain, I still only got a general sense of what the game wanted to tell me. I still don't really know which country is which and it didn't help that the game introduced several other countries as plot devices later on. Also, telling a story in-mission and over radio calls while me plane is pursued by 1829 missiles at once, is always a brave decision. 
Other than that, I had a good time and I'm looking forward to the next entry. But not at full price :)
Yes
Spectacular.

Cool Jets - but you don't have to learn how to fly them. 
The campaign is filled with excellent missions with action and surprisingly some puzzle solving as well. 

Its not that easy, you will crash, fail missions, get shot down - and there are no checkpoints. 
You could be on a 20 minute mission - crash on the last minute - and have to start again. 
But once you figure out what is required - either it be tactic or setup - you will want to try again and get that S ranking on the mission. 

There is a big tree of upgrades and planes for you to grind out 

Multiplayer is ok - easy enough to find servers, you will be flying in circles a lot - its the best and quickest way to get credits and unlock the planes. 

Graphically it holds up - you can tell a lot of care and detail went into modelling the planes - but this is not a sim, don't expect perfection here. 

Overall - I have enjoyed my time in Ace Combat - it can be infuriating or exhilarating and I'm here for the ride.

I would give "Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown" a 4 out of 5. The game is a fantastic addition to the "Ace Combat" franchise, offering breathtaking aerial combat and stunning graphics. The campaign is well-written and offers a good variety of missions, and the multiplayer mode provides a fun and competitive experience. Ace Combat 7 has pretty big shoes to fill coming off of the masterpieces that are the PS2 era Ace games (Ace 4, 5 and Zero). 

Did it fill them for me? Eh, kinda. It's a modern Ace experience that's full of challenge where the right secondary weapons make the difference between a neckbreaking clear and guarenteed failure on Hard, but the story for me didn't hit the same as Ace Combat 5 (and I replayed the PS2 games just the year before).

That being said, there's still a great experience here. I put Ace 5 and Zero on a pedestal for some of the best games I've played, so to say that it's as good as Ace 4 is a nice spot (8/10 for both).

Ace Combat 7 is an air combat game released in 2019. I would describe it as an 'arcade sim.' It is to flight sims what something like Forza Horizon is to racing games - something that's way more realistic than a Mario Kart or Ridge Racer, and focuses on gorgeous presentation of fully licensed vehicles, but which nonetheless takes a lot of liberties to give you a fun experience moreso than a strict simulation.

It is the first mainline entry in the series since 2007's Ace Combat 6 (X360), so it was the revival of a dormant series. This arcade sim flight combat genre is one that was really popular back in the day with Ace Combat 4, 5, Zero, and the very similar Rogue Squadron games, but which has basically ceased to exist in recent years. I don't know why that is, but I'm glad it's been revived.

---{ Graphics and Art Direction }---
☐ I want to live in this world
☑️ Beautiful
☐ Functional
☐ Bad

One of the fortes of the game, for sure. The art direction is excellent so that, even running with the settings turned down on Steam Deck, the game looks gorgeous. The planes are (with one exception) all real and modelled with enough care to make /r/warplaneporn blush; the clouds are beautifully rendered; as you pass through them tiny droplets form on the camera and refract sunlight as you emerge from them again; sunsets are like photos. Weak point is ground and building textures, but if you’re close enough to see those you’re about to crash. 

---{ Gameplay }---
☐ Hall of fame
☑️ Keeps me coming back for more
☐ Fun enough for a few hours
☐ Watch paint dry instead

The other forte. The controls are wonderful and there’s real joy in zipping about dogfighting enemies. It’s just plain simple fun. 

---{ Story / Writing / Lore }---
☐ Deserves a Pulitzer
☐ Wouldn’t be out of place on a bookshelf
☐ Nothing special
☑️ Written by teenagers
☐ No Story

Awful. The plot and characterizations are barely intelligible drivel. You can skip story cutscenes, but unfortunately a lot of the stupidity is shoved down your throat during mission briefings, which you kind of need to pay attention to because they tell you what your objective is.

---{ Music and Audio }---
☐ Earned a permanent spot in my playlist
☑️ Enjoyable
☐ I didn’t notice it
☑️ Mute immediately

Music is good, though not as good as some previous entries. Planes sound great. Unfortunately, the terrible writing continues to be forced down your throat during missions as your wingmates chatter stupid shit nonstop. I would suggest muting it, but unfortunately the radio chatter sometimes give you important mission updates that are essential for you to know what you’re supposed to do. 

---{ Difficulty }---
☐ Walking simulator
☐ You can technically die, but you probably won’t
☑️ Easy to learn / Hard to master
☑️ Frustrating
☐ Dark Souls

Not exactly Dark Souls, but surprisingly difficult. Basic enemies are no pushovers and will dogfight you hard. Even on Normal, some missions needed multiple runs before I succeeded. I would say it sometimes leans into frustrating territory. One particular type of enemy is almost unfair in its mobility, and too many missions have multiple « mission updates » where the goalposts are moved in the middle of the action. You usually get checkpoints when this happens, but it’s annoying. Sometimes the new objectives don’t match the kit you’ve brought on your plane, and if you want to back out and change your loadout you have to start the mission over from the beginning.

---{ System Requirements }---
☐ Could run on a Samsung smart fridge
☑️ Modern console or decent PC
☐ Ask NASA if they have a spare computer

Runs great on Deck

---{ Length }---
☐ <10 hours
☑️ 10-25 hours
☐ 25-100 hours
☐ Hundreds of hours, if you want

About 15 hours to play through campaign, although these games are designed to be played through multiple times - you won’t be able to unlock all planes on your first playthrough for example.

---{ Value }---
☐ Buy it twice
☐ Worth full price
☑️ If it's on sale
☐ Not recommended

Overall 7/10 - there’s the bones of a stellar game here, but it’s a bit buried behind some poor mission designs and writing that saps your will to go on. Only recommend this if you’re a fan of the genre and you can plug your ears sometimes. Otherwise not recommended.

Pro:  
- It is Ace Combat and it is finally on PC  
- None of that Assault Horizon nonesense just plain good old Ace Combat gameplay.  
- //edit: Denuvo has been removed 

Con:  
- Game was delayed after console launch.  
- No Ultrawide Support (there are some user made solutions on WSGF, but this really should be officially supported)  
- No Field of View slider (if Forza Horizon 4 and even Anthem can have FOV Sliders, so can this!)  
- Flight Sticks are only supported for Thrustmaster, because Thrustmaster has some promotional contract with the Developer, but they only thought about Consoles so only the Thrusmaster HOTAS Flight Sticks that happen to work on Xbox and PS4 as well as PC are supported. -> so Xbox gamepad it is. (i hope you like stick drift)  
- VR Missions one year exclusive to PS4, don't expect them to add it to PC after that time.  
- They sell a Season Pass, don't tell us what is inside or when the content is being released, i would have liked to support this game with more money to welcome them on PC as i love the Ace Combat series, but i'm not buying content unless i know if its single or multiplayer.  
- The game has been released a while ago now and i find the Patch Support lacking. The game doesn't have huge technical issues but there have been few patches and the latest one didn't even have patchnotes posted.  

Well, those are the technical pro's and con's.  

The game is very much fun, and i do recommend it to anybody who ever played and liked any title in the AC series and to anyone who wants a simple short Arcade Jet Shooter game.  

Sadly this is a lazy Console Port and it is obvious that PC has been an afterthought for the Developer, none of this is rocket science to address but they just don't seem to care.

I think the Ace Combat 7 is rather weaker entry. But my bias is I've played Ace Combat 4, 5, Zero, and Assault Horizon plus Project Wingman. And I put 5 and Zero as the standard for judging Ace Combat 7.
FIrst, squad is naught but formality. "Mantain element"? Hah! That aside, why couldn't they bring feature of older titles like choosing wingmen's aircrafts and commanding them? At least make player capable to command AI wingmen and their kills is counted as squad leader's so players don't have to be frustrated if their kills are stolen. And also, I do really wish there's time where I can change my wingmen's aircrafts like Ace Combat 5 did in the future. Then the story and levels, I find it as strong as Ace Combat 4, okay a bit stronger since there are less "destroy until certain amount of score reached". Quite straightforward. I don't have issue with that except three striking Osea, Erusea, and even nation aren't felt necessary because the enemy is still Erusea, the enemy we're facing from start, and we're playing for Osea or coalition cause. Compare that to Blaze's story as Osean soldier which see him fight against radicals of Osean and Yuktobanian and his involvement along with his squad and people they who support the cause to rescue the leaders for respective nation. And also I think Project Wingman is better at making single player story.
Even all the drawbacks I've mentioned before, using back the Strangereal to the game is something is good to see. And story about princess itself is quite serviceable, from a princess that declares the war for brighter future only for her to see how bad battles and war could be, even her people are divided. So finally she wanted to redeem herself, by doing some risque acts near the end of story. And then finally, Ace Combat 7 brings post-stall maneuvers without QTE like Ace Combat Assault Horizon. Also, combination of Strangereal world and more recent technology made the world more beautiful. Despite the beauty, my computer that is mid can keep the FPS consistent and smooth animation. This is something that I found in Ace Combat 7 but not in Project Wingman (of course it's reasonable, since PW gives more enemies to shoot and the gamr is full of bright orange-red lights). Plus some additional stuffs like checkpoint making 4 tier of difficulties instead of five are welcome. Control is easy that using keyboard (and mouse) for me is enough to enjoy the game.
In the end, despite how many drawbacks I've seen in this game by recalling its predecessor, I still recommend people to buy Ace Combat 7. But, on sale.

Another fine addition to the wonderful world of Ace Combat. Despite lacking many awesome features that AC5 and AC Zero have, and having a decent story line (not as amazing as AC5 or AC Zero), the game delivers fun action. It's not an Ace Combat game if it doesn't have battles with titanic aircraft carriers or humongous weapons, flying through a ravine in low altitude to get to an objective, flying through tight tunnels at fast speed and fighting intense boss battles with highly sophisticated aircraft. Now the only thing I wished for this game was to be a bit longer, had a better story line, and had some proper Japanese to English translation. This was an  improvement on that last part, yet it still needs some improvements. Looking forward to the next AC game (or hopefully a remastered version of previous games since it's today's trend to do that)

This is how you make a video game!

- Nice enough graphics, supports +120 Hz and optimised to run like that on higher mid-range PC
- Good soundtrack, good voice acting
- Actually interesting narrative/story/lore
- Impeccable cinematic style. 

Some of the available aircraft is licensed by real manufacturers but the game isn't an ultra-serious simulator by any means. It is a fun, narrative driven power fantasy where planes manoeuvre in a way that makes controlling them approachable while still feeling "real" and logical to a noob pilot like myself. Difficulty sliders help prevent getting stuck in your progress.

I am enjoying this game, so much so that I have just spent the last 3 hours playing non-stop, an interesting story line with lots of combat flying. This is the first time since childhood that I have played a combat flight sim and the graphics and flight physics make very enjoyable game play.

Campaign and script have a strong - and slightly annoying - air of "hero worship" about them which isn't present in other Ace Combat games (at least Ace Combat 6), but beyond that the gameplay, graphics, and sound quality are exquisite! Highly recommend if you enjoy aerial combat games!

Ace Combat always impresses me with how great and consistent it is. The gameplay is similar to the previous games but it still manages to keep me interested. You'll do everything from destroying ground targets, sinking fleets, providing escort, and dogfighting other pilots and you're given lots of choices on how to do it. Ace Combat 7 isn't lacking depth. The game added new things like a weather system which change battle conditions in drastic ways. Some people understandably find the weather system to be annoying, as it makes even basic actions like navigating and finding targets harder, but I appreciate the new layer of challenge in a game which can already be challenging at times. 

The campaign is very replayable. You can't do everything in one playthrough. You won't unlock every plane in one playthrough but your progress carries over to the next run. You'll likely have missed out on challenges on a normal playthrough, like shooting down every enemy Ace pilot. The hardest difficulty isn't available until after the first playthrough. You don't even unlock plane skins until the second playthrough. There's even a multiplayer mode I haven't touched yet, which undoubtedly makes the game more replayable.

Ace Combat 7 doesn't reinvent the wheel but that's not a bad thing in this case. It reminds me of the legendary PS2 trilogy of Ace Combat games it's not too far removed from the PS1 games. It's a good place to start if you're new to the series. I would recommend it.

Second Review - 2.5 years later (spoilers)  kinda

This game went on sale and honestly just had to give it a shot.   got it on sale for I think 9.99.  
this game by just as a flying game and not part of the AC series.  it was an alright arcade game.   I got it on sale and helped with some of the bad taste i had when i first tried the game at full price.   

I tried to appreciate development of this game but it still just wasn't a great game.    a few extra planes some better models with more polygons.  I understand this is a semi-realistic arcade flight style game and I just hoped they pushed closer to realistic.  

 I honestly feel like it was just repeat of Ace combat 5.  fly a mission and defend a base getting attacked.  defend and counter strike - something happens and now you are the hero/protagonist and all other pilots hate your presence in the air until you show them that you are the ACE.    missions feel similar.  a super structure of vehicle shows up and drones attack.  oh no. run away.   engage elsewhere super weapon able to fire large scale weapons and avoid the circles where the bombs blow up.  survive and go again later.   attempt rescue of important political figure.  fails.   fly a mission around radars attack a base.  main enemy shows up.   do a surprise attack and fly through a canyon under radar.   there are people guard posts with spot lights in the canyon that if they see you you fail the mission but can hear a jet flying at low altitude near them.   ( understand arcade but come on)  insert a couple more missions and chase the boss underground through a tunnel underground and fight underground and blow him/it up. yay end campaign.  

I personally wont buy another AC series game again unless they revamp their flight style.  
again the game by its self and not comparing it to anything.  its an alright game almost 4 out 5.   but for me.  this game was a good way to spend several hours playing but once it was done did not want to go back through and replay the campaign.  

sorry for such a sourpuss review.  if you like arcade style flight games this would be a great game.  if you haven't played the AC series again a great game to experience.  In my opinion this game has done so well because of nostalgia compared to breaking the limits of game development.  




(first review July of 2019)-
Ace Combat 7... I have been a fan of AC series for a while.  AC 4-6.   So when i saw they had 7 in the oven.. I was a little more than excited about the release.  And just as i was to my father... this game was to me... A disappointment.   so here is the run down.  

Graphics pretty good.  a couple moving gauges in the cockpit.  okay thank you.   sound ehhh 50/50/have nothing good or bad.  that is about it.   played the game on the hardest difficulty played for about and hour and a half and just could feel the pain.  like taking a puppy from a kid.  The good hurt.   I was hoping that this game that came out almost 12 years after the last one was going to tap into something more.   NOPE for the price of 59.99 you get the same physics/handling/and terrible AI that you would get from a game that is 15-12 years old.  but hey the water affect on the canopy while doing mach jesus makes it worth it.  

So if you are new to flight "sims" go ahead i think you will like it.  If you have a little bit more experience with games like this or you are looking for the new and revamped installment of Ace Combat.  Im sorry but just like my father you wont find it.

Ace combat 7: Skies Unknown, is the epitome of freedom in a video game. Swooping and soaring through the sky is now one of my favorite gaming experiences. The process of learning to fly your ever growing arsenal of aircraft in the wide open skies and then using that practice to complete increasingly difficult missions was always as exciting. I found myself always looking towards the next challenge wondering what could be next. The story was not always the most interesting but the characters and rivalries where very fun and endearing. finally the music ties all of the rest of the game up so perfectly with a beautiful ost covering a wide range of emotional. 
Please play this game if you have any interest in it!
I will look to play more in this genre asap.

If you're looking for a great aerial combat game, then this is by far one of the best that you're going to find. Solid 9/10.

Commercial trailers made me think this game is about fighting AI and gigantic escalating storyplots in witty japanese storytelling style, but its only a tiny part of it, and its not really witty. Its mostly about current political mainstream ideas such...
SPOILER :
 such as open borders are so cool, "refugees" coming for resources are the best thing (no really, its the end) and baed old man finally parts from his way so all the underage looking girls GeT inTo PoWer , yaaas slay queen, finally they can make star trek happen yaaaasszZzzzZz... 
It's story only challenges your patience and left me feeling or thinking jackshit except writing my disappointment and describing the disengagement. At least they didnt start rapping or play the racecard all the time. Actually one part of the story is sort of unexpected non-pc in that regard, but I wont spoil that part if you actually wanna buy the game. But I doubt it would manage to create any wowzers.

The videos are really nice looking , the average grafics are good, but the pacing of the storytelling feels just weird. It tries to be poetic and fails mostly. Would rather watch Snake talking about nanomachines or just  watch some action flic, because there is just not much that I even care to remember here.

Gameplay was ok at times but I see no point getting more airplanes since most missions feel rather tedious and dull. I wish they'd just embrace the arcade part more, ditch the expensive licenses and did more gameplay testing / design more cool enemies, a sense of accomplishment... 

Instead you just slow down , do a u-turn-  shoot missile, hope enemy does come from the right angle or else missile of course misses despite lock on or just fly in their face and shoot minigun... or force yourself to reaally fly super slow. Actually a lot of time thats the key to victory..being slow..in an action game.. ok.
A shit ton of time the game creates tension by protecting someone or something or stuff thats hard to miss (have fun crashing against tunnelwalls, flying against walls in a hall , yes a hall,  etc) . Is it even an action game ? A patience game ? A dont hit anything accidentally game ?  OH the terrible checkpoints at times.
A few missions are a bit of a tech spectacle, the clouds are nice and the first thunder is cool... but that doesnt make it a classic , especially with time moving on. 

I'd give it a middle thumb, but that does not exist so there it goes, a thumb down to balance the other reviews eh ? No hard feelings..  

Oh and the Soundtrack is really good. meh.

The game where reality takes a back seat and absurdity takes the wheel. The gameplay is simple enough for a caveman to understand, but that's not a bad thing, it's actually quite enjoyable. The visuals are stunning, like a beautiful painting, but with the added bonus of explosions and planes. The sound design is like a symphony of destruction, truly beautiful. The story is like an anime, where logic and physics are just suggestions, but it's so ridiculous that it's hard not to like it. If you're looking for a game that will make you question reality, this is it, 8/10

I didn't expect much from this game when I bought it on sale, just thought that it looked graphically impressive while still something my machine can handle. I've never played an Ace Combat game before, and the flight games I usually play include the likes of Star Fox 64 and Star Wars: Rogue Squadron. I was immediately [b]blown away[/b] by AC7. The difficulty settings are [i]just right[/i], the gameplay is fun and addictive while feeling fairly realistic, and even after playing through the campaign dozens of times I just want to keep playing more of this. Buying all the DLC felt like a no-brainer, and am I glad I did - all the content is amazing! 

tl:dr if you're thinking about buying this, just do it. Let's show the industry that we love quality games like this one that don't push the "games as a service" loot box crap on us.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for his birthday from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me learn the controls. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Game will not let you remap controls. Seems many have asked specifically for YAW controls to be able to be remapped to a different stick or mouse axis, but devs dont seem to listen. Tried looking up a manual way to do this a couple weeks after purchasing with no success, and since i waited longer than 14 days to ask for a refund, it was denied, even with 50 min of game time played. 
Pls add a way to map controls on PC  like every other AAA game does in current year. Calling the control scheme advanced but limiting input mapping to keyboard only is a joke. I dont make games but i would assume allowing full remapping of controls to keyboard and mouse inputs and mouse axis wouldnt be that hard of a task for a studio who has been making games for years. Flight stick controls work, but i couldnt change the sensitivity of the stick inputs, only mouse sensitivity can be changed.  
Gameplay is good, but the lack of ability to change the yaw axis, basically breaking pitch and roll out to two different sticks on a controller or map yaw to a mouse x axis instead of using a keyboard makes it so any BF player who has flown like that for years has to relearn controls to be able to enjoy this game.

- Great visuals

The Bad:

The Ugly:
- DLC is relatively expensive

First AC game I've ever played but not exactly unfamiliar with flight sims in general as I had experience with a mobile series (check out Sky Gamblers if you're interested). And oh boy this game is spectacular, although it only does well what it set out to do, which is an arcade flight game.

Visuals and sounds are really good, but I would've preferred it if there were actual damage marks such as bullet holes or lingering fire effects instead of a small burst of flame that goes away after a few seconds. Engine sounds are also pretty quiet, but I've heard that they're very audible in VR mode, so give that a try if it feels underwhelming in the main game.

Gameplay and flight mechanics are in line with my previous flight sim experience, and they're pretty tight. Highly recommended to use a controller as it's pretty frustrating to play with a mouse (possible, but had to bind pitching up/down to the back/forward buttons). I was a bit surprised when there were no blackouts/redouts when doing consecutive high-G turns, but having played through the campaign at least once I hope they will never add them in because it'd be impossible to play.

The story on the other hand is in a pretty weird spot. It's not bad, but as the 7th main installment in the series, the game assumes you have a general understanding of the preceding plot events and characters, which can be tough for a lot of people who have this as their first AC game. But there are a lot of YTers out there who do a pretty good job at summing up the previous AC stories to give you better context of AC7, so it's not exactly a huge problem.

Aside from the main campaign, there are 3 DLC missions that I would recommend getting via the Top Gun Maverick Ultimate Edition during a sale to save the most money possible (it's 80% off so don't be tempted at any time during the normal prices). DLC planes are up to personal preference as they're quite pricey and not in any way necessary to enjoy the full game (note that the Season Pass [b] DO NOT [/b] unlock access to all the DLC planes, only the 3 specified in the description alongside the extra missions). As for multiplayer I haven't touched it yet, so there isn't anything I can say.

Overall a good game that's really worth the money (again, during sale).

Story is sub-par with complex background and annoying NPC's, unlocks are pricey and required too many missions to unlock planes and parts. Missions are often boring, tying you on a leash: escort a cargo helicopter or plane, stay in the clouds, remain as low altitude as possible ... You are rarely free to just fight other jets. Mission will often require you to pick a specific jet to use a specific special weapon (like long range air to ground missiles) to help you complete objectives. Some mission will have a secret objective who would require a completely different plane then the one you choose for the main mission.  

Overall its not a bad title but I was expecting a lot more freedom for an arcade type jet game ...

Campaign missions are so repetitive and dull most of the time. I'm just dodging missiles and pressing A on the controller. Enemies just don't know how to dogfight, and bosses are more challenging simply because their aircraft are using magic, an instantly 90-degree turn? Easy! I don't see any chance of defeating the Erusian army since they've already found a way to defeat physics. And the game levels are just like physics itself: Not hard, just too many of them.

I understand this is not a hardcore game, so most game mechanisms are unrealistic, but this unrealness is too much for me. For example, to finish this game, you don't need any missiles; just use your gun, few shots are enough to wipe out a cruiser, and there is no ammo limit (at least in normal difficulty). Those magical manipulations also made fighters like toys.

Btw, considering the size of the game, the max resolution of 1080P is a joke.

More frustrating than fun.

So I ended up replaying every mission where you have to get a certain score in x minutes because there aren't, or i couldn't find, any weapons to effectively destroy ground units.  One mission has you guiding in bombs by holding you cross-hair on a target for a few seconds while constantly being shot at by missiles etc.  It's fine because there are 10 or so targets but a similar mechanic happens again over the course of a handful of missions where to even figure out if you should be shooting at any target, you have to ID it by flying close with it in the middle of your screen for what seems to be way too long.  Another mission where you need to shoot trucks that blip in and out of radar for whatever reason.  I gave up on the game in the fly into the death star mission these games all seem to love because it's a maze of nonsense where I'm constantly crashing.  The tech tree is another source of frustration because it's 1) too zoomed in to view any reasonable amount of info for what to get and 2) an annoyingly long little animation plays every single time you purchase something.

Absolute garbage game. It wont let you customize joystick controls or use a head tracker to play it. Top that off witch how terribly unrealistic it is and your better off not even wasting your time with it.

**NOTE ABOUT JOYSTICK**
For some reason, Steam refuses outright to detect my Extreme Pro 3D, and in AC7 the controls weren't mapped by default in the game. Even though the controller was detected I couldn't control anything, and from what I found searching around it's a somewhat common issue (both with Steam not detecting, and button/axis mapping within AC7). With no joystick mapping available within the game's options, I had to edit the input.ini file in C:\Users\*user*\AppData\Local\BANDAI NAMCO Entertainment\ACE COMBAT 7\Config\Input.ini with the proper mappings and it works alright with some fine-tuning. Just wanted to leave this as a heads up, maybe save somebody a headache.

That being said,

Very fun, easy to get into and just enough customization to feel meaningful without getting complicated. I'm only on the 6 or 7th mission, and so far the missions have been engaging and varied in objective with a pretty decent story line (as far as I've seen, anyway). The flight is fun and feels immersive, and runs beautifully on my 6700xt. I was playing a few other games until I picked up an old Extreme Pro 3D flight stick, and pretty much dropped everything else because I keep coming back to this game when I can play.

I somehow finished this game and really enjoyed it. I don't see the credits roll often for games, but this was a fun and engaging game through most of the 15 hour campaign. The controls took some getting used to playing on the controller, but you can't rebind any of the controls however. The 20 missions were varied enough while still focusing on what this game does best, and thats bombing runs. Sadly dogfighting became monotonous near the end, watching enemies on radar and in sight just defy the laws of physics (and sometimes reality). The missile warnings were  annoying as well near the end and you can't mute it without muting the game. The story was fun but yet a little disjointed.

It's still a pretty good game, it felt amazing launching multi missile projectiles and seeing them all reach their target in unison on the ground, dodging rockets, and pulling maneuvers like a Top Gun graduate. I only wish the controls were rebindable, the AI didn't cheat so much, and the storytelling be a little better.

I'd say this is a well deserved 3/5, a good game to pick up on sale. The DLC is OP as hell, but still fun and worth getting.

AC7 has a lousy story with a terrible anti-conservative message that is too hard to ignore. It's the first game in the franchise to glorify war while bombarding the audience with endless nihilistic dialogue from the most annoying characters ever put into a video game. The gameplay is flashy, with lots of explosions but overall lacks depth. The boss battles are just a matter of bashing the missile button until the Boss finishes saying all the unnecessary dialogue, so the level can finally be over. Lastly, while the graphics are good, they are far from mind-blowing, especially the cockpit textures that look overly cartoony compared to the exterior model.

this game makes me uniquely frustrated, and not for good reasons

oh, you think dogfighting is the best part of the game, do you? here, have a fucking POS mission where you hunt down trucks in the middle of a storm. bombing is fun, isn't it? it isn't? well have about ten more

this game is at its best when you're dogfighting, but unfortunately i think that dogfighting was only about 30-40% of the actual campaign, at least in a way that actually progresses the mission. the rest of the 60-70% is hitting static targets on the ground, repeatedly doing bombing runs to grind up your score/fulfill a target quota (fucking trucks in the storm) and accepting that C- so you could get to the fun bits again.

I understand that bombing is integral to the core of aircraft combat in general, but "oh wow they're so faithful to the aircraft experience" was the last thing I was thinking every time i failed a point mission because I didn't hit enough or I was shot down when the POS allied AIs did nothing to distract the four enemies shooting missiles at me simultaneously while I was hitting targets.

Unironically the best point mission was where you hit the oil fields, and it wasn't because it was fun; it was because it was conveniently fast due to chain reaction explosions and that meant I could get to the dogfighting parts quicker, rather than true entertainment.

I like this game a lot, even if I seem really negative toward one particular aspect of it. But that aspect is so bad that those aforementioned missions are impossible if you went down an aircraft tree branch that has subpar bombers, requiring you to farm (yes, farm) earlier missions or the multiplayer for currency so you can unlock better bombers. In my case, I straight up rage uninstalled the game, didn't play it for nearly a year, and literally restarted the campaign with my previous progress made in the aircraft tree. It's so bad that I don't think I can in all good faith tell new people to buy AC7 without adding in a lot of asterisks about how shit the bombing/ground attack segments are and how prolific they are.

TL;DR game really fun when you're doing literally everything but bombing, which is unfortunately 60-70% of the overall game

Let me know if there's an alternative way to look at this, because I would love a way to stomach those bombing run missions without wanting to punch my screen out. (or tell me git gud, I'll take that too lol)

Ace Combat is one of the most consistent game franchises, and Ace Combat 7 is no exception. Boasting possibly the best gameplay of the series, AC7 is a blast from start to finish that features some intense missions, from having to attempt to shoot down a massive warship to having a dogfight in the mountains with an ace pilot. It might be a tad difficult for newcomers, but if you're willing to bear with it you'll experience something pretty special.

Also amazing soundtrack, god.

I did an unplanned, impulsive Han Solo style "Whoo-Hoo!" twice, during chapter 13 and 19. And that alone is worth a recommendation.

The game looks gorgeous, huge, beautifully rendered landscapes and models, I know they're using tricks and it looks better because its small and far away, so they don't have to model them as well to make them look good, but good god does everything look bloody amazing. Its incredibly cinematic and really lives up to the AAA standard. 

Soundtrack is legendary, definitely go out of your pay to put a bunch in your playlist tier.  It fits the mood so well, and something about it makes it "feel" like "flying high" music. They nailed the theme. 

Gameplay will take hours to learn, but once you do it becomes very smooth. Even by the end I still don't really know any fancy manoeuvres that I see on YouTube and Reddit, and I still got through feeling like a badass. 

Story is B tier, great, but not quite "obsess over the lore tier", maybe if I play more if the games I'll get into the lore more. It seems like something thats up my alley. 

The closest game to AC7 in terms of scope, quality, and fun that comes to mind is Yakuza 0. 

Absolutely worth what I paid for it! (A$12.74 for 16.8 hours)

I'm a big fan of the Ace Combat series and this game delivers everything I would expect from an Ace Combat game. Really good story that expands on events of previous games (you can play this game as a standalone thing, but you'll understand a lot more if you play at least Ace Combat 04 and 5), a soundtrack score that has no business being this good (a staple of Ace Combat and just Namco games in general), and the most important thing, thrilling arcade dogfighting action that really makes you feel like an awesome ace who can do anything in a fighter jet. 

In terms of graphics, it's not just the most beautiful Ace Combat game to date (obviously), it's one of the most stunning flying games I've played, period. The way vortices form around the aircraft, the effects of condensation when you fly inside of clouds, everything is beautiful and cinematic in this game. 

Flight dynamics are phenomenal for what this game is, an arcade dogfighting game, and hit just the right spot of being accessible and arcade enough to implement it's over the top cinematic missions, while still having enough realism to give you control over the plane. This is NOT a simulator, you have no control over any of the systems of the aircraft, you carry dozens of missiles, and obviously the physics are very simplified.  Falcon BMS, DCS, IL-2 Sturmovik, etc, those are simulators, and they're great at simulating. This isn't a simulator and isn't trying to be one. 

There's also a lot of choices when it comes to aircraft and loadouts. Unlike the buying and selling of planes and weapons of the PS2 game where you could essentially experiment with different planes without having to commit to them, in this game there's a progression tree of aircraft, upgrades and weapons, and once you spend your points, you can't get them back. So there's a certain weight to decisions there, especially during campaign gameplay, although I believe it is possible to eventually unlock everything through multiplayer. I feel neutral towards this system as the simpler "just buy and sell whatever you want" approach of Ace Combat 04, 5 and Zero worked really well for me. But it does add a bit more depth and progression to the campaign.

Overall in terms of gameplay, I think this is the best game so far, it is the most polished, has the best flight dynamics, controls really well on both gamepad and more hobbyist input options like HOTAS and flight sticks (which you really don't need for this game, but definitely makes the experience a lot cooler and more immersive), and it also has multiplayer which might add a bit more longevity to the gameplay after you're done with the campaign, if that's your cup of tea. In terms of story, it is a solid entry in the series, although I still rank 5 (The Unsung War) and Zero (The Belkan War) above it. Speaking of Zero, it is a bit sad that the Ace Style system from that game (which I liked to call the "war crime meter") never made a return, would be awesome to have your playstyle influence the story like it did in that game. There's also some points of the plot which I found a bit forced (I won't enter in details to avoid spoiling anything), but overall, it's a good story regardless.

9/10 I really want to see more from this series.

The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.
In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.
The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

Is the game better than the PS2 holy trinity? No. Is it still fun? Yes.

*Spoilers in black boxes*

I wouldn't recommend this to someone starting out Ace Combat as a series. Find a PS2, or... figure out other ways... to play AC4, AC5, and AC0 before playing this game. You'll be lost in the story without them. The story is a bit of a mess and begins to "unwind itself" the longer you play. Not only that, but it doesn't feel like the stakes are that high in this title, compared to the previous titles. Finally, most of the characters feel forgettable and/or unlikable. I was not a fan of Scrap Queen.  [spoiler] What I feel the game lacked was a strong villain, because the DLC villain was incredible. He made the DLC feel better than the actual campaign because he brought in higher stakes. Corsette or the Belkan scientist could've gone that route, too. ("Proper and calm in the spotlight, but evolves to be unhinged like Torres with UAV's instead of nukes) [/spoiler] However, Count is awesome. Even though he became one of my favorite Ace Combat characters, he can't make up for the blandness of the other characters.

Now, the good:
The soundtrack slaps. It's unfathomably good. It's like the Seraphim from the Bible came down to create Ace Combat OST's. The gameplay and graphics kick ass. It plays very well and looks great while doing it. I thought the utilization of cloud cover would be more akin to a gimmick, but turns out I utilized it quite a bit. It felt natural. The PSM was fun to utilize too, even though I didn't use it as much. The plane selection was great, too. The "parts" seem overwhelming at first, but then becomes simple to understand after a mission or 2.

Overall: 8/10
Story doesn't feel as impactful, but everything else makes up for it.
Decent return to form for the series. Story is a little all over the place though.
Pretty neat so far, multiplayer feels dead

Gameplay - Personally doesn't feel like it's quite as exciting as AC 5 and Zero, but still completely solid. I'd say 8 out of 10.
Music - Daredevil is without a doubt one of the best pieces of AC music, but the rest of the missions have... Completely forgettable music with a few exceptions (Hi, Sol Squadron). On average 3/10, but the mission with Daredevil alone makes it an 11/10.
Story - Not only is it the worst story in the Ace Combat franchise, it is the worst story I have ever encountered. There are more moments that you go "Who one EARTH would even consider that a good plan?!" and plotholes than there are plot. Like, I ranted about the terrible story even before I was halfway through my first playthrough. You're better of just skipping cutscenes completely. 0/10, absolutely atrocious.

Overall: Despite the flaws, it still has the spirit of Ace Combat, so if you're an Ace Combat fan you're by law required to play it.

Honestly... not my favorite Ace Combat game.

When I listened to music for it on YouTube and saw a mission, I thought it looked like it might be a lot of fun. Based on the comments from people who loved it, I was wondering if it was like Ace Combat 5 with a super well crafted storyline that would make me feel powerful emotions.

Instead, it felt like an Ace Combat 6 knockoff. Most of the characters who are supposed to be your 'allies' are just annoying, and I don't really find them memorable. I didn't care at all about the person that was supposed to be my rival, and my ultimate goal fell pretty flat. It also didn't help that I never really saw the threat posed by the airships. In Ace Combat 6, you see the airship's interference constantly becoming an obstacle and a threat that they agreed needed to be dealt with. But in AC7, it seems like they're just off somewhere and barely a footnote in most situations.

I felt like the ending came too quickly, and I felt really underwhelmed when it was all over. This game apparently received a lot of high praise from people, but I just do not understand why. More interesting stories were created in the past and executed better. This one just fell flat.

Firstly:  It is not "review bombing" to express legitimate concern for terrible consumer practices.  Ignore all others who would tell you otherwise.

Game only natively supports one specific model of joystick the game was meant to push; you need to use 3rd party software to map your joystick's inputs into a 360 controller emulator to get any other peripherals working. Never had this problem before on any other flight game.  Who doesn't love spending an hour tweaking emulation software before jumping into the latest fighter jet game?!

This game also introduces the "aircraft tree" and makes you grind to unlock planes via in-game currency rather than naturally as you progressed like every other game ever.  You can grind offline and online.  Truly a gripping experience.

Great fun. Recommended for arcade combat fans and aviation enthusiasts alike !

Yeah it's an Ace Combat game alright, but I feel it doesn't live up to the legacy left behind by the previous titles. Game play is okay I guess but it feels very different from previous titles in the sense of how your enemies fly their aircraft. They go slow when you are on their six and fly at near stall speeds which usually forces you to overshoot if you aren't disciplined with your throttle. It's tolerable at first but gets rather annoying as the game progresses with almost every single enemy aircraft flying at stall speeds. I don't remember the other games doing that, but then again its been awhile since I played the originals . It makes some of the boss fights more enjoyable though, as the aces tend to actually fly at faster speeds.

The story feels half-baked and is very confusing at times. Lots of info dumps, and lots of cut scenes that look right out of a B movie. Dialogue is particularly cheesy even for an Ace Combat game. Most of the characters are forgettable with a few that are actually likable with the rest being edge-lords. This was the one area I was expecting this game to shine as all (most) of the previous games tended to have engaging stories and characters. 

The game is pretty good looking though, I will give it that much, and as I said it does feel like how an Ace Combat game should feel like. I guess it just doesn't have the spirit the originals on the PS2 had. I wouldn't recommend this game over the others like Zero and The Unsung War, but since it is the only one that can run on a modern PC with out an emulator then I guess its worth it.

I'd recommend getting Project Wingman instead, You'll have more fun with that and it does a better job at capturing the soul of Ace Combat.

Ace Combat 7 is beautiful, has magnificent clouds, has a great arcade gameplay, has a lot of varied missions and it's an Ace Combat. It also uses scripts to its detriment, it is full of escort and defense missions and there's always a timer to watch out for. Now, where does that leave us? That's a good question.

Like its ancestor Air Combat, AC7 is an arcade game with a bit of simualtion. True, planes can stall but regaining their control when that happens is fairly easy. There are points, score, a notation at the end of each mission (with S being the best) and a timer. It couldn't be more arcade except by making you fight giant alien ships while riding a dragon shooting lasers. And although the aliens and the dragons aren't here, the lasers are though. You'll also find a lot of F planes and Su/Mig in there; you obtain them by buying them and you can add parts to them, which you also have to buy. Once you're in the middle of the enemy forces, your plane will constantly reminds you that a missile is coming for you, and indeed, enemies are abound. Fortunately, your plane carries almost a hundred missiles on it, just don't ask me where they are hidden, but the action is continued and you will have to constantly be on your toes.

The story takes place in a fictive world, on a continent called... Osea? Usea? Erusea? And that's one of the problems with this game, even after multiple hours of playtime I still don't know who is who. At least, I know you play the role of a new pilot nicknamed Trigger that will become a part of a conflict between two countries, or was it one country and a federation? Now, who has started the war and for what? Well, that's the story of AC7. Along the way, you'll encounter your Sasuke/Sephiroth type rival (= mysterious and super strong) here nicknamed Mister X, make new allies (that are quite forgettable, except for two characters), and attempt to end a war. By the way, about your allies, they are totally useless. In AC6, you were able to choose their planes and give them order. Here, it's like they do no damage to enemies. If they shoot.

One thing I can't stress enough is that AC7 is a fun game. It's quite arcade, full of action and "Missile!» My problems with the game don't come from the gameplay in itself but rather from what surrounds it.

One thing that's particular is the design of the missions. They are indeed very varied and you won't find a lot of repetition while playing AC7, which is a good thing (at least, if you're new to the franchise). On the other hand, those, in my opinion, are badly designed because of the constraints they put on you. Although the missions are varied, in their attempt to bring something new, the designers also made them annoying: one time your radar won't work, the other time you'll have to watch out for the wind or the lightning, the other time it will be the light (sic), etc. Furthermore, all the missions are timed and sometimes very strictly. They are also a lot of escort/protect missions; mostly, when I had to restart, it was because I weren't able to protect something or someone. It is not as grating as protecting a certain Ashley but you have to be prepared for that. Also, and this one might be a very personal grievances, but in order to make things more cinematic, the game don't hesitate to use scripts. Thus, a boss won't go down until the game has decided it's time for it to go down even if you manage to nuke it to Pluton; and that also means you will often have a "surprise" encounter when you think you're finally finished with a mission. Lastly, although there are checkpoints, those are used sparingly, therefore making you sometimes restart a whole 10 minutes of play. 

Because of the design of the missions, AC7 is the hardest Ace Combat I've played. I've only played three of them before playing this game, Ace Combat 2, Ace Combat 6 and Ace Combat: Assault Horizon but never have I felt greatly frustrated while playing them. In fact, the Ace Combat games were always in my eyes some sort of comfort food, a game to play when I want to chill and have fun. But it isn't really the case with AC7, even in normal. You might have to retry some missions a fair amount of time, moreso if you're not familiar with the franchise. And to make things worse, there are some hidden mechanics that can make things easier which are never mentioned like the post stall maneuvers or how to make the camera follow a target (by holding Y/triangle).

So, like I said, where does that leave us? It's an Ace Combat. That's the first thing that sprung to my mind the first time I played it. I always liked the franchise and AC7 didn't betray my expectations. It didn't really surprise me though but I guess you can only go that far with an arcade flight game. If you're a fan, chances are great you will like it. If you're not, there might be a certain period of time needed to adjust yourself and gain some automatisms. I had fun while playing but it also frustrated me more than I expected, so in the end I don't regret buying it for only 19,99€. So, yes, you can go for it, especially on sale. Just be prepared for its flaws.

I do not recommend this game, primarily for the price (85$) for an 8-10 hour campaign. I think that alone is criminal, seeing as that some levels can take an hour on their own due to how many times you have to restart, with mission 6 and 19 being the greatest offenders. The game on a technical and gameplay level are of a high quality, aside from most of the English voice acting which can be pretty half arsed; its a Japanese developer/publisher so its to be somewhat expected. There are a variety of aircraft you can fly, but as for where to fly them, you can only replay completed campaign missions. There aren't any other modes like wave defence, shorter skirmish missions, or dogfight against tougher ai outside the campaign. Your only incentive is to try campaign missions again is for a higher score, which feels very lacking for its price point. Even with the campaign, most missions felt very samey, with only a small handful of missions I went "wow, this feels amazing, with missions 14 and 16 being standout. This game does nothing that hasn't been seen for the last 15, except for marginal graphics improvements and very pretty cutscenes. [b] If the price drops to 15-30$ I would say to give it a go, [/b] but for its listed price of 85$ I think you should steer clear.
