The game is fantastic flying game with a story. I don’t know of any other realistic flying game that has a story. I’m pretty sure that the game that I played when I was very little at my friends house, was ace combat on the ps1. Her older brother wouldn’t let me play it for long and I think we took turns. It was a fun game. It’s so nice to finally play the game again but this time with better graphics, and what I think is the most recent version of the game. I didn’t know that there were so many of these games. Do they all have a story? I thought it was just a realistic jet fighter simulator where all you do is missions?


The good
Graphics are great
Story is alright
Music is really good
Controls are pretty great
Customization with parts for your craft and buying new planes is cool
The 3 story dlcs are alright. The 10 million, being the best one.
There’s a casual easy mode.
Every mission was a new set piece.
This game reminds me of starfox 64 in some parts but with no characters that you care about.

The bad
You can only change the vertical or horizontal controls to inverted from the main menu, once you are in the game and playing, when you go to the controls and change it, it doesn’t work. It only works for a gamepad.

No way to change resolution. It is locked to whatever the game thinks your resolution is.

The main character that we play doesn’t talk, I actually thought that he might be a drone but I remember a character mentioning, after a completed mission, that he smiled while they were in the room after some successful mission. I truly think it hurts the story so much and the writer makes the characters mention how Trigger doesn’t talk even while they are talking to him. And at one point near the every end of the game, a character asks Trigger if someone is okay and of course he doesn’t answer. It’s just terrible.

Two parts in the story that come to mind, is just too anime like or done with no logic. One where the princess prefers to parachute down some very tall structure even though a battle just occurred. And another in two DLC’s where in the first 1, the intro with the brother and sister. He calls her an idiot and she’s just like “Don’t call me an idiot or I’ll kill you” or something. Like to me, they are acting like children and bickering the whole time and yet they are flying these very expensive jets. Oh and they also did some aerial thing when they into battle. It was like they were flaunting and showing off. I dunno, I didn’t like it cause they were so edgy and I didn’t feel like it fit the game that we were playing.

The brown woman in the story really serves no purpose.

Don’t know who most of the characters in the story are.

Some people in the story don’t seem to die even though we killed them? I guess everyone ejects from their plane but don’t show up on the screen?

The game kinda forces you to do the uturn move in the game for battles. Because I had to do it a lot, to try and quickly get a kill, it ended up hurting my hands and arms.

You don’t gain money when you fail a mission. Imagine playing a mission for 15-25 minutes and then making a mistake and just hitting a wall or letting a missle hit you. The sunk cost is your time and your life.  You should gain the money or at least half of what you got when you lost.

Timers in missions. There shouldn’t be any. They always sucked.

I think the game expected players to redo missions and grind for money? Cause one aircraft is good for mission 15.

I hate mission 15. It sucked so much. I had to use a DLC planes b to beat it cause I was tired of losing because I just missed 4k points. Though, I am thankful that a DLC plane helped me beat it.

I feel like maybe the extra DLC planes aren’t worth it. The game is better being played normally by upgrading your planes and buying new ones along the way. Some DLC planes are really OP though.

Scripted battles. When you know it’s happening, it’s like why? Trying to uturn and wasting time trying to get a lock on sucks so much, cause the boss enemy will never give you an opening to attack it. And when you do get a hit, it doesn’t matter cause they have endless health. I pretty much don’t like how they programmed the ai, I guess.

Cloud saving only

Can’t switch to easy mode at any time during the story.

Don’t really like how the enemy ai is programmed and how it always felt I was doing everything. Though in the DLCs, my ai teammates appeared to actually help me which was odd to see.

Multiplayer doesn’t work and it single-handedly tanks my internet when I try.


Conclusion
Anyways, the game is good and it truly had some epic moments in the game. I personally feel that the game is best played on easy or probably the casual easy mode and I wish I did for the main story. I just wanted a story with my realistic planes, going fast, and seeing things blow up. If there ever is a new one, I would totally play on casual.

I haven't played an Ace Combat game since 04, with my friend on the PS2. I remember it fondly, especially our 1v1 skirmishes that were always super intense. Our battles were legendary, and took a long time because we wouldn't let the other get a lock for very long.
I remember the campaign as well. A collection of highly varied, objective-based skirmishes, which were not very complicated to complete but terribly difficult to master. The voice work was fantastic.

This game is a very similar feeling. I have long since burned out of PvP multiplayer, so I can't speak to that, but the campaign is amazing so far. The plane details, gameplay, graphics, sounds, and voice work are all amazingly done. 
I am also running this game on integrated graphics. My Ryzen 5 3400G can successfully run this game with everything on High, and rarely dips below 30fps. It feels well optimized, while also looking absolutely stellar.
The story also feels very familiar. It is a heavy political conflict, leading into war. I found myself wanting to keep playing just to see how things develop, which is how I view a GOOD STORY. There is a heavy plot twist at one point that actually made me start to feel things deep in my heart, and it leads into where I am now as I write this review.

The gameplay is why I'm writing this review. It feels just like the amazing time I used to have while playing AC04 at my friend's house, all those years ago. Flying at 2250+m/s through frozen clouds that are actually freezing your plane over, being able to fire anti-ground cluster bombs to clear out AA guns that cannot even track you at that velocity, and barely maneuvering successfully through gigantic rock spires while dodging fire from an opponent with as much flight skill as you, WHILE ALSO DODGING LIGHTNING... It's a genuine intense rush and I am thoroughly enjoying it.

The plane unlocks feel pretty fair, and while I've gotten a few in so far, the benefits come from the mid-point unlocks between planes with upgrades; allowing you to hold more missiles, be more resistant to having your plane freeze over, improved turn rate, and many more.

I recommend this game if you enjoy good plane shooty.

This game is such a good sequel and deep breath of nostalgia for seasoned Ace Combat fans. The intricacy of the missions, including boss fights and flying through tight tunnels at fast speeds, leaves the player feeling challenged and exhilarated at the versatility of modern military airplanes. 100% would recommend.

[h1] First of all, what's the game like? [/h1]
Well, this is a great option for [spoiler] you maverick wannabes [/spoiler] air combat lovers who want to have a good time other than war thunder and dcs. Mechanics are simple to understand and the overall sceneries in the game are just splendid. And particularly the soundtracks ingame [spoiler] hail to Kobayashi-san [/spoiler] are incredibly phenomenal, which every game throughout the entire franchise possesses, they will not let you down.

[h1] About the Singleplayer... [/h1]
[b] The base game [/b]
The lore is okay-ish, storytelling is fine [strike] hey at least you got a pretty nice looking waifu [/strike] and it's not very hard to figure out the whole background and it's totally not a problem if you haven't played any of the previous games. The missions are time limited and can be a challenge if you are new to the game, with more practice you won't have any difficulties dealing with them [strike] yes you can speedrun the whole game[/strike] . Almost every different weapon in the game offers a unique playstyle, you can focus heavy strike on a single target with highly maneuverable QAAMs, or getting rid of a large enemy group with 4/6/8AAMs. The game almost offers a varieties of futuristic weapons like the Tactical Laser System [strike] an onboard laserpointer [/strike], the EML [strike] basically a railgun [/strike], MPBMs [strike] multipurpose tactical nukes ;) [/strike] and so on. Some of the missions provides special mechanics [spoiler] contains but not limited to: low altitude breakthrough/valley runs/gigantic super weapons/tUnNels [/spoiler] which add more fun to the campaign.
[b] The DLC missions [/b]
Definitely worth the price, has another huge air to air only combat apart from the base campaign, more mechanics and adds a fantastic and attractive villain, play it yourself for the best experience.
[b] The mods [/b]
Yes this game supports modding and oh boy, the communities are just went all out. You can have completely new aircrafts with new weapons from iconic aircrafts in previous titles or aircrafts in real life, new hud, new effects, new skins for aircrafts and even maps with a completely different setting. Apart from those you can also have rebalanced AIs which gives you a more challenging campaign and new mechanics which tweak from the aircraft cannon firerates to new missile tracking methods. Still, i recommend trying the mods out after at least finishing the original campaign once.

[h1] About the Multiplayer... [/h1]
[u] PLEASE DO PLAY THE SINGLEPLAYER FIRST BEFORE TRYING MP [/u]
[b] Overall situation [/b]
This is where all things went down, only two game modes are available and they are max 8 players free for alls and max    4v4 team death match. Apart from those two you can also set for 1v1 games but it's really time consuming if you want to get your skills up. Also, many experienced players wander around and they will not give you a good time in MP and can easily ruin your experience and make you ragequit, [i] Seriously, you have been warned [/i], prepare for being killed over and over again if you are rookies to the game. [spoiler] Stay away from those lobbies with "join midmatch" turned off and theres only one player in it, you will most likely get rekt very hard. [/spoiler]
[b] Mechanics [/b]
For battle royals [spoiler] not the one you expected [/spoiler] or free for all is competing for the best, the match ends when anyone reaches 100k score. For team death matches, mostly are the same as the battle royal mode except the game ends when any of the teams reaching 250k score. In both game modes, if a player got a score thats high enough, he would receive stars varying from 1 to 3, which in turn maximum triples the scores you get from killing them. Remember to configure your aircraft set in the hangar first before entering any match or you will be end up on a stock F16. Inside the hanger you get access to different parts that can boost your aircrafts and weapons performance dramatically, but the slots and options are limited so be wise on your loadout.
[b] Some warnings [/b]
Be very mentally prepared before entering MP, it's P2P based so connection quality will impact your experience a lot. Furthermore, the game has NO anti cheat methods and it's very painful when encountering one. A point worth mentioning is that a lot of the advanced techniques, for instance backwards flying [spoiler] yes you see that correct, flying literally backwards not upside down [/spoiler] would behave very similar to cheating but they are different fundamentally.

[h1] TL;DR[/h1]
Good game if you like arcade flying with exciting combats, the SP part is around 30 hours with many content, mods add a lot more fun to the game and theres plenty of them, the MP experience is basically trash if you are not willing to spend time taking hits and sharping your skills and learning stuff. Not worth the full price, get it when on discount.

Ace Combat 7 is a return to what made the franchise famous and well loved. The story is back in the universe the franchise belongs in and the references/return to locations in the previous games was refreshing, and something that separates Ace Combat from lazy writing set in the real world (USA v Russia/China/Iran/Terrorists). This game is peak in terms of combat mechanics, with new features like turbulence, lightning, duststorm radar masking, and storms throwing off heat seeking missiles occasionally. Dogfight mode was rightfully scrapped, and return to the classic style of aerial combat was a welcomed one. I also personally loved the introduction of having to identify targets before fighting, as well as keeping post-stall maneuvers. I do have mixed feelings about the futuristic weapons, but given the in-universe timeline, previous games in said universe, and nostalgia for them it wasn't unreasonable. As always, Ace Combat once again has mastered symphonies to set the tone. The mission radio chatter was on-point, especially during the Spare-Squadron portion of the campaign. Characters like AWACS Bandog, Avril Mead, and Cossette are some of the best developed and fleshed out of the entire franchise, I just wish I could say the same about any of the wingmates or antagonists. Dr Schroeder dropped his vendetta with the tiniest of convincing, given the fact he went so far to instigate a global war to avenge his country's nuclear-suicide after losing a war it started... Mihaly A. Shilage was just "only cares about flying and wants decent opponents". It felt like a lazy knock-off of Yellow 13, but AC4 had the depth of his character explored in the context of caretaking a war-orphaned boy whose parents he inadvertently killed, took pride in looking after his wingmates (unlike Mihaly), and showed mercy on kids who personally assisted the resistance in bombing his runway and helping kill his closest wingmate. My only other frustration was that the campaign seemed short, but mission variety was excellent. I would've also liked missions that mandated the use of certain aircraft like Assault Horizon's bombing run mission, or the door gunner mission. I also miss formation management from AC:5, as well as the branching story of AC:X. What I really wish was there was a remaster or conglomerated remaster of the previous games with the updated visuals and mechanics.

This game is just beautiful, from the extremely well developed history to the gameplay, graphics and sounds. I mostly enjoy simulator-style games, so i was kinda reluctant to play an arcade game, but after finishing the campaign i can assure you that i would not have this much fun on a simulator, it opened my eyes to a new style of games that always gets me hyped.

The campaign is kinda short yet VERY emotional, it provides an incredible immersion and you can actually feel (personally) what your character feels.
Although the campaing is short, it's far from being the end of the game, it has great replayability and tons of planes, weapons and upgrades to unlock and get even higher scores.

If you fancy competitive gameplay, the multiplayer is pretty accessible, there are some hardcore players but even so it's not hard to get some kills and have fun, and the multiplayer tech-unlocking is pretty extense aswell.

Finally, this game hyped me to ACE COMBAT so much that i'm desperate to play other games on the series, but unfortunatelly they are not available to PC. I greatly recommend it to everyone, BUT PLAY IT ON A CONTROLLER.

Edit: About the DLCs, they are very well made, the missions feel the same as the main campaign, and the new planes are beautiful, but they are hardly worth the full price. Buy them, but wait for huge discounts.

I bought this game on while it was on its Top Gun: Maverick promotion, and let me just start off by saying that yes, this game is truly amazing, and i dont think i have ever had this much fun playing games alone in my computer.

What i really love about this game is how you can clearly see the amount of effort that was put into developing it, the graphics are insane (even in my low-end laptop), the gameplay feels REALLY nice and the music is simply perfect and it sets the mood flawlesly for every scene.
The campaign is also incredible, although i want such a big fan of the story, the missions are what made me really enjoy it. The locations, the characters that are involved and the objectives are perfect, and it truly suprised me how fun they were. The missions are genuinely challenging and concluding them is a amazing feeling
The multiplayer is nice, although i wish we could have longer matches or an open world server where we could just mess around with friends, but it is pretty fun to hop onto online rooms and just spend some time

It is definetely one of the best games i ever played, and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to try it

Graphically AC7 is quite superb and amazing to play, making it such a shame as to the lack of proper VR support as it would've taken so very little on the developers' part to add it to this style of game.  I'm not normally one for promoting DLC but I'm sure a great many VR users would pay premium for an implementation of this.

In terms of story, once again Ace Combat has you flying for the evil and dull Osean Air Force against a much more interesting Eruseans, making you constantly root for your enemies and want to defect to the other side.  After Ace Combat 5 and now 7 it feels like the developers want you to hate Osea, and I think it was a big missed opportunity on their part to fly for Erusea since they clearly put way more creative energy into making them.  

Like Ace Combat Zero the game also needlessly leans heavily into the 'World Without Borders' theme, which remains as unnecessary as ever and again detracts from the overall plot.

Overall, the story can be quite cringy at points, but the graphics are quite good and at least its in Strangereal again so it can be forgiven of its faults.  Ace Combat 8 better not be another rerun of flying for the Osean villains though.  Belka and Erusea did nothing wrong.

Those SU 33's are the best ... totally love the game !!! amazing mission design, altho what frustrates me the most is the game never has any frequent checkpoints, sometimes even an entire 15 mins progress can be wiped out if you make a mistake or crash it somewhere, and it hurts to play it all over again and to destroy the the same gawd damme thing all over again and also the progression system is atrocious I gotta do multiple sorties just to unlock the entire SU flights and guess what,  it was already a pain in the ass, and to do it all over again nd again was a brain dead decisions by the devs cuz this game is quiet frankly meant to be played for the campaign alone nd  no one really cared about multiplayer tbh , and my gawd! it was totally a meaningless boring grind to do the same sorties all over again without any variation and same dialogues and  hence to restore my sanity I was forced to get a mod to unlock all the parts and flights from nexus modding, if it wasn't for that I couldn't have tried out all the other wonderful flights locked behind those dull and vapid grind this brings to me to another point that is,  the flight models could have been a tad bit better, for the cockpit and  for the overall look and feel aesthetically, atleast it would be good enough reward for the insane grind that I did for an hour  or so ! .  but nonetheless other than those flaws that the game has, it still is fun! from the story to the height intensity arcade aerial battles it all just clicks, I'm giving a thumbs up just for the story and the level design and the good arcade aerial combat! would love to play an ace combat game again but except without those infamous grinds for those flights and parts !!!

I bought this because my Logitech X56 HOTAS, and prior to this the X52 HOTAS, were not supported by Ace Combat : Assault Horizon ENHANCED EDITION, unless I used third party software,  like JoyToKey or JoyPro, to bind keystrokes to JOY_BUTTON(s).  Even then the joystick movements were not smooth as you're bassically spamming the game with what amounts to thousands of keystrokes per minute, which leads to choppiness.  So I broke down and bought Ace Combat 7.   The X56 HOTAS appears to be supported out of the box and performs much better with no tweaking.   ROLLing and YAWing with the X56 HOTAS appears to be fixed.  Finally!   Good game.   Fun.  Good story.

Wide array of aircraft and weapons to choose from. Great graphics. Great game play. It's a worthy successor to previous Ace Combat games. I especially prefer to use F-15 and F/A-18 variants, but I've flown all of the base game aircraft (which, even without DLC, is about 30 aircraft) 3 or 4 times between the PC and PS4 versions.

Its multiplayer is a bit lacking - No Co-Op mode, no Naval Team Death Match. It's just Team Death Match and Battle Royale only. A lot of the missions themselves are a bit biased toward multirole aircraft - only a few missions in the first half of the game are suitable for ground attack aircraft, like the A-10C Thunderbolt II. Although, if you want a heck of a challenge, the A-10 in air-to-air missions will certainly give you that.

I would absolutely recommend this game! What's not to like? The gameplay is fantastic, the story is great, but if you don't play Multiplayer for a while, a whole lot of people will be better than you. Lol.

Gameplay:
This shouldn't be marked as "simulation," it should be marked as "arcade!" The flight physics are terrible, there's no cockpit view and you're missing basic things like an artificial horizon. Why do I have unlimited missiles, but limited flares? Why am I affected by icing but my enemy isn't? Your AI allies are near-useless and are basically just there as plot devices - being able to issue orders, change their target priority, or change their formations would be nice.

Menus and things:
Buying upgrades and things for your aircraft is nice, but skill/tech trees are just expected at this point, and offers nothing compelling like being able to paint your plane pretty colors, or build new planes. The mission playback is a super neat feature, but camera controls are locked, so you miss some of the best thematic elements.The wireframe view had me excited for a moment as a way to actually improve my fighting tactics in review, but it doesn't show critical things like missiles or gunfire, and you can't manipulate the view except to zoom in or out, so you're basically left seeing "Oh right, that must be the part where I kept taking 1 billion missiles and had to keep dodging instead of fighting (sic, that's 50% of the game)."

Storyline & Pacing:
The voice acting is like Metal Gear Solid 1, which maybe did it for me when I was 10 but is just cringe now. The storyline is in a fictional world that you're dumped into and instantly fails to address the most basic aspect of "why do I care?" While it might be an interesting show to watch if they developed the characters, they don't, and the the storyline just feels glued on to the fighter action worse than Modern Warfare 2. Dialogue between your pilots is ultra-trope-y, and makes me hate them. Being able to customize your pilot would be nice so at least you can be semi-invested in your character but you cannot; you may say that you're playing a specific character in the storyline, but are you really? When you're flying your basically just the Silent But Deadly type on par with Claude from GTA3/4. 

Overall:
The game play features the usual flying around in circles, dodging missiles, and stalling out into terrain that most flying games offer without offering anything new. Maybe I'm just not jacked up on mountain dew to appreciate it, but I can say without a doubt I was super-sonically disappointed. 

5/10

Really a spectacular game with hours upon hours of fun to be had. Theres a reason that the Ace Combat franchise is such an icon, and Im glad that this was the game that introduced me to it.

The music is awesome and will give you goosebumps at just the right moments, the cutscenes are STUNNING - Ive got over 500 screenshots simply from quick 'oo that'd make a great background' moments, and the gameplay will keep you on the edge of your seat throughout regardless of whether you have a keyboard, controller, or HOTAS in hand.

I play DCS for the satisfaction of splashing bandits tens of miles away using realistic and fiddly systems and mechanics. I play this game for the adrenaline rush of doing backflips in a 6 fighter strong FFA furball with a dozen missiles on my tail, no flares, and a solid column of rock rapidly closing in on my nose.

My only qualm with the game is the native HOTAS support, but once you know how to edit the required files it's not that much of an issue.

I'd recommend this game to anyone wanting to wear-in a new joystick, anyone looking for an introduction to the Ace Combat series, or really just anyone looking for a fun game to dump some hours into.

There isn't much to like about this game. The story makes no sense and you quickly ignore it and skip the briefings and cutscenes just to get on with the action. You always end up with enemies which weren't mentioned on the briefings anyway. 

The music is mostly forgettable, previous AC games had much more visceral soundtracks. Not that you can hear it most of the time anyway, over the endless tedious cringey dialogue and the constant 'MISSILE MISSILE MISSILE' warnings. The graphics are okay, but most of the time all you will see is sky or clouds. There is no wow factor. Another flaw is there is no way to change FOV so it is like you are wearing blinkers all the time, this is a serious hindrance on some missions. 

The clouds and weather are a gimmick which quickly gets irritating which interferes with your ability to simply see where you are going, or identify enemies. Several missions require you to identify enemies before being allowed to shoot them. They can shoot at you instantly though, but if you shoot them you get punished by the game. Fair? This game doesn't do fair. It does tedium and frustration. Some missions have a tight arbitrary time limit where if you fail you go way back to an earlier checkpoint and may have to play again for 15 minutes just because you fell short by a few seconds. Don't be surprised if you have to replay some missions dozens of times. 

For normal players I recommend playing on the easiest difficulty (which often is far from easy) and get the 'part' which repairs your plane so you can take more damage. Although you can carry hundreds of missiles, of course you can only carry a handful of flares, so you will either be taking damage regularly or constantly dodging missiles. All while desperately trying to identify enemies against a pale bright sky / clouds, and before the time limit runs out. Mission 17 'Homeward' is particularly horrible for this. 

The PS2 era games still haven't been bettered for gameplay, especially 4 and 5. For a story and voice acting, the unfairly maligned Assault Horizon was much better than anything in AC7's cringey, emo 'anti-war' story which will just make you roll your eyes. You have to keep dialogue on because at times you need to hear instructions of what to do or where to go.

The missions can be very long and you can't save mid mission, so if you get through a particularly tough part and then get stuck on another part, you will either have to sit there for ages while you try again, or quit and lose everything. This isn't a game which respects the player's time, it is designed to irritate you. Even at the end of a mission when it says mission accomplished, you can still fail after that point if you accidentally hit terrain, or fly out of the arena. The mission goes on for another minute while you listen to more tedious unskippable dialogue. The writer should stick to the visual novel shovelware that Japanese devs specialise in and which Steam is full of these days. Get a western writer for the next game, like Assault Horizon had, and a story and characters that actually makes sense and you care about, and the game would be much better for it.

[h1] Awful in all aspects (singleplayer) [/h1]

If you are looking for a game where you feel like you are flying an airplane [b]PASS[/b]. All planes can and will constantly turn and instantly accelerate. Feels like flying an ufo not a plane

If you are looking for a game with interesting dog fights [b]PASS[/b]. There are only 3 special enemies in this game that you “dogfight”. 1 Dude you fight 3 times and 2 special Drone types and all of those fights were dog shit. There's no real strategy you just keep on turning

If you are looking for interesting gameplay [b]PASS[/b]. The game stays the same from the first to the last mission. No improvements, no new mechanics. Sometimes you get new objectives but the interesting ones are far and few between. Most of them are “Kill all” or “Kill X in Y minutes”

The story is not great imo and more like a very cheesy b movie where you better not try to think about anything. The game also fetishishes the MC in a way that gets really annoying. It is kinda immersion breaking when you have 30 allies circling the last enemy and not attacking because ONLY YOU can do it, it becomes ridiculous.

It is also not really challenging (only played on medium though). I literally never died to aircrafts or came even close to it. I only died to the almighty enemy, the ground. Why? Because half of the map have bad visibility (clouds sandstorms rain etc) which is a really annoying combo when you constantly keep turning

Main campagne doesn't even take 10 hours.

Pros: Very fun gameplay (aside from some really frustrating levels that honestly seem to depend wholly on luck), good performance even on almost highest settings, very good sound design, art design, and of course graphics, and...that's it. 

Cons: The story is mostly nonsense that doesn't withstand even basic "why" and "how" questions, and the player character is constantly fellated by both friend and foe as the best pilot ever and the best person ever and boy he's the best oh my gosh isn't Trigger the best. 
The legacy superplanes such as the Morgan and FALKEN are locked behind DLC despite previous games letting the player simply unlock them in-game. 
The "upgrade parts" mechanic is basically just "lowering the difficulty mode without actually lowering the difficulty mode", which is funny because the game doesn't actually let you alter the difficulty mode once you begin the campaign, making grinding for upgrade parts mandatory if you have trouble beating a level. 
Missions can auditorily overwhelm you at times with "MISSILE. MISSILE. MISSILE." in your ear as multiple radio conversations talk over each other, all the while explosions and roaring jet engines and lock-on noises and all kinds of other audio all plays at the same time. 
Oh, and you can't even change the paint schemes of your plane until you beat the campaign...which I don't really have much interest in playing again anyway.

Basically, pros = it's Ace Combat finally on PC, but cons = it's not a very good Ace Combat game.

I've been waiting a long time to play an Ace Combat game in PC. With my moderately-powerful computer that did met the minimum system requirements, the game still ran fairly smoothly . I really enjoyed soaring through the sky with high speed and freedom. Although the game isn't currently supporting a 3rd-party joystick yet, I've heard that the developers are working on the issue right now. I hope that joystick-support would be implemented later on, since I find that playing this game on keyboard and mouse can be a bit difficult. Nevertheless, the beautiful cinematics, captivating soundtracks, and simple gameplay really brings out the highlights to Ace Combat 7.

Update:

Wow, anniversary aircraft sets are pleasant surprises!

One of the most satisfying games to get good at.

This is not a simulation by any means, but that arguably makes it better. Your standard F/A-18 can and will carry 90 missiles yet not have enough room for 5 flares.

Special weapon variation is so high that you can go from launching eight missiles at a 8th generation fighter piloted by an old man to liquidating some unarmed tanker ship with a crack-filled laser-pen, committing several warcrimes in the process.

You get to fight everything from an oversized boomerang to a boat with more anti-air than insane crew members. What more must be added?

The game often goes on sale for 80%, and if it does i 100% recommend at that price. 60 dollars is a bit steep, but in the event of a beefy sale, pick it up. (get the deluxe edition it comes with the DLC campaign which is by far the best)

10/10

Would love to try this again a million times.

For long time (more than 20 years) ace combat series was console exclusive. Namco didn't think that demand for this kind of game exist in PC market. Now finally they release new instalment on Steam and I am happy with this.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The game use unreal engine 4. It's allow to create good picture. Sky and clouds were created from scratch and looks very well. And with different clouds come different weather. Some mission will have clear blue sky and some heavy clouds with rain and lightning. And it's looks absolutely amazing. I am not a pilot so can't compare but for me it is good enough to create sense of immersion. As for ground obviously it's not good as sky. Models for tanks or vehicle not better than in RTS game. Same about amount in details in terrain. Luckily most of time you fly in big heights and if you bombing some things you don't need come to close. The planes well designed and distinguish not just by specs but also by their look. As for characters nothing groundbreaking but it's look decent. Overall it's definitely not next gen of graphic but the game's picture accomplish what it must for this genre.

[h1]SOUNDTRACK[/h1]
Outstanding. One of the best. You probably didn't hear about it because game not that popular. But it's really very good. Each mission have unique soundtrack that reflect what happened on the screen. One vs One, one vs everybody, stealth mission - everything have something special. 

[h1]STORY[/h1]
This is very tricky part. Previously I played in Ace combat 2 (1997) and two spin offs for PSP: "Sky of Deception" (2006) and "Joint Assault" (2010). Definitely not enough to know lore and background of this fictional world. As preparation I watched summary posted by YouTubeer Ace combat fan where he provided short version of events in previous games. It's definitely helps. You play speechless pilot (which kind annoying element  in 2019) that caught in middle war. After some "mistake" he was sent to prison and serve as expendable pilot for most dangerous missions along with another prisoners. The war continue and with it your adventure. The pilot not a single main character (but he is only who playable) so you see same events from different points of view. I like this style. Add to this variuos conversations on radio that help to develop characters a bit more. The game have couple good memorable moments and interesting enough to want to continue. Overall nothing heartbreaking but nothing cringe either. Just remember that this game from Japanese devs.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Gameplay is divided into two parts. First is preparation for mission. Here you see briefing before launch. Unlike others military based game this part really important. It's provide critical information about weather conditions, day/night cycle, enemy type, enemy awareness about your presence and etc. Then based on what you hear you choose plane, parts and special weapons. It's highly recommended to choose wisely. Otherwise wrong set up can significantly increase difficulty. For example, if it's attack against oil fields bring A-10 with bombs that have big radius of explosion.
Second part is mission itself. The game have 20 mission. Each mission take place in different locations. Their objective are various. It includes seek and destroy, escorts, defense, destroy enough amount of enemies, stealth mission. A lot of dogfight (you can hide in clouds but it can create icing problem) , bombing ground and navy target. Objectives can change on the fly so listen to radio and do what you have been told. Also some missions have unique circumstances. Like bad weather that causes interference in radar and missile locking system, altitude restrictions. I don't to tell more because of spoilers. The game not easy and requires planning before each mission and focus on the objectives. The game have challenges and you feel good when you succeed to overcome it. By beating missions you earn money to unlock new craft, parts and weapons. And you can replay any mission that already have been unlocked. New planes and parts create good progression system that rewards players. Also very important to mention. You should play only with EXPERT control. Otherwise it will hurt your experience.

[h1]REPLAYABILITY[/h1]
Aside single player the game multi-player with 2 modes: team deathmatch and (4 vs 4) and battle royal (8 players) . Not a fan. Unless you have friends it's good cool experience or want to grind in game currency it's not worth it. I wish they implement PvE instead PvP. It will cool fight together in order to bring down huge enemy plain defended by navy/ground forces along side other planes. The game have huge tree with planes and parts to unlock. Also high difficulty and different medals to earn. 

[h1]PERFORMANCE[/h1]
I use i5 9600k, GTX 1080; 16GB RAM and Windows 10. I run game on 2560x1440 resolution with max settings (scale 150%). The game runs very smooth, fps between ~70 and 90. Zero crashes. I use XBOX360 controller and it always work. No complaints here.

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
I am very happy with my purchase. This game offer pretty unique experience that allow you have you to have little glimpse to real piloting. Of course, a lot things were simplified but it never take away fun. I recommend to this game purchase and hope that next game full have full VR support including PC.
P.S. New DLC with planes from TopGun Maverick is so cool addition.

Well, what a treat.  Ace Combat 7 is the first game I've played in a long while that was just flat out fun.  In many ways it is an absolute joy to play, fantastic graphics, great controls, pumping soundtrack and fun gameplay.

It's important to know that this is not in any way a flight simulator - it's a well paced arcade game that happens to feature some real life planes, you do not need to map 50 keys to play - it all works from a controller - or if your prepared for a little hassle, a HOTAS - this requires you to map keys in notepad. Honestly though, I preferred the controller.

Just a note about the DLC to help buyers - the Ultimate Edition does not contain everything, if you want it all - you'll need to buy an extra three packs of three planes and a single plane pack to get it all.  You do not need these, it just gives you more planes to fly.  Be warned, some of the DLC planes are way OP for the campaign and will make it very, very easy.  I suggest a play through with the default planes first before using the DLC ones, but it's up to you.

Overall - Highly recommended.

The storyline is a little cringe at times but I'm having fun. Aircraft/weather graphics are great. Had to do a minor hack to make my logitech flightstick work, but that's OK. Haven't played all the way through the game or MP yet.

This game shouldn't be as annoying as it is. The flight controls are great. The graphics are nice. The story is decent. The music is fantastic. But there are far too many flaws that get in the way of all that.

Most of the missions in the campaign have some extremely annoying part to them that ruins the fun of flying. Like the one where you have to hunt down trucks in a sandstorm. You can't see, they barely show up on radar, and there's constant wind blowing you all over the place. I feel like the only reason I managed to finally beat that mission was sheer luck. Way too much of the difficulty comes from cheap gimmicks, instead actual challenging mission design.

And the core problem that makes it all so frustrating is the ever present time limit. If it weren't for that, most of these missions would be way more fun. But the fact that you simply CANNOT take your time and be careful, like any sane pilot would, just ruins the whole thing. I had to redo most missions multiple times, just because I was one target/a few hundred points short when the time ran out.

Plus, I feel like whether or not missiles hit is more up to luck than any skill. Both on you, and on your targets. I can usually just ignore all the incoming missile warnings and never get hit. But I also took down the final super maneuverable drone boss with my first random blind shot that I figured would never hit it. Guess I rolled a natural 20 on that one.

Overall, I would be much more forgiving, and give this a thumbs up, if it weren't for one unforgivable sin: The DLC. The fact that all the best planes are not even available in a $60 game is complete BS. You already have to spend a stupid amount of time grinding free missions or multiplayer if you want all the planes that are actually the base game. But then they expect you to pay over a hundred more on top of that? No thank you!

If I hadn't bought this game when it was $9, I would feel ripped off. And there's no way I'm getting any of the DLC. Not when there's Project Wingman to play instead.

This game is sheer, un-adulterated adrenaline. It very much reminded me of being the main character of a children's action show, or a lighter hearted action anime. There's a hero's rise from zero to hero, a beloved pet (PNG dog for life), loss, amazing and insane stunts, and loads of melodrama. Even without a flight stick or any other simulation tools I found myself shifting in my seat like I was trying to counteract g-forces and feel the wind in my hair. I wanted thrilling aerial combat when I got the game, and I got that plus a raucous, unbelievable ride. 


(Note: the meme community for this game is brilliant, highly recommend checking it out after beating the game. Dont worry about spoilers for the rest of the series, its so incomprehensible you can read the top 1000 posts and still barely know whats happening.)

MISSILE. MISSILE. MISSILE.

This game is pretty fun for a while, but the longer it goes on the more frustrating it becomes. The standard missile never increases in range, while your aircraft and your enemy's tend to get faster, making late-game dogfighting really frustrating as you spiral in vain to get a lock at close range, then miss because the homing capabilities are pretty bad (unless you get a part deep in the American plane part of the aircraft tree, which I didn't because I like the Russian aircraft and wanted to actually get the last one before the end of the game, which I did barely). In an ironic twist, the A-10 ends up as one of the best planes for combating enemy fighters because it's actually slow enough to stay behind them and not stall, allowing you to effectively use your machine gun. 

But the levels themselves aren't super great for flexibility in aircraft choice. You may be unlocking new fancy interceptors with the actual long range air-to-air missiles, but most of the late game missions are very ground-target based. Without spoiling much, the last mission heavily encourages you to bring a very fast interceptor and then punishes you for doing so by putting you in a very small space that's difficult to maneuver in. The plane I had (Su-57) was actually incapable of going slow enough without stalling, so I had to get very creative in many, many tries. But, if you wanted to bring a slower bomber or a multirole, you'll get severely punished in the first part of the mission.

The story is barely coherent at times and often simply makes no sense whatsoever. Things just sort of happen, and one of the major plot points early on is caused by something that is never given a satisfying explanation for the bizarre events that occur. Actually, there's a couple things that cause major shifts in the story and atmosphere that just aren't explained well at all and act like a thing to just make certain gameplay aspects happen. If you just skip all the story cutscenes, you probably won't be any worse off for it.

Overall though, it's fun enough, and if you can get it on sale it's well worth the money. The last Ace Combat game I played was 4, and there's a neat callback to that one (maybe others too).

A true abomination abusing the name Ace Combat.
Too many scripted events, too many stupid design decisions.
A key mechanic in several missions is to ID the targets before firing, them firing on you is not considered ID of being hostile, neither is getting close enough to read the patches on the pilots arms or count their nasal hairs.
Some targets you will identify at 1.8Km, others you can`t identify 1.8CM with your nose resting between their tail planes.
The "strong winds" mechanic...works without any form of logic all the way up to 10,000M above the formation causing the winds and on jets doing better than mach 5.
Guns...why they even bothered putting them in is beyond me, even fully upgraded you could do more damage spitting on target, worse some of the AI have been given godlike missile evasion but the old school technique of smashing them from the sky in a hail of bullets...isn`t available.
The basic missile hell formula with crazy future jets are all there, the developers just managed to get it catastrophically wrong.
I can only hope once again a talented mod team get their hands on this and turn it into something half decent.
The game also has the most stupid blocking of cheaters system i have ever seen...every month you have to suffer a 100Mb update that has then to be integrated into the 12 Gb of game files...just to block a set of people playing multiplayer..its a system even Rube Goldberg or Heath Robinson would look at and say...thats a bit over the top and complex.

If you're into flight games and can't be bothered to learn all about the extra complicated aspects of realistic combat flying, look no further than Ace Combat 7, It won't take you long to get the hang of it, you can use a controller to play it too, plus it's got a fairly good story as well to keep you engaged, you'll get to use a wide variety of exotic and experimental special weapons ranging from multi-lock missiles, guided bombs to stuff like lasers,and railguns,and it's got a really good soundtrack too, the DLC missions are definitely worth a purchase too.


SPOILER WARNING: Once you finish the campaign you will be able to select any aircraft skins you've unlocked and you can put emblems on them too(Note: Some skins including DLC skins will have restrictions on this). 


Multiplayer is a bit limited in its options compared to most other games, you only get Battle Royal and Team Death Match, but it can still be a lot of fun sometimes. 


Whether you're new to the Ace Combat Series or have been playing the Ace Combat games for a long time like me, this one is a must have if you're looking for flight action games. 


Oh and if you've enjoyed playing this game I highly suggest buying a PS2 if you don't already have one and buying the PS2 Ace Combat games and/or Ace Combat 6 if you have an Xbox 360/Xbox One.

It's a bit weird to describe an arcade flight shooter as "magical", but that's the appeal of the Ace Combat series. AC7 isn't just a fun fly by the seat of your pants experience. It's a story. One told through emotional beats, highs and lows, twists and turns, where you are both the hero and the villain, the sidelined soldier watching the war unfold and the hero. And it's told not through forced cutscenes and set pieces, but across the radio as you are tearing through the skies evading dozens of missiles with an orchestra in the background. This is actually a game you keep on wanting to play to see the story unfold.

The gameplay is not overly challenging if you're looking for something casual to spend 10 hours on, but challenging enough on higher difficulties to unlock everything. Missions are varied, and while it obviously isn't intended for the sim pilot, it does force the player to learn the quirks of AC's combat to feel like you're in control. It's fast, intuitive and extremely fun.

I did not expect to love this game as much as I did. The core game-play is amazing, it is fun, exciting and epic.
As a new comer to the Ace Combat series I felt how I was getting better and better at the controls with every mission (changing to the "expert" flight option later on due to it feeling a bit more intuitive and fun).

The story brought me back to the days of Metal Gear Solid, with crazy plot twists and details that are so over the top that I can't stop loving. Today the game has broken the 4 million mark in copies sold, so I've finally decided to write a review. Used to play flight simulators in my childhood, but now I'm interested only in multiplayer shooters. For some reason I thought it'd be fun to try Ace Combat because it's actually arcade. It exceeded all my expectations. Altough it's an arcade, immersion is so great. What also amused me is that despite the simple core gameplay, every mission feels so unique. When I finished the game, I felt like I watched one of those life-changing animes or something like that.
[i]Thank you to all developers for making this masterpiece![/i]
P.S. If you're new to the Ace Combat franchise, I'd recommend watching some videos explaining the lore, but it's not necessary, you can still understand the plot of AC7

I haven't played an Ace Combat (we don't talk about Assault Horizon) since PS2 so when I saw this beauty on sale I couldn't resist. 

It's the same tried and true AC formula but now prettier. The story is still weird but that's okay. It took me about ten hours to beat the campaign on easy. 

The missions aren't each a consistent length, generally 5-20 minutes. Checkpoints aren't always present or at logical points in the missions so you may have to start some missions from the beginning if you die. In some target-rich missions you can run out of missiles so dying actually puts you at an advantage since it refills your ammo when you resume from checkpoint. 

I really wish that Ace Combat had a random scenario generator for solo or co-op play. Some way to just have fun blasting enemies outside of the structured mission list. Repeating campaign missions loses it's appeal when you know exactly what to expect. Seems like a wasted potential for this awesome game engine.

Just finished the campaign at time of writing, and damn is this game great. I watched a review video before buying, and the reviewer described this games feel perfectly: "You know how Forza is like that perfect blend of realism and arcade game play that's super fun? This is like that, but with planes." Hits the nail right on the head.

To add to this, the story is engaging and the music is fantastic, setting the scene and creating a very intense atmosphere. During missions there's tons of radio chatter, which really completes the feeling that you are the squadron ace, fully participating in the events of the game.

I bought this on sale for like $5 with all the DLC, but it is absolutely worth the full price.

Bonus points: I love any game with a space elevator, even if it's not the best game, but this was I think the best use of a space elevator I've seen in a game. [spoiler] It's not just a cool set piece, which is generally the case. Often times the elevator is destroyed in a spectacle, maybe setting the tone of the story. However, in this case, it ends up being what I really think it should be: a symbol of hope for mankind, showing what we can achieve when we work together. At times, it seems like it may be the root of all evil in the world, which it totally can be, but it comes around! Best ending, if you ask me.[/spoiler]

Ace Combat 7 is a spectacular game, carried both by the visuals and the setting of Strangereal. While arcade-heavy, gameplay is involving, with tense, gripping missions influenced by your loadout and are structured in a way to help the player get his bearings at a pace.

 Apart from phenomenal quality of cinematics and the story, the game opens a door to a wider world, showcased in inner monologues and snippets of backstories. The world lore is rich and the supporting characters outside of our squadron each have their own stories. It is refreshing to see the conflict is not about cartoonishly evil empire vs alternative reality american good guys, kind of which we see in Killzone for example, but a rich, complex world influenced by collective histories of the nations that make it up.

 The soundtrack deserves a special mention - a work of art on its own and perfectly fitting for the noble aerial combat. It sets the mood and reinforces the vision of the world our squadron wages war in, providing a truly immersive experience. It's easy to get lost in the moment, just like in the clouds.

 The way conflict is waged, morals and values of combatants and leaders present a precious noble bright setting. Princess Cossette's sorrow, Mihaly's own longing for the skies and the resolve of his graddaughters provide more meaningful input for the setting and theme than most of the missions and quite honestly despite high flying ambitions, the game fails to reach its ceiling, hampered by one-dimensional writing of supporting characters and sub-par voice acting with the exception for some key characters leaves a few scratches on the otherwise pristine canopy. I know your squadron mate thing is that he's a gambler, but repetitive remarks about betting every 15 seconds make you wish he was dead and quite soon you feel a pang of shame about not feeling guilty he finally was. 

 Beauty of the game and the dignified grace it presents make it all worthwhile, however, and with the wider world to look at, flying somehow falls by the wayside. And that is all well, the war is over now and the skies beyond Earth are now within our reach.

Second Mission: Teaches Air to Ground". BEST Weapons for "Ground Attack"
The Game warns Players to spend "Currency" wisely on the Proper Weapons for SPECIFIC Missions.

Finally, a return to form for Ace Combat. There's a big space elevator, there are giant robot drones protecting it,  you'll be having a war between Erusea and Usea with a veteran of Belka, you know the deal (these fake countries may have REAL LIFE analogues!! BUT NOT TOO REAL!!). Me, I've always been at war with the People's Republic of Pineland. This game comes off a lot like Area 88 / UN Squadron, with your scrappy group of POW fighters and eventually a long-range carrier group cut off from the main air force. There's a frame story that's really pretty incoherent, and they really could have done without that. I get it, but like... the whole time you can see how it would be better if your character was involved directly with the story.

Anyway, gameplay-wise, if you like other Aces Combat (not including Assault Horizon) you'll like this one, IMO. The grind system / tech tree is severely lacking, requiring too much grind to unlock what you want and causing your planes to get unlocked in a weird order, possibly to sell DLC? I don't know. It certainly doubled, if not tripled, my playtime. It's a good game, but not fun to have to re-run the high points missions over and over to grind out unlocks.

The Season Pass killer sub DLC is excellent! I kind of wish more of the game had been so tightly packed.

Overall, I'd say BUY IT. And maybe a DLC too, they're cheap, save you some grind. I think the season pass has a couple planes and the killer sub DLC, that's probably a deal.

The most refined gameplay of the series. I know it's important to not fix what isn't broken. but it is a major disappointment that the series refuses to innovate on gameplay mechanics much at all, still even backtracking from AC5 in some areas, and critically lacking a co-op mode or campaign that was offered with Ace Combat Infinity. 

The lack of score-attack missions compared to previous games also hampers replay-ability. I think I have 60 some runs on mission 11, half as many on any other level.

It's beautiful, highly replayable game (8 play-throughs at time of writing), that on its own, is a marvel of gaming, but I can't get over how little is done with what is here. 

Solid 8/10

I was really not sure what I would find while I was installing this game, because I had no idea how simulation-wise it was, or was it too much action and not feeling as realistic as it looks...

But!

In the end I got addicted! Even as a Gamepad noob, I had really fun time going through the campaign. The story, cinematics, mission design, action, it was all really fun and captivating.

I'm sure I will play through the campaign several times more, I may even try the PvP side of it. Anyways, to sum up, the look of planes, the feel of flight and the relatively realistic feel the game is giving is quite nice.

I'd strongly recommend every flight enthusiast to play this game. Unlock every plane and try every weapon and system.

The only problem I had was I couldn't record or keep my mission recordings on the side to watch them again or edit them to watch them later or to upload to Youtube etc. For example there was no recording to watch at the last mission. That was such a waste, it's an amazing ending mission and I'd love to watch how I made it again and again.

Overall an easy 9/10 from me.
Great respects to everyone who worked for this game.

It's an arcade air combat game, just like all the previous others in the series and it's really fun - a great return to form since the misfire that was Assault Horizon. The story is a bit convoluted (one wonders if there are no things such as lawyers, JAG Corps or flight cameras in the Osean military) but also has many memorable moments, the gameplay is really fun, the soundtrack is AMAZING and there's a ton of replay value (unlocking planes, weapons, upgrades, paint schemes, mission rank, chasing the in-game medals and the achievements, experimenting with different planes, challenge runs, etc) so it's total recommend. 

The DLC missions were fun to play but the story was too goofy get me invested; the DLC planes are super good but it's unfulfilling since you don't unlock them. Online is okay, I guess...  everyone is using the F-22 Raptor with QAAMS, so you will do the same and it turns into a competition to see who hits the other first and when you are the one getting the kills you will get kicked out of the lobby by salty people, so it's better to just play with friends. Also, you only unlock the sound player if you buy the season pass and that's scummy. Despite this, still I played this game for 158 hours.

With that said:

This game is phenomenal... It feels really good to play. Different moves and flight tricks you can use to get the upper hand against your opponents. A big selection of aircraft to choose from with different types of guns, rockets, upgrades to aircraft. You can basically choose how you want to play the game.

Start off with the more basic aircrafts, but start moving your way up to eventually unlock the kings and queens of flight that rule the sky today, as of Nov 2nd, 2022. And then eventually move into new and experimental aircraft, which will bring you to the god tier, where you can bring the hammer down on your insignificant and unexpecting foes.

There are also different types of missions to play. You have air to air, air to ground, air to sea, boss battles... and all of them do repeat, but each one has it's own little twist on it. Missions where you need to protect an asset, ones where you need to navigate tight passages, destroy targets on the ground and/or air. 

All in all, this game is amazing. Played through it like 3-4 times on my Xbox, then I upgraded to a PC, and decided to get it on here to experience it again. I also recommend a controller, as it will feel better with the arcade-like feeling of the game. A keyboard will work perfectly with it too. 

When the next one comes out, I will definitely be playing it, 100% guarantee.

Just want to say in advance that i've put in atleast 50+ hours of the game on my PS4 account with the platinum trophy unlocked and all but two single player medals achieved. This review will be more focused on the game itself rather than the technical compatibility.

Ace Combat 7 is a return to form for the franchise after 12 years since the last numbered title. For the most part, the game succeeds in capturing what fans love about the franchise, mainly Ace Combat 04, 5 and Zero, while also making small improvements to the formula to become one of the best experiences in the franchise.

PROS:
+ Beautiful graphics with nicely detailed aircrafts and 3D clouds that adds more dynamic to flight. Ground textures looks muddy at a closer look but that's to be expected with flight sims and it doesn't effect the overall experience.
+ Solid control schemes. 25 years of getting the controls right has led to one of the best designed controls for the entire franchise. Smooth arcade flight controls that gives you complete control of your aircraft that's perfect for both beginners and veteran players to master.
+Absolutely fantastic level design. With 20 base game missions and 3 DLC missions that will test players in their mastery of flight and battle over an estimated 5+ hour campaign. There are atleast one or two levels that doesn't really come together as you want, but overall the entire campaign is expertly crafted with the last 4 missions and the DLC being among the highlights of the franchise. Add that with the replay value to 100% the game and you got a good package. This is Ace Combat mission design at its absolute best.
+Top tier soundtrack. Keiki Kobayashi and the gang are back at it with the soundtrack which has become iconic in its own right. Archangel, Daredevil, Long Day, and Mimic being among my favorites.
+This game is hard. Perhaps the hardest in the entire franchise. But it's hard in a good way. You will be tested to make the best of what you have and prepare in advance on what plane and weapons to sortie with. I heavily recommend new players to start on Easy and veterans to start at Normal difficulty just to get a feel of the game. Having played all of the games except Ace combat 6, 7 really is a whole different ball game.

CONS:
- Story overall felt like a missed opportunity. It has The Force Awaken syndrome of pandering too much towards fan nostalgia without adding more substance to it. There are certainly highlights like Count and the third half of the story but overall, it's disappointing. Nowhere near the quality of Ace Combat 04, 5 and Zero.
- There's some balancing issues regarding the aircraft selection with the loadout strength being a tad too bias towards American planes and some missiles types feeling useless or underpowered. the biggest glaring issues being that there are only 2 Attacker type planes and having two variants of the F-15C which is unnecessary
- More of a personal preference, but i'm not a fan of the scoring system having time being accounted for. This makes missions like Faceless Soldier that require patients become too hectic to get the S rank for.
- Multiplayer while fun feels very underdeveloped. The lack of co-op introduced in Ace Combat 6 being a glaring omission.
- Another personal preference, but the lack of wingman control feels like a missed opportunity both gameplay wise and story wise. What made the wingmen in Ace Combat 5 and Zero so memorable is partly because you directly lead them in-game to battle with commands and such. AC7 opted to go for the Ace Combat 04 route as a lone wolf but with game's large cast of characters, it ends up making you feel disconnected with the rest of your Squadron and that's a real missed opportunity.
-No VR support outside of the PS4 which is a big missed opportunity.
-Shallow customization options for your aircraft. You can only select skins and place one emblem on your plane which is a big downgrade from Assault Horizon and Infinity where you can color the planes right down to the smoke of the missiles and have up to three separate emblems placed on your craft.

Overall, being a fan of the franchise since its inception, Ace Combat 7 is the game i've been waiting for in a long time for the past decade and it almost fulfill all my expectations that comes with the franchise. It may not be my favorite overall (Zero imo is where the franchise peaked.), but it does everything so well that it's up there among the best. I definitely recommend it for anyone looking for an arcade flight experience wanting to get their Top Gun fix and all that jazz. 

P.S. Play with a controller or a flight stick for the full Ace experience!

Its a good game but something went wrong when they ported it over from console.  The input lag is ridiculous; I can make more abrupt control inputs flying a Cessna 172 IRL than I can flying an F/A-18 in game.  I'm talking about .25-.5 seconds for the game to recognize that you've centered the controls.  Input lag makes precision flying nearly impossible and there have been plenty of times I've slammed into something due to it.

I've played Ace Combat since I was a child; this isn't a skill issue.

Do you want a fun game to fly around in with military aircraft? Do you want a solid dogfighting game that's enjoyable with any control setup? Do you want a game that not afraid to give you an innate fear of Latin descending from the sky? Do you want a game that gets as philosophical about war and technology's place in it as the MGS franchise? Well all of that comes in spades with Ace Combat 7.

Fly through the open skies, contemplate the moral implications of replacing soldiers with machines, cripple an old man, and become the mute psychopath you always secretly wanted to be.
This gives you that feeling of watching Top Gun as a kid. Except instead of watching Maverick, you ARE MAVERICK.

Best flight game, feel like a bad ass when I take down the planes. If you are looking for a game that is like the top gun movies this is like it but with a different story line of course.

Cons: 

* Poor introduction for new players - not easy to get into in terms of controls as there is very little tutorial - I used a search engine to find some discussions on the controls to answer some of the questions I had. 
* Mute protagonist - your character doesn't have a voice and never interacts with anyone. This is always an immersion-breaker; huge missed opportunity from a story-telling standpoint. 
* Doesn't seem to be much storyline between missions - mostly radio chatter, etc. during the missions which makes it tougher to get into as your character (whose Callsign is "Trigger"). This is an area of opportunity for the developer if they wanted to bring in more of a story and give the player an opportunity to actually play as a specific character and make narrative choices in conversations, etc. to develop relationships with other characters in the game, from fellow pilots, to commanding officers, to romance opportunities, etc. This would add a lot to the game, IMO as the story flows in a disjointed manner. 
* Targeting system is frustrating at times. At times you'll be in a mission and some additional targets show up that are critical to the mission (like a set of bombers, etc. that you have to quickly take out) - you have no way of tracking them initially; you literally have to just fly around and hope you can find them. You'd think your targeting system could differentiate between target types to find the nearest of a certain type if you're looking for a specific type or the newest on radar, etc. 

Pros: 

* Great graphics & lighting
* Smooth gameplay
* Excellent music during the missions that fit the situations well. 
* Fun combat / controls during flight. Very responsive. 
* No additional nonsense launchers (EA, Ubisoft, Epic, etc.)

Game Length: ~11-12 Hours

Final Rating: 7/10 - this was the first of the Ace Combat series I've played. I have heard the earlier ones are console-exclusive - they should consider remastering them and porting them to PC. I would be interested in checking them out. Overall a solid game - a lot of ways the game could be exponentially better from a storytelling perspective, though, as noted in the Cons area - the main character needs to have more of an identity and absolutely has to have a speaking role / interaction with the other characters - something the much earlier Wing Commander games (90s games that were friggin' awesome) did that helped in this area was having areas to free-roam between missions where you could talk to the other pilots, and even at some points during the series there were romance options, etc which were pretty cool. Food for thought.

Fun game, never played any of the series but found that it fits right in-between pure arcade and pure simulator. I wanted to try a flying game where I didn't have to read a manual and know how to operate a real cockpit but also wasn't on rails and this game nailed it after I used the advanced control set (otherwise it is on rails).

I didn't really follow the story at all, there was a lot of dialogue while flying and in combat and it's too difficult to listen to that and keep yourself alive. It seemed interesting but also felt disjointed. I can say the cinematic cutscenes were really well done, it seemed as if it was partially CGI mixed with reality, I really don't know if it was all CGI but it's hard to believe some of it was, if it was, it definitly fooled me.

The mission are quite varied, ultimately it's destroy a lot of things but oftentimes you had to worry about altitude, or knock out specific targets in time and under pressure. Your guaranteed dogfighting and a fair amount of ground targets throughout the game. I thought the missions were unique and interesting, it wasn't just a big field with the same rinse and repeat objectives, each mission was unique for sure.

I didn't expect a progression tree, it works and you do gain a sense of accomplishment after you unlock better jets with better armaments. It wasn't a driving factor for me but I know others will like it. You can really put some time in and unlock all sorts of jets, weapons, modifications, etc.

Good fun game, not unlike an entertaining summer blockbuster film.

There's a lot to like about AC7, like the plane selection, the multiplayer mode, the new airplane physics tricks (thrust vectoring, control stall stuff), the weapon selection, the music. It even looks pretty good and the cockpit views are great. Hell the DLC planes are a blast to use and the topgun maverick promo is fun!

But the bad thing is you need to play the god-damn missions. This is by far the worst mission design I've ever seen from an Ace Combat game. Special mention must be given to the sandstorm mission and a bunch of the "AVOID RADAR" missions. Also loses points for weirdly scripted and janky boss fights which seem misplaced.

Another problem is the story which is also nearing Final Fantasy levels of nonsense, a far cry from the cyberpunk futurism seen in games like AC3JP (with multiple endings!) and the more grounded war stories of 4 and Zero (Even if all AC games have crazy stuff in them to some degree.)

Good thing we got Project Wingman when we did, because I feel that game is the true continuation of the AC franchise, at least in spirit. Give AC7 a shot if you've followed this franchise since its beginnings in the arcade, but beware of the absolute nonsense. Also worth it if you're into the multiplayer component. Otherwise, Project Wingman is just the better single player experience.

Overall, it's okay but not great.  Visually, it's fantastic.  The airplane models are wonderfully detailed, and the clouds, terrain, and lighting are also very good.  The actual game is more of a mixed bag.  The core gameplay is adequate but uninspired.  The fundamentals are fine; the controls are responsive, the UI is intuitive, etc.  However, the planes don't feel distinct from one another.  Some planes have much higher stats than others (e.g., the F-35 is better than the F-14 in every way), but planes within the same tier all feel pretty much the same (e.g., the Rafael, Eurofighter, and F-15 all feel like slight variations of the same plane, just with different secondary weapons).

Personally, what I find most disappointing is that the planes (including the top-tier planes) never feel especially powerful.  I think that a lot of this comes down to the feeling of the planes' guns.  They're weak, and--perhaps more damning--they look and sound weak and indistinct.  The A-10's 30-mm cannon sounds just like the 20-mm cannon's on other planes, and none of them do much damage to anything.  Each plane is also restricted to a single secondary weapon.

The mission design is okay, though not great.  There's the escort mission, the trench run, etc.  It's all okay, but never feels inspired.

The voice acting and the quality of writing are bad.  It's definitely not the worst I've ever seen in a high-budget game, but it's bad.  It's not game-breaking by any means, but I found it bad enough to be distracting.

Overall, I thought Project Wingman was more enjoyable than this game.  It certainly doesn't have the production value this game has, but it mostly fixes or sidesteps the deficiencies I've outlined here.  I think the Ace Combat series would do well to follow Project Wingman's lead in terms of overall design.

Wingmen are totally useless and don't actually do anything at all (at least on hard), one mission I decided to test this, I only left a single enemy jet left. That last enemy jet survived over five straight minutes against over a dozen wingmen before I had to blow it up myself.

The only game where I fly a plane is usually GTA. Never really try out a game that solely focuses on only flying and combat. Except for Ace Combat X in PSP, but I have no memory of that game. Although daunting at first booting up this game, Ace Combat 7 is actually very simple and fun. I thought it was simulation heavy like Microsoft Simulator but no, the game is pretty arcadey in its flying controls which very much up my alley.

You play as a pilot known as Trigger and do missions sent by the higher ups of the government. I'll be honest, due to my inconsistent playtime and just other games distracting me, I did not focus much on the story. Also my brain just can't focus two things at once, like flying, dogfighting, and then listening to the dialogues between pilots that fleshes out the story. Hell, towards the end I finally knew each of the casts' name. This is just a me problem. With that being said, the story here is one of the best I've experienced. The story is not generic at all like my initial expectations. There are twists and turns and things going wrong in a mission. Not for the sake of subversion but just to show horrors of war, putting characters you know in danger, and just overall fun story stuff. I do hope I just focused more on the story, but damn I never expect it to be this good.

With me being new, I found combat to be fun. There are multiple jets to choose from with different types of special missile equipped. Choosing and customising your jet is key to complete a mission successfully. A mission usually lasts for 30 minutes and you better know what to equip and such. The missions can be hard if you don't know what you are doing. Dark Souls styled, if you know what you're doing than its just easy. But if you don't then back to the hangar we go starting the mission all over again. 

The soundtrack is very fire and Keiki Kobayashi is a chad. It is a crime that the tracks here is not available to listen (atleast not on Spotify). I need this now.

On to the downsides, nothing much really than a me problem. Missions can be very hard if you don't know what you're doing but I have very high tolerance for that. The 2nd half of the final mission can go to hell though. 

Overall, best game I never thought I'd play.
