First, I'll do the quick review.

Ace Combat 7 is a good arcade-style flight shooter, with a fun variety of missions to fly.  It's exhilarating, has a lot of replability, iconic moments you'll want to revisit, and tons of polish at every step.  It's a solid 8/10.

If you have an itch for a flight game that doesn't bog you down in the tedium of true sim, and gives you some fun challenges to face for several hours, you'd be hard-pressed to find a better candidate for your free time.  The AC franchise practically defines the arcade flight genre and leads it in innovation and style.

Gameplay, graphics, music, and story are all solid.  Tweaking aircraft performance via parts is a very interesting new dynamic to the game.  Weather effects giving you real “terrain” in the sky that you have to work around (or if you're smart - worth *with*) was an inspired choice and I love it. 
-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~
Now when AC7 first came out, I wrote a review with opinions that I feel should be revisited now that I've learned a bit more about how and why certain things happened.

In the broad strokes, I accused AC7 of being a good game, and a good AC game, but lacking certain standout features that players have come to expect from this pedigree.  Specifically, “no real incredible/epic final battle”, and “[this game] fails to have a legendary final music track which helped define and elevate it's predecessors like AC4, 5, and Zero”.

Moreover, I also made remarks about the game's story.  Namely that some characters were just badly written, beginning of the story was kinda iffy, and important characters lacked development and kinda just disappear for a while then show up for the finale.  And the core theme of the game, “relegating war to drones and missiles allows you to keep the horrors of wars at arm's length comes at the cost of making you a monster wholly ignorant to the atrocities you're committing remotely”, is definitely present but I really wish they'd actually put it more at the forefront.

Well, long story short, these problems have some overlap and there's a story to it.  First, let me say I WAS WRONG IN SAYING THIS GAME DIDN'T HAVE A LEGENDARY FINAL BATTLE WITH APPROPRIATELY LEGENDARY AND TRANSCENDENT MUSIC.  Basically it comes down to something that happened late in development (you can probably find the full story if you Google it).  Someone on the production team made a phone call and asked the music director to make a legendary music track

...and he did.  He absolutely did.  He created an absolute banger of a music track, music so inspired and incredible that it will live on in the hearts of fans until the end of time.  And I really mean that - I wouldn't be listening to this soundtrack on a 30-minute loop on YouTube if it wasn't completely amazing.

The producers of the game rearranged a lot of things to synchronize this godly music with an epic battle to match.  But the problem is how late this happened in development. Certain things just didn't fit quite right after the changes because those things were set in stone.  So that created a situation where this amazing music and final battle...isn't /actually/ the final battle.  There's still one more mission after.  So when I had talked about “no epic final battle”, I was thinking too narrowly and focusing on what is a somewhat anticlimactic final mission instead of recognizing that the game is  meant to end on mission 19, not 20.

I was at fault for missing the forest for the trees.  While I was not really thrilled with that final mission (mission 20), the thematic end of the game and where this epic music comes into play (mission 19) is every bit as amazing and legendary as the final missions of the big three (AC4, 5, Zero) and deserves to stand with honor alongside it's predecessors as some of the most epic climactic battles ever put into games.

Keiki Kobayashi is a genius composer, with a legendary body of work to his credit.  His achievements speak for themselves and his name deserves to be spoken of in reverence.

This was an absolutely excellent experience from start to finish. The game is beautiful with excellent sound and an easy to use UI, and the in game controls and UI are everything I've come to expect from Ace Combat. It makes for a fun, fulfilling experience as the difficulty continues to increase throughout the campaign in steady, fair, and most important creative and interesting ways. I never felt cheated by a death; if something was hard, I was able to see what I did wrong and how to correct for it (even on one particularly difficult mission where my failures boiled down to "I was getting in a rush and getting sloppy") and the checkpoints are well placed to leave the player staged in a position to quickly reengage without breaking the narrative should they fail.

QA absolutely knocked it out of the park as well- I didn't notice a single bug from start to finish and I'm paid to find that stuff, haha. Usually even very minor defects stick with me but there's absolutely nothing that I saw wrong in my start to finish playthrough which was immensely satisfying on a personal and professional level.

If I were to make any suggestions at all it would be to have hidden items on the aircraft tree shown as ? boxes or something (I ended up spending a lot of points on minor upgrades which I could have used after the campaign was finished, leaving me with the annoyance of having to grind a huge amounts of points to unlock an aircraft I could have taken into multiplayer immediately otherwise). I also found myself somewhat confused by how the narrative was delivered between missions at first, though this cleared up as the game progressed and some of the events made more sense in retrospect- I think localization may have played a part in some of this.

Overall, amazing game, 10/10- I can't wait for the next one! I wish I'd gotten it sooner when the MP scene was still more alive!

I want to preface this review by saying I was a player of AC4/AC5/ACZ before I came into this game and when I wrote this review I had just completed the game.

This game does well with capturing the feel and gameplay of the old Ace Combats while adding new features such as upgrades and other environmental and flying movements such as hard banking. The gameplay and story has the classic ace combat feel with clear science fiction inspirations. I recommend this game.

However, it is not perfect. As classic Ace Combat the story is. The biggest complaint I have with the story is that it is sort of short with only 20 missions vs. 30 in Ace Combat 5. Now there is a season pass that comes with this when I purchased it and I bought it alongside the game. I expect Bandai-Namco to update the game with more planes/missions as time goes on but I can't help but feel there should be more to begin with from the start. 

The other complaint I have from the story is that while there are some familiar names and people that show up indirectly in the story. There is no real character to the real bad guys in the game. In Ace Combat 5 you had the 8492nd squadron that had so much personality and mysteriousness to them. In this game you have Yellow Squadron Mk 2 and basically you never directly fight the real bad guys in head to head combat, only drones. While I like the combat and difficulty aspect in this game, your enemies lack real personality. If there is any real complaint from the game though that is it.

As for the first Ace Combat to make it to PC on Steam, it's pretty good.
I'm running on an 8700k and a 1080 ti at 4k. It is VERY well optimized.

In terms of Rank I'd put it

ACZ > AC5 > AC7 > AC4 > AC6 > ACAH

tl;dr: 

If you want to play only in multiplayer and make your own story in your mind, this might be a great game.
If you mute all radio/story audio, turn off subtitles, and use the campaign as a "I don't care why, just give me a fighter/etc and put some targets in front of me" this might be a great game.
If you want to have a story and a meaning to the campaign's progression and characters you will love (or hate or respect, etc) and an arc of progression that makes you feel immersed and like you are a part of what you have played through - this game will be shit by most standards. 

This is not a game for those who care about anything other than gameplay and/or flight-simulation/

The right decisions:
1- Return to the world of strangereal
2- Focus on story and player impact around characters
3- Innovate on gameplay 
The worst possible direction [spoilers ahead]
- 'let's sprinkle in some geopolitical tensions... but they will not matter at all by the end'.
   Namedrop cities and events from the other series... with no meaningful consequence (you even get to -- once again -- invade a city you invaded 4 games prior; but this time you don't even win anything you just enter a weird limbo state).
   Characters in the cutscenes will openly talk about loving the princess from the nation they're supposed to be at war with because they hear her broadcasts in prison. "enemy of my enemy" except they don't ever say what they like about her and her messages or politics are left to the imagination.

2- Save for your wingman... well, your wingman from mission like... 4? Nobody else becomes a mainstay. Some characters come and go in-game but none really get to make much of a statement -- some are even killed-off ingame as part of a "woooo we're so clever we put in this... wait, we thought we'd make a point about war-time secrecy and the expendability of troops that may pose security/espionage risks; but save for a single radio comment, nobody even seems to notice or care so we're gonna forget this happened" moment. Everybody is "gruff, emotionless bastard", "vulnerable fodder" or "I have a comic-relief gag about food and I tease a guy | guy loves it and me and pretends not to" personality.
3- Thunderstorms are fun and the "clouds-mess-with-missile-locks" mechanic is fun at first (idk if realistic in any way). Some late-game mechanics are also interesting in their own right; I actually have no complaints on this topic though I'd like to have seen some improvements like... for once in the series having the instruments on my planes in cockpit-view actually work and do things (at least give me a screen that mirrors my in-game radar ffs...)

Oh, as for story? 
You either get 5 stories in 1, all bland and half-baked
 - "I'm the gifted-asshole stereotype -- my talent is making jets good -- and I got drafted into slave-labor for Brosea because I happened to fly a plane minutes after war was declared. I have no lawyer, no rights and no prospects even though I have friends in the top-brass due to my granddad. I am anti-war and anti-this-war except I end up not actually trying to leave.
- Colonel "I am an asshole and want promotions - that's it, that's my character arc"
- Everyone you meet up until mission like... 10 or something - "I am kiiiiinda rightfully imprisoned for very obvious crimes I readily admit - unlike you protagonist - and I don't even have a heart of gold I'm just a normal-ish guy who's also an ace pilot who's also either going to die or not be mentioned again soon"
- "I am a very thinly-veiled nazi scientist working with an old war criminal to create the perfect killer-bot because... reasons. I speak with a very calm demeanor about how I am responsible for creating a devastating world war... because I don't quite care about the two superpowers I am working against. I will change my mind at the last moment because ... reasons"
- "I am a soft-spoken child-princess that rises up to the occasion... except all I do is make speeches, do dumb teenager shit and... take a swan dive".

I really cannot emphasize how much worse the story is than those tidbits.

The gameplay is great, but it's properly insulting that a series that nailed this so fantastically in AC4, 5 (best IMO) and "Zero" [each with their hits and misses but collectively extremely superior to this garbage] could fall so far with so much time on their hands.

I don't trust this studio anymore.

Having never known who and especially what I really am, LIFE has been a hard game to play since its very beginning.
Luckily enough I found my inner self rather soon when I saw this beauty for the first time, the AH-64 Appache attack helicopter.
I finally knew who and what I was and held onto that idea ever since, no matter how much the others were mockin me. 
Starting in kindergarting going on through elementary and high school, even at the university I never let off the idea that I would be an Appache attack helicopter.

With all the hype coming from the game i myself was excited. And its turns out you can actually outgrow a game.

I was excited on the prospect of a simple point and shoot shooter and with sightseeing involved while flying my favorite plane of all.

But right of the bat we  have a problem... The Logitech Extreme 3D Pro nor the the any of my other more expensive HOTAS does not work. So i can only play it with either a keyboard or an Xbox 360 controller as those works.

But having played other flight sim. The feel of flying an aircraft on a gamepad wasn't really a good experience and it greatly detracts from the experience.

Despite being cheap i found the Logitech Extreme 3D Pro to be a good fit for my hand and with every important action could have been mapped on the head which makes for a simple and intuitive controls.  The game pad jsut doesnt give you the same range of motion and precision that can be had on a Flight Stick. 

The next issue is on the game mode itself. I have played the snot out of AC2 and that was probably my most favorite iteration aside from AC5. And having played both games a lot. I was excited to play those same missions under a different skin.

And here is where my biggest issue for the game lies. It got boring... Doing the same mission as i did from before turned out to be boring and repetitive for me. The time element on each mission was still a challenge especially when you stubbornly use a single aircraft for each. But yeah. I have outgrown it.

The multiplayer mode is what you would call chaotic. As each weapon is point and shoot. Every engagement devolves in who gets lucky enough to score the most hit using the most OP plane in the roster. Having no Flight Dynamics to speak of there's no point in knowing fighter maneuvers,,, 

So yeah. Unless your an actual 12 year old. There's no joy to this game.

Update September 25, 2022 Game is still has no HOTAS SUPPORT. This game is basically just sitting in my inventory unused i dont think i would support the game and its developer anymore.

The game has some fun moments to be sure, but ultimately it's undone by a number of factors.
- The story starts of interesting but devolves into a confusing mess.
- Some of the missions are poorly designed and are exercises in frustration, especially if you didn't choose the right aircraft for the job (the game makes almost no attempt to help you choose).
- You can't direct your wing-mates like you could in AC 6. And the friendly AI in general is completely useless.

One of my favorite parts of AC 6 was that each mission had an enemy ace that wasn't specifically pointed out as a target, but if you found them and shot them down you got to read about their history. It was a cool bit of world building and it was up to the player to find them. Nothing like that is in this game. Overall it's a major step down from it's predecessor.
funny jet game fun

There are things to like about this game.  The flying and dogfighting generally feel good, and the advanced controls are fun to play with.  But there are too many problems for me to give this game a positive rating.

For one, the story is all over the place, unclear, and very hokey.  I tried to get into it and really paid attention to the mission briefings and cutscenes, but in the end it all just felt like a bad anime with poorly-developed characters and a plot that got lost before it was ever really found.

Missions are frantic.  Your wingmen, allies, and commanders yell and scream at you every second; and their instructions often conflict.  Objectives are not always clear, and failures are far too easy to just stumble into even when you feel like you're flying a million miles per hour doing everything one human being can possibly do.  And that leads me to the fact that your wingmen are utterly useless.  They talk and talk and talk and ultimately do nothing.  If there's too much going on, you can bet they'll do nothing but yell at you to take care of everything.  This makes many of the missions, especially the addon missions, ungodly hard.  Maybe some people find ball-busting challenge like that fun.  I do not.

Everything is either timed, gated behind a point threshold, or both.  You cannot just get into a mission or dogfight and have fun with it.  You're not only racing the AI and the mission design but the clock and performance thresholds as well.  This makes every single mission feel like a gut-wrenching tightrope walk along the razor's edge of instant failure.  While that kind of tension and suspense can be fun here and there in a story's narrative, having every single mission function that way leads to adrenaline fatigue and burnout.  Not fun.

I really wanted to like this game.  Had been thinking about getting it for some time and took the opportunity to snatch up on it while it was on sale.  But between the bad storytelling, frantic and unclear nature of every mission, and sheer insane difficulty, I just can't recommend it.  Pick it up if you catch it on sale and are prepared to keep expectations in check while enjoying feeling like a fighter pilot.  But be ready to be frustrated to hell and back as you resist chucking your controller clear across the room over and over again.

Great game if you're into blowing shit up and feeling like a badass. The plot is weird and isn't all there at times, but that hardly matters in games like these. You don't play Ace Combat for the plot (though they can be good), you play it for the power fantasy and the god-tier soundtrack.

I don't think this needs clarification but this game ISN'T a flight sim so don't expect hardcore realism. Expect pulling ridiculous high-G turns that would 100% push your organs out your asshole, 120 missiles + bombs on your plane, and being a one man air force. That is Ace Combat, and it's bloody awesome.

If you are an aviation enthusiast and you're not a realism snob, this is a solid choice for you. 

9/10 Honks, though admittedly, this franchise is what made me pursue a career in aviation and holds a special place in my heart, so I'm a little bit biased. Take that score with a grain of salt.

Metal Gear Solid but Planes, and bangers all the way down. The story is a continuation of the previous storyline so don't worry if you're confused at first, the story is very cool to deep dive into (I definitely did) but if you're not into that, don't worry, the gameplay has you covered. 

Firstly, if you aren't playing with a gamepad or HOTAS, YOU SHOULD BE USING A GAMEPAD OR HOTAS. This game really isn't great on keyboard and mouse. You can play it that way kinda, but its not designed for that at all. 
Also, if you want the full freedom of movement, USE THE EXPERT CONTROLS. The default simple controls prevent your plane from going upside down and basically is star fox style controls. It works, but the expert control give you the feeling of really controlling a multi-million dollar piece of military hardware going mach 5 with its ass on fire and blowing up a ground target while doing a midair somersault (which is something you can do in this game). It takes maybe 15-20 minutes to get the hang of the expert controls, its not a big deal, and the game is soooo much more rewarding when you do.

I cannot recommend this game enough. If you have the slightest passing interest in this game please get it, it is sooo worth it. Also, The DLC with Patchy the Pirate's SALVATION tour is S tier, so if you like this game get that too. 

Also Top Gun Maverick has a crossover with this game.

10/10 Would Dogfight a Geriatric with a Railgun over a Medieval castle again
